An AT&T corporate vice president, Tom Norris, labeled any allegations of impropriety as ``preposterous'' and said the company would fight any move to force it to disclose more information about its rate filings. The petition was filed on the same day that Democratic members of the House telecommunications subcommittee urged the FCC not to make ``a multibillion-dollar mistake'' by too aggressively deregulating the long-distance marketplace. At the subcommittee hearing, Sikes was asked to defend commission proposals to loosen further federal oversight of AT&T and impose a new price-based regulatory system on the interstate long-distance earnings of the nation's local telephone companies. Lawmakers said they feared the FCC had not sufficiently studied recent changes in the long-distance business and the impact that a major deregulatory change on AT&T last year has had on the marketplace. Sikes declined to delay action on the proposed regulatory changes, both of which could happen before 1991, but he said he would make a report to Congress on the current state of the marketplace. The petition to the FCC dealt with the commission's order that local phone companies on July 1 of this year reduce by $1.1 billion the charges they levied on long-distance carriers to connect with local telephone networks. Under the rate-of-return regulation that the FCC abandoned in 1989, AT&T was required to pass on most, if not all, of its share of these savings to customers. Such actions have been the primary reason long-distance prices have declined more than 40 percent since 1984. The ``price cap'' regulatory scheme that the FCC adopted in July 1989 restricts AT&T's prices instead of its earnings to give it an incentive to hold down costs and prices. AT&T doesn't necessarily have to pass through all of the ``access charge'' reductions to customers. In fact, AT&T boosted some small business prices on July 27. AT&T's share of the $1.1 billion access charge reduction was about $520 million, according to the July 30 issue of Business Week magazine. But the company's July 1 prices cuts were just $300 million. The petition by the Consumer Federation of America, the International Communications Association and the National Association of State Utility Consumer Advocates asked the FCC to look into the ``apparent discrepancy of at least $140 million _ and perhaps as much as $200 million.'' The groups, noting that the FCC had estimated consumers would save $900 million over four years under price caps, said AT&T should be required to file data supporting the rate cuts ``to ensure that ratepayers are realizing all of the savings the commission promised.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Former Striking Pilots Can Bump Trainees
DOC.TEXT: Union pilots who struck Eastern Airlines are entitled to replace trainees hired to help the carrier rebuild, a federal judge said. Thursday's ruling by U.S. District Judge Edward Davis apparently affects only those who were in training when time the pilots ended their walkout, said E.J. Breen, spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association. Still, Breen said, ``It's clearly a major victory.'' All but 200 of the 3,600 union pilots walked off the job in sympathy with Machinists who struck the Miami-based airline in March 1989. Pilots ended their sympathy walkout in November, but fewer than 50 have been called back to Eastern, pilots association officials say. The Machinists are still striking. At least 404 pilots were in training when the pilots returned to work, the pilots association says. The airline estimates only 180 jobs are affected by the ruling, Eastern spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak said. Further hearings likely will be determine the exact number of affected jobs, Breen said. Eastern said in a statement it would appeal the decision. The airline predicted the ruling wouldn't immediately affect current employees or operations. Many pilots took jobs with other airlines after the strike began March 4, 1989, but about 1,400 former Eastern pilots may still be interested in returning, pilots' association spokesman Lou Baldwin said. Davis' ruling stems from the association's challenge of Eastern's claim that the formerly striking pilots were not needed. Davis agreed that the federal Railway Labor Act guarantees returning strikers job rights ahead of newly hired trainees. Davis said Eastern violated the Railway Labor Act by hiring pilot trainees not already qualified to fly regular flights. The act was devised to provide ``uninterrupted transportation service,'' the ruling said. Eastern sought bankruptcy protection five days after the strike began. It presently operates about 800 flights, down from its pre-strike service of 1,040. Ms. Ceremsak said she does not believe Davis' ruling must receive bankruptcy court approval. If the ruling is upheld on appeal, all returning pilots would need to go through several weeks of recertification training under the Federal Aviation Administration, Eastern officials said. Eastern currently has about 1,900 pilots, including those trained before the strike was settled, pilots hired from other airlines and union pilots who later crossed picket lines. Baldwin said the Eastern pilots trainees' annual pay is about $27,000. The average pre-strike pay at Eastern for fully accredited pilots was about $65,000, he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Iraq Invades Kuwait, Soldiers Surge into Oilfields; Overnight Shelling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with fighting reported all night around Kuwait's main military barracks. Pickup 4th graf `Kuwait's emir...'; EDITS thereafter to trim.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos FRA1, FRA2
DOC.TEXT: Shelling was reported at Kuwait's main military barracks Friday, a day after Iraqi troops overran the oil-rich Persian Gulf sheikdom and caused a storm of criticism worldwide. Iraqi soldiers also were reported surging through the southern oilfields near the Saudi Arabian border. Iraq, which said it set up a provisional Kuwaiti government, warned foreign governments it would turn the rich sultanate into a ``graveyard'' if they came to Kuwait's aid. A U.S. aircraft carrier was steaming toward the gulf to join a flotilla of other U.S. warships. Residents, speaking by telephone on condition of anonymity, said they heard shelling throughout the night in the northern area of Shuwaikh where the barracks are located. The report indicated that resistance was stiffer than the first day of the invasion. Residents in the capital woke up to what one described as ``as very active gunshots and louder explosions than at any time'' since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein launched the invasion early Thursday. Artillery shelling also occurred on the gulf coast, 16 miles from Shuwaikh, with two military vehicles on fire, the residents said. It was not immediately clear what was going on in that area. There was no word on casualties in the latest fighting. Diplomats said at least 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded the day before. Kuwait's emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, fled to neighboring Saudi Arabia. His government pledged in a radio broadcast early Friday to win back the country, but with the huge imbalance of armed forces that seemed impossible. Iraq has 1 million soldiers. Kuwait has 20,300. Iraqis occupied all government buildings in Kuwait City and strengthened their hold on the capital Friday as they moved south to the oil installations at Mina al-Ahmadi, officials said. Iraqi soldiers swept through the oilfields early Friday, according to residents and Lloyds' insurance service in London. Saudi Arabia issued a statement through the official Saudi Press Agency, saying it was following the situation with extreme concern. Iraq said its troops entered at the request of revolutionaries it said had staged a coup. Kuwaiti and other diplomats called the coup report a charade. The move by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein brought worldwide condemnation and sanctions. The Soviet Union, Iraq's biggest arms supplier, said it was suspending weapons shipments to Iraq. President Bush called the invasion ``naked aggression.'' He froze control of Iraqi assets in the United States and blocked most Iraqi imports, including its most important revenue source _ oil. Fellow Arab states, though, failed to take action. Iraq responded by freezing repayment of Iraqi debts to the United States, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. The total size of the debt is unclear. Last year, Washington provided $1 billion in agricultural credits to Iraq. Iraqi soldiers rounded up and moved ``a few'' American oil field workers from their work places near the border of Kuwait and their whereabouts are unknown, a State Department official said in Washington. The official, like many other sources, spoke on condition of anonymity. The Pentagon earlier Thursday ordered an aircraft carrier into the region. Bush said military intervention was not under discussion, but later noted that if Americans in Kuwait ``are threatened or harmed ... I have certain responsibilities.'' About 3,000 Americans are in Kuwait. A White House spokesman said no reports surfaced of American casualties. Kuwait, through its U.S. ambassador, appealed for U.S. military intervention. The Soviet news agency Tass reported out of Kuwait City that ``a figh near the Soviet Embassy ... was short and fierce. ... A column of Iraqi tanks surrounded the palace of Crown Prince Prime Minister Saad al-Abdullah (al-Sabah) and shelled it for about half an hour from guns and machine guns. ``After Iraqis made sure there would be no more retaliatory firing from the palace, they drew up in a march formation and a column of tanks moved along the bank toward Salmiya, where several yacht clubs are situated.'' Sheik Fahd al-Ahmed al-Sabah, a brother of the emir, was killed trying to defend the royal palace in Dasman, diplomats in the Persian Gulf confirmed. The emir's radio station called it a ``barbaric invasion.'' ``Under the leadership of the emir, we shall by God deter the invaders, purify our beloved country from their treachery and send them fleeing back,'' Crown Prince Saad said in a later broadcast from an undisclosed site. In other developments: _The U.N. Security Council voted 14-0 to condemn the invasion and demanded immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops. The vote carries no enforcement powers. _The State Department said Secretary of State James A. Baker III would fly to Moscow on Friday to issue a rare joint statement about the crisis with his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. _The invasion created turmoil in world financial markets, with the price of oil, gold and the dollar rising steeply. In Baghdad, the Revolutionary Command Council led by Saddam issued a statement saying Iraq intervened in support of ``The Provisional Government of Free Kuwait.'' It said the government was made up of ``revolutionary youths.'' The provisional government announced through Baghdad's INA that it was dissolving parliament and would hold ``free and honest elections'' at a future date. Iraq also warned foreign governments against coming to Kuwait's aid. ``Our armed forces will close in an iron rank against those who try to challenge us and will make Iraq and Kuwait a graveyard for those who launch any aggression,'' a statement on official Baghdad radio said. Iraq began threatening Kuwait two weeks ago after accusing it of stealing oil from a border region claimed by both nations. It also accused Kuwait of depriving it of oil revenues by cheating on OPEC production quotas, thus driving down oil prices with plentiful supplies. Talks to resolve the dispute broke down Wednesday, and diplomats said Iraq had moved 100,000-120,000 soldiers to the Kuwait border. Early Thursday, about 350 Iraqi tanks wheeled into the capital after crossing the border 40 miles away, diplomats said. Within two hours, they had taken the emir's palace. Residents of the area said about 50 tanks surrounded the palace and the neighboring American Embassy. Persian Gulf-based Western diplomats said the invasion was too swift to arrange for evacuation of nationals. The Iraqi armed forces were led by the elite Republican Guard, which did the brunt of the fighting in the 1980-88 war with Iran. Thousands of residents attempted to flee in their cars. Iraqi troops set up roadblocks and shot at cars that did not stop. Kuwait is a former British protectorate that gained independence in 1961. Its 1.9 million residents are among the world's wealthiest because of vast oil reserves. Iraq, with 17 million residents, has long coveted its territory. Kuwait sided with Iraq in the Iraq-Iran war.

DOC.HEAD: President Wants Fewer Troops But More Weaponry
DOC.TEXT: President Bush envisions needing 500,000 fewer troops by 1995 in a restructured, fast-response U.S. military, but he wants to move full speed ahead on major weapons programs, including the B-2 stealth bomber and Trident submarine. Bush, in a major speech on defense policy in Aspen, Colo., on Thursday, said Iraq's ``brutal aggression'' against Kuwait demonstrates that ``the world remains a dangerous place.'' ``Even in a world where democracy and freedom have made great gains, threats remain,'' Bush told an Aspen Institute symposium. ``Terrorism. Hostage taking. Renegade regimes and unpredictable rulers ... all require a strong and engaged America.'' On a trip cut short by the Iraqi invasion, the president announced his support for a 25 percent reduction in America's 2.1 million active duty military personnel over the next five years. That would be the lowest level since 1950. Bush said the threat of a sudden Soviet invasion of Western Europe was ``more remote'' than ever in the postwar period, and ``the Cold War is now drawing to a close.'' ``With the emergence of democracy in Eastern Europe, the Warsaw Pact has lost its military meaning,'' he said. An administration official said 200,000 of the 1 million civilian jobs in the Defense Department would be cut by the mid-1990s in addition to the 500,000 uniformed positions. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also predicted that military bases at home and overseas ``will be reduced and restructured dramatically'' as part of the troop reduction. The possibility of a 25 percent military cut has been raised previously by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Some members of Congress favor even deeper retrenchment. ``What we need are not merely reductions, but restructuring,'' said Bush, outlining his vision of a military that would continue strategic modernization. This would include building all 75 radar-evading B-2 bombers and 18 Trident missile submarines in his defense plan, pressing ahead with the mobile Midgetman missile and putting the silo-based MX missile on rails. Bush said a restructured military must be tailored to respond rapidly to crises anywhere in the world. ``A new emphasis on flexibility and versatility must guide our efforts,'' he said. ``These threats can, as we've seen just in the last 24 hours, arise suddenly, unpredictably and from unexpected quarters.'' ``The events of the past day underscore also the vital need for a defense structure which not only preserves our security but provides the resources for supporting the legitimate self-defense needs of our friends and allies,'' the president said. The House Armed Services Committee voted Tuesday to trim the 2.1 million active duty personnel by 129,500 by the fall of 1991, more than triple Bush's proposal for a cut of 40,000. The committee, proposing to slash Bush's $307 billion military budget proposal by $24 billion, also recommended ending the B-2 bomber program at the 15 planes already authorized, making deep cuts in the Star Wars antimissile program and halting plans for the mobile nuclear missiles. Working on its $289 billion version of the 1991 defense bill Thursday, the Senate rejected a proposal to end the B-2 program at 15 planes but imposed restrictions on it until critical tests on the plane have been conducted. Cheney has said a 25 percent troop reduction could save $8.6 billion over five years as the Pentagon retired six Army divisions, 111 Navy ships and 11 Air Force tactical fighter wings, and removed 442,000 personnel from active duty. Cheney may announce new proposed military base closings as early as next week. Before his Aspen speech, Bush conferred with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, also attending the Aspen Institute symposium. Her defense minister, Tom King, last week announced plans to reduce the size of the British army by 25 percent over five to seven years.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Closes Down
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,515.76, down 729.42 points, or 2.41 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Committee Wants Trump To Testify on How He Got Bank Loans
DOC.TEXT: The House Banking Committee wants New York real estate developer Donald Trump to explain how he persuaded major banks to loan him $2 billion that he is now struggling to repay. Committee Chairman Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas has twice invited Trump to an Aug. 9 committee session. So far, Trump hasn't replied. At a time when soured real estate loans are cutting into many banks' profits, the committee wants to look into ``commercial real estate lending principles ... in general and more specifically the banks' handling of the Trump organization loans,'' Gonzalez said in a letter to Trump. Gonzalez, in a notice to committee members Thursday, said the Trump loans illustrate the problems banks are having in some areas of the country. Representatives of state and federal regulatory agencies have said they will appear, as have three banking analysts. However, representatives of Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and other banks who lent to Trump haven't replied to the panel's invitations.
DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Will Return to Philippines When Safety Is Assured
DOC.TEXT: Peace Corps volunteers will return to the Philippines when their safety can be assured, the corps director said after the release of a worker detained for 50 days by Filipino communist guerrillas. Timothy Swanson, a 26-year-old volunteer from Cheyenne, Wyo., was released Thursday by New People's Army insurgents and he appeared to be physically unharmed, corps director Paul Coverdell said. The program's suspension June 27 was not intended to be permanent, and ``I think there are valid reasons for us to begin discussions to find a way volunteers can return to that country in safety,'' Coverdell said. However, he said, ``Until we can verify that safety, they cannot return.'' He did not list specific conditions. U.S. officials suspended the Philippines program after learning that the New People's Army had targeted volunteers for attack. Manila headquarters did not learn Swanson had been abducted from his home in Negros province on June 13 until it summoned participants to return to America two weeks later. The reason for the kidnapping remains unknown, Coverdell said. The Peace Corps began Philippine operations 30 years ago. Until it abducted Swanson, the New People's Army left all foreign volunteers alone, Coverdell said. Their release of Swanson and of Fumio Mizuno, a detained member of a Japanese service organization, may suggest that they have reverted to the earlier hands-off policy, he said, but ``it is too early to know as yet.''
DOC.HEAD: House Approves Airport User Fees for Passengers
DOC.TEXT: The House approved passenger user fees at airports as a way of financing new gates, runways and other construction designed to cut increasing congestion and delays. Fees would be limited to $3 per passenger at each airport, with a ceiling of $12 per passenger for one round-trip. ``This bill will bring our air transport system into the 21st century,'' said Rep. Lawrence Coughlin, R-Pa., as the House voted 252-171 Thursday to defeat an effort to drop the user fees from the legislation. The House then approved the bill 405-15. The measure would authorize $17 billion over two years for airport operations and development. It calls for spending more than $6 billion in the Aviation Trust Fund over the next five years to upgrade airports. The Senate has taken no action on the plan. House members clashed over the provision authorizing local airports to impose fees on passengers. Whether to impose such fees would be a decision made by local officials, subject to regulation by the federal Department of Transportation. Improvements are needed to ease crowding and delays caused by an increase in airline passengers from 266 million in 1978 to 480 million last year. Authorities are forecasting an increase to 750 million within 10 years. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., and other Chicagoans said that a third major airport to service the city could not be built without the passenger charge. The new airport is estimated to cost $4.9 billion. But critics said the fees would benefit only a few cities with major construction projects on the drawing board _ especially Chicago _ and that most travelers would reap no benefits from the airport improvements. ``Aviation passengers are being taken for a ride by the White House and Congress,'' said Rep. Norman Mineta, D-Calif. A study by airport associations has suggested that $10 billion a year would be needed for the next five years to overcome congestion at many of the nation's major airports. The Transportation Department has generally accepted the estimate. Rep. William F. Clinger Jr., R-Pa., said the critics had provided no alternative way to meet the costs. ``They can hope the tooth fairy will, under cover of night, extend the runway or build the new terminal,'' Clinger said.

Quirky `Twin Peaks,' `The Simpsons' Get Surprise Emmy Nominations
LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: Two quirky series with cult followings were among television series showered with Emmy award nominations. But once again, heavyweight housewife Roseanne Barr failed to impress the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. ABC's offbeat ``Twin Peaks,'' the critically acclaimed but poorly rated saga of sex, murder and cherry pie in a fictional Pacific Northwest logging town, snared an industry-leading 14 Emmy nominations Thursday. ``The Simpsons,'' Fox Broadcasting Co.'s cartoon chronicle of a grumbling American family, collected five nominations _ three for primetime series and two for a Christmas special. ``Twin Peaks'' was nominated as outstanding drama series. The show's executive producers, David Lynch and Mark Frost, shared a nomination for best writing. Lynch, the auteur filmmaker, also was nominated for best drama directing. ``We're just delighted to be in the position we have suddenly found ourselves in,'' said Frost. ``Frankly, the whole thing has sort of been out of left field and this is the icing on the cake.'' The Emmy nominations also could bring added respectability to ``The Simpsons,'' featuring wisecracking 10-year-old Bart Simpson, who vaulted to national prominence with a rebellious attitude and resurrected American slang phrases like ``Don't have a cow, man.'' The show has been criticized for its often cynical portrayal of the American family. ``Simpsons'' executive producer James L. Brooks said he was ``in a sleepy, sweaty puddle'' when awakened with news of the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences nominations announced during a pre-dawn ceremony by actor Louis Gosset Jr. and ``China Beach'' star Dana Delany. ABC's top-rated ``Roseanne'' received two selections, one for co-star John Goodman as best supporting actor. But Barr was snubbed by academy voters, who also ignored the controversial comic in last year's nominations. ``It always takes the industry a few years to catch up with anything ground-breaking,'' said Barr's husband, Tom Arnold. Barr wouldn't comment. Earlier this week she told talk show host Sally Jessy Raphael that last year's snub ``really my hurt feelings,'' but she expected the same this year. ABC's highly rated ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' also was ignored by the academy, proving that top Nielsen figures don't automatically translate into Emmy nominations. NBC's legal eagles on ``L.A. Law'' received 13 nominations. The network's long-running comedy ``Cheers'' and CBS's hit ``Murphy Brown'' both amassed 12 nominations each. ``The Simpsons'' was nominated in the category of ``outstanding animated program for programming one hour or less,'' where competition included Garfield and Charlie Brown specials. ABC won 95 nominations overall, tying it for first with NBC. ABC finished last in the 1989 nominations, a position held this year by CBS, with 73 selections. Upstart Fox earned 26, more than double its 12 nominations last year. Another notable Fox nominee was ``In Living Color'' _ a highly praised sketch comedy show featuring mostly black performers. Kyle MacLachlan, the cherry pie-loving FBI agent on ``Twin Peaks,'' was nominated for best actor in a drama series. Piper Laurie earned a lead drama actress nomination. Other nominees for best drama series were ABC's ``China Beach'' and ``thirtysomething,'' and NBC's ``L.A. Law'' and ``Quantum Leap.'' Six programs honored Thursday won't be on television next season: Fox's ``The Tracey Ullman Show,'' which earned 13 nominations, CBS' ``Newhart,'' ``Beauty and the Beast,'' ``The Famous Teddy Z,'' ``The Equalizer'' and ``Mancuso FBI.'' One nomination went to the late Muppets creator Jim Henson, who was named for directing a variety or music program. Other nominees for best dramatic actor were Peter Falk of ABC's ``Columbo,'' Edward Woodward from CBS' ``The Equalizer,'' Robert Loggia in NBC's ``Mancuso FBI,'' and Scott Bakula of ``Quantum Leap.'' Dramatic actress choices included last year's winner, Dana Delany, of ``China Beach,'' Jill Eikenberry from ``L.A. Law,'' Angela Lansbury for CBS' ``Murder, She Wrote'' and Patricia Wettig in ``thirtysomething.'' Winners will be announced Sept. 16 at a ceremony in Pasadena scheduled for broadcast on Fox.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed in Car Bomb in Southern Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb has exploded near an office of the Syrian-backed Amal militia in this southern port city, killing eight people and wounding 75 others, police said today. They said the car, rigged with 43 pounds of explosives, detonated in the city's Hay al-Raml district at 11 p.m. Thursday. A police spokesman in Tyre, 80 miles south of Beirut, said the casualties occurred when people rushed to check damage caused by a small bomb that blew up minutes before the car bomb exploded. The spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said one Amal militiaman was among the dead and 10 others among the wounded. The car bomb, the sixth in Lebanon this year, came a few hours after a booby-trapped car exploded in Nabatiyeh, killing one person and wounding four others. No one claimed responsibility for either attack. Reporters based in Tyre said Amal militiamen toured the city in cars today, urging the population through loudspeakers to observe a general strike today to protest what they called an ``Iranian massacre.'' The daylong strike was called for in Amal-controlled Tyre and Nabatiyeh, 18 miles farther south. Amal has been locked in a 3-year-old intermittent war with the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiite Moslems, who make up the country's largest sect. By police count, more than 1,000 people have been killed and 4,000 wounded in the power struggle.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Loses 765,000 Members So Far This Year
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party has lost 765,000 members so far this year, leaving it with about 18 million members, the party's personnel chief says. Boris Pugo says 370,000 members have joined Russian President Boris Yeltsin and other reformers in quitting the party, about three times the number of membership cards turned in during all of 1989. In addition, 125,000 members were expelled, 120,000 died and 150,000 stopped paying their membership dues or participating in party activities, he told Tass on Wednesday. In the first six months of this year, 125,000 new members have signed up, for a net loss of 765,000 members, said Pugo, chairman of the party's Central Control Committee. Pugo said many people had joined the party to promote their careers. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has moved to separate the government from party jobs and affairs since taking office in 1985. As a result, the Communist Party has lost much prestigious along with its constitutionally guaranteed leading role in society. ``The figures are not large enough to speak about a catastrophe or an extraordinary situation in the party,'' Pugo told Tass. ``It is not large enough to cause great concern.'' Pugo could not say how many people have quit since the party's 28th congress ended July 13. Yeltsin stunned the meeting by announcing he was quitting the party to concentrating on governing the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. Other leading reformers, including the mayors of both Moscow and Leningrad, have also quit. Party officials said between 120,000 and 130,000 people resigned from the party last year.

DOC.HEAD: Commando Who Fled Links Himself to More Rapes, Police Say
DOC.TEXT: An Army commando recaptured after escaping police custody en route to court to face two rape charges has linked himself to nine more rapes in three other states, state police said. Master Sgt. Marshall L. Brown, 37, was captured unarmed by police early Thursday in a stolen car in an East Providence parking lot. Police found Brown through a tip from a confidential source. The former Green Beret and Ranger escaped Monday after freeing himself from handcuffs while being taken from a jail to the courthouse for a hearing on two charges he raped two Cranston, R.I., women. He faces life in prison if convicted on those charges. He also had been charged with two rapes in North Carolina, where he was a member of the Army Special Forces stationed at Fort Bragg. After he was recaptured, Brown gave state police information linking him to five rapes in North Carolina and four others in Texas and Arizona, Lt. Brian Andrews said. Brown was cooperative, Andrews said, but he stopped short of calling Brown's remarks a confession. It was not clear whether the five North Carolina rapes included the two for which Brown already had been charged. Brown, of Spring Lake, N.C., was attending a nine-week course at the Naval Education and Training Center in Newport when Cranston police arrested him on June 11, 1989. The alleged rapes outside Rhode Island occurred between November 1988 and May 1989, said Attorney General James E. O'Neil. He declined to be more specific. O'Neil said additional charges of escape and theft were expected to be filed as early as today. Brown most recently was a member of the Delta Force, the secret anti-terrorist group and took part in the failed raid to free U.S. hostages from Iran in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Indicts New York Congressman on Fraud, Tax Evasion Charges
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Floyd Flake and his wife face federal charges they embezzled more than $140,000 from a government-subsidized housing project for the elderly and the church where Flake is pastor. The indictment, unsealed Thursday after a two-year investigation, prompted denials of any wrongdoing and at least one allegation that some black elected officials appear to be targets of selective prosecution. U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney replied, ``We go wherever the evidence takes us.'' Flake, 45, was indicted on 17 counts of conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion, and his wife Margarett, 42, was indicted on nine counts, Maloney said. The Democrat who represents New York's predominantly black 6th District in Queens was charged with diverting $141,700 from church and housing funds for personal use and failing to report it as taxable income. Flake said he had cooperated with the investigation and accused the prosecutor of ``attempting to substitute his judgment on how a church should manage its affairs and how a pastor should fulfill his special duties.'' Flake's lawyer, Gustave H. Newman, said the money was used for ``church-related activities'' and that the case would not affect the congressman's plans to seek re-election to a third House term in November. Mrs. Flake's attorney, Theodore V. Wells Jr., said his client was added to the indictment simply because she signed joint tax returns. The indictment will ``give further credence to the perception that minority politicians don't get even-handed treatment,'' Wells said. Similar accusations have surfaced recently regarding Washington Mayor Marion Barry and Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley. Flake is pastor of the Allen African Methodist Church, which was founded in the 1830s and has a 6,000-member congregation. It built the 300-unit Allen Senior Citizens Apartments in 1981 with a $10 million federal loan. The church operates the complex with a $100,000 monthly subsidy from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The indictment charged that between 1983 and 1987, the Flakes embezzled $75,000 from the complex. Maloney said the money was siphoned from money set aside to transport the elderly residents to local stores, banks and restaurants. The indictment alleged that Flake took another $66,700 from a special church ``ministerial expense fund'' account for his own use between 1983 and 1988. If convicted on all 17 counts, Flake could be sentenced to a maximum of 87 years in prison and fined up to $3.95 million. His wife could face penalties of 55 years in prison and fines of up to $2.1 million. The investigation began based on information from sources including ``an alleged paramour'' of Flake, Maloney said, refusing to disclose further details.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Killed, Girl Wounded in More N.Y.C. Street Violence
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager arguing over a moped was shot and killed by another teen who allegedly wanted to make a name for himself as a tough, the latest slaying in a rash of street violence in New York City. Hours later, a girl was critically wounded when a gunman opened fire on a group of people standing on a corner. Since July 22 in New York, four children from 9 months to 9 years old have been killed by stray gunfire, a young advertising executive was shot to death while using a pay telephone on a street, and a couple was clubbed in Central Park by a deranged attacker. Gunmen also have killed two more cab drivers _ Nos. 18 and 19 this year in the city _ in the past two weeks. Late Wednesday night, 14-year-old Shamel Knight was fatally shot in the mouth in the borough of Queens after he told another teen-ager to stop riding a moped that belonged to friend, police said. The boy was killed by a 19-year-old who had boasted he wanted to be a famous criminal, witnesses told The New York Times. The suspect fled and remained loose today. Early Thursday in the Bronx, a gunman opened fire on a group of people standing on a street corner, hitting Yanira Correra, 15, in the chest. She was in critical condition at Lincoln Hospital, police said. Police arrested a 20-year-old man nearby on weapons charges, but did not know if he was involved in Correra's shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Plunges, Dollar Gains Against Yen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Wraps up, adds details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plummeted as the dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen today because of uncertainties over the Iraq-Kuwait conflict, traders said. The dollar finished trading at 149.35 yen, up 0.45 yen from Thursday's close of 148.90 yen. After opening at 149.77 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 148.90 yen and 150.35 yen. On the stock market, 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average shed 729.42 points, or 2.41 percent, ending the day at 29,515.76. It lost 592.81 points Thursday. ``The drop is because of nothing else but concern over the Iraq-Kuwait situation,'' said Kenji Maeshiro, an analyst with Yamaichi Securities Co. The index dropped more than 600 points early in the morning and then narrowed the loss to 291.71 at the end of the morning session. It fell back again in the afternoon on a rumor that Iraqi troops were heading for the border of Saudi Arabia, Maeshiro said. He said large-scale arbitrage selling to take profits from price differences between the spot and the future markets also fueled the plunge in the last 30 minutes of the afternoon session. As a result of the last-minute massive selling, the index ended at the day's low. ``Because rumors come out one after another, market players just could not figure out what was really happening over there, and growing uncertainties and fears prompted selling,'' Maeshiro said. Iraq invaded Kuwait and took control of its capital Thursday. Japanese participants are sensitive to Middle East conditions because Japan could be hurt more than any other major industrialized nation by disruptions in oil supplies. Maeshiro said already-rising oil prices also discouraged buying because of predictions that higher oil prices would lead to inflation and delay possible U.S. action to lower interest rates to revitalize its economy. North Sea Brent crude oil prices moved sharply higher today as the market continued to react to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. By 3 p.m., Brent crude oil for September delivery was at $23.00 to 23.30 a barrel, or higher than the $22.00 late Thursday in New York. Earlier Thursday in Tokyo, September Brent was valued at $22.60 a barrel. Stock trading was thin with first section volume destimated at 430 million shares, up from Thursday's 400 million. In currency dealings, dollar-yen trading continued to fluctuate nervously as market players were influenced by rumors about the Middle East, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. Following its overnight strength against the yen in New York, the dollar opened higher and continued to rise as market players saw little movement toward a peaceful settlement of the conflict between Iraq and Kuwait. ``Participants tended to buy the dollar because they think the dollar is a safe investment,'' Kanai said. The dollar had been falling recently because of gloomy predictions for U.S. economic growth. ``It's difficult to find any factor now to buy the yen,'' said Yuichi Tsuchiko, a dealer with Fuji Bank. With uncertain prospects in the Middle East, coupled with rising oil prices and a slump in the Tokyo stock market, Tsuchiko said many market players adopted a wait-and-see position. Japan depends on imports for nearly all its oil needs. The yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 7.705 percent, up from Thursday's 7.615 percent finish. Their price ended at 84.72 points, down from Thursday's 85.11 points.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Cesar in Mid-Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Cesar steadily moved across the mid-Atlantic today from the coastal African waters where it was born. Cesar was just south of the Tropic of Cancer, about 920 miles west of the Cape Verde islands, forecaster said. They said it was moving west-northwest near 16 mph with maximum sustained winds of near 50 mph. The storm was expected to maintain that motion through Saturday, with little change in strength, said forecaster Miles Lawrence. ``It's not bothering anybody right now, except maybe ships,'' said specialist Robert Molleda of the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. At 6 a.m. EDT today, Cesar was located near 19.1 north latitude and 39.8 longitude, the center said. Cesar, the fourth tropical depression of the Atlantic hurricane season, grew from a tropical wave that formed Wednesday afternoon. On Thursday, Hurricane Bertha dissipated after striking the coast of Newfoundland. Tropical depressions become storms when their top sustained winds reach 39 mph. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 through Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Captive Peace Corps Worker in Philippines Endured Marxist Propaganda
DOC.TEXT: A Peace Corps worker freed by communist guerrillas in the Philippines wasn't harmed during 50 days of captivity, but he had to endure droning Marxist propaganda and tales of jungle ambush, his parents said. Timothy Swanson, 26, was freed Thursday by the New People's Army. In a telephone call with parents Larry and Lynne Swanson, he said he became fed up with guerrillas' rebel yells and communist indoctrination. ``He was questioned rather heavily at first and then later I think they tried to influence him a bit,'' his mother said. ``He said he got so sick of revolutionary music and stories of ambush he started to complain ... so they stopped.'' Mrs. Swanson said her son sounded a little tired, but otherwise was in good spirits. ``When he went into the Peace Corps he wanted a little adventure. Well, he got it,'' she said, ``It's just so sad that the world is not a place where people can help each other and not be suspect.'' President Bush, who met briefly with the Swansons when he visited Cheyenne on July 20, called to congratulate the family after the release. ``We thought it was very nice of him to call,'' Larry Swanson said. Mrs. Swanson said her son was expected to return to the United States on Sunday or Monday. He was scheduled for a medical examination today and debriefing by Philippine authorities. Swanson was abducted him in the middle of the night June 13 on Negros, a Philippine island. Led by three armed rebels, he hiked for several days into the back country before reaching camp, she said. ``He said he was treated well. He had no restraints. He said he was treated pretty much as one of them,'' she said. ``Apparently, they wanted him to see what their life was like. They may have been trying to indoctrinate him.'' Toward the end of Swanson's captivity, the situation became tiresome, his mother said. ``His basic feeling at least during the latter part of his captivity was mainly boredom,'' she said. ``He was sick to death of the thing.'' Swanson was released by the rebels shortly after a Japanese aid worker who had been held since May 29 was freed. The United States suspended all Peace Corps operations in the Philippines on June 27 and sent volunteers home because of alleged reports that the rebels planned to target them. U.S. officials said they were unaware of Swanson's kidnapping when the order was issued and learned of it June 30 when they tried to contact him. The captives mother was proud of her son for joining the Peace Corps. ``I'm not sorry he did what he did,'' she said. ``I believe he was doing the right thing. I'm so proud of that kid _ I guess I should call him a man.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in Florida, Skies Mostly Clear Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms broke out in Florida early today while skies were mostly clear over the rest of the nation. Most of flood-plagued Texas was looking forward to a break from rainy weather as the forecast called for a mixture of clouds and sun. Some thunderstorm activity was expected along the Gulf Coast, as well as in Arkansas, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia and Florida. A high pressure system remained over the Northeast with continued sunny skies and low humidity expected. A band of thunderstorms was forming over the northern central states, with rain forecast for Minnesota, Wisconsin, South Dakota and Nebraska. High pressure was also expected to bring sunny skies to the West, except for some thunderstorms in Arizona and New Mexico, with temperatures mostly in the 90s and 100s. Temperatures were expected to reach the 80s in the Northeast and Midwest, and the 90s in the South. The high for the nation Thursday was 109 degrees at Bullhead City, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Forces Tighten Grip, World Reaction Hardens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 30 grafs to UPDATE with France sending second warship to gulf, phone links cut off, fighting subsides, more countries freezing Kuwaiti assets or condemning invasion. Pickup 30th graf `Iraq responded...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX7,8,NY8
DOC.TEXT: Shelling and gunfire today shook portions of Kuwait's capital, where invading Iraqi troops sought to consolidate their hold on the Persian Gulf nation. World reaction toughened against Iraq. The U.S. aircraft carrier Independence headed to the region, and President Bush refused to rule out direct U.S. military intervention, calling Iraq's lightning attack Thursday on its smaller southern neighbor ``naked aggression.'' France said it planned to send a second warship to the gulf. World oil prices jumped sharply Thursday and U.S. lawmakers demanded a worldwide boycott of Iraqi oil. The invasion followed weeks of threats by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in a dispute with Kuwait over oil, land and money. Iraq threatened to turn the rich sheikdom into a ``graveyard'' if anyone tried to intervene and said it installed a government to replace the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who fled the country. The 21-member Arab League scheduled a closed meeting today while Arab leaders held urgent consultations on how to respond to the crisis. There was no further word on casualties. Diplomats said at least 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded the day before, most of them from the government Emiri Guard. Shelling in Kuwait city occurred at the country's main military barracks in the northern area of Shuwaikh and was heard throughout the night, indicating resistance was stiffer than the first day of the invasion. There was also artillery shelling on the gulf coast, 16 miles from Shuwaikh, and two military vehicles were on fire, the residents said, speaking by phone on condition of anonymity. A British Embassy official, quoted by the British news agency Press Association, today reported explosions and gunfire along the seafront in Kuwait City and around key installations, including the emir's palace. A curfew was in force, all ports were sealed, the airport remained closed and the three main land crossings into Kuwait were impassable, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. By this afternoon, gulf-based diplomats speaking on condition of anonymity said the fighting had abated. Telephone operators in the gulf nation of Bahrain who previously had been able to reach Kuwait said this afternoon that lines appeared to have been cut off. The sheik's government vowed to fight to win back the country, a seemingly impossible task since Iraq has 1 million soldiers in its army and Kuwait has 20,000. His radio station, beaming from an unknown location, reported that the emir was taking charge of directing the resistance from a ``safe place.'' Meanwhile, a spokesman at the U.S. Embassy said three Americans had been seized by the Iraqis from the Shuaiba oil refinery. He indicated that the Iraqis had taken them to help run the refinery and ``not as any particular threat'' to the Americans within Kuwait. The spokesman, who could not be named under embassy rules, said the Iraqis were not hostile to Americans. Soldiers escorted Americans they met on the streets to their homes and were ``treating them very well,'' he said. Nearly 4,000 Americans are among the large expatriate community in Kuwait, where more than 60 percent of the 1.9 million residents are foreigners. Iraq has 17 million residents. Iraq recently accused Kuwait of stealing oil. It claimed its troops entered Kuwait at the request of revolutionaries who it said had staged a coup. Kuwaiti and other diplomats said the coup report was a farce. Iraqi troops backed by 350 tanks and air cover swept into Kuwait before dawn Thursday, meeting brave but ultimately ineffective resistance from the vastly outnumbered Kuwaitis, said the diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity. Iraqi soldiers were making sweeps today through the southern oilfields near Saudi Arabia, according to residents and Lloyds' insurance service in London. Izzat Ibrahim, deputy chairman of Iraq's ruling Revolutionary Command Council, flew to Saudi Arabia today on an official visit, the Iraq News Agency reported. The two oil giants have a non-aggression pact. In the United States, members of Congress, after briefings by intelligence officials, expressed fears that Iraq's next target could be Saudi Arabia. However, a well-informed diplomatic source in the gulf reported no movement of Iraqi troops into Saudi Arabia or directly across the Iraq-Saudi Arabian border. The invasion of Kuwait brought universal condemnation and sanctions. The U.N. Security Council on Thursday denounced the occupation and demanded that Iraq withdraw its troops immediately. More countries joined the United States in denouncing the invasion, including South Korea, New Zealand, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, China, Singapore. The Soviet Union, Iraq's biggest arms supplier, announced a suspension of shipments to Iraq. The United States froze Iraqi assets and blocked most Iraqi imports, including its most important revenue source _ oil. The United States, Britain and France froze Kuwaiti assets Thursday to protect the holdings from Iraqi occupiers. Japan and West Germany were among other nations that followed suit today, officials said. Iraq responded to the American moves by freezing repayment of Iraqi debts to the United States, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. The total size of the debt is unclear. Last year, the United States provided $1 billion in agricultural credits to Iraq. Iraq began threatening Kuwait two weeks ago after accusing it of stealing oil from a border region claimed by both nations. It also accused Kuwait of depriving it of oil revenues by cheating on OPEC oil cartel production quotas, thus driving down oil prices. Talks to resolve the dispute broke down Wednesday, and diplomats said Iraq had moved about 100,000 soldiers to the Kuwait border. It was unclear whether the takeover would slow or halt Kuwait's oil production, but it seemed to signal an important shift in the balance of world oil power. Private analysts said Thursday in the United States countries dependent on imported oil now face new economic risks. The United States gets half its oil from abroad, 10 percent of which comes from Iraq and Kuwait. By grabbing control of Kuwait, Saddam added about 94 billion barrels of oil reserves to his country's own 100 billion barrels, second only to Saudi Arabia, according to the American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade group. Iraq, larger than California, has coveted New Jersey-sized Kuwait for decades. Their common border was left undemarcated upon Kuwait's independence from Britain in 1961.

DOC.HEAD: France To Send Second Warship To Persian Gulf
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: France will station a second warship in the Persian Gulf because of Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait, acting Premier Pierre Beregovoy said today. Beregovoy said a second gunboat, or corvette, will be sent to the region, but he did not say when it would be dispatched. France had planned to replace one ship with the other, Beregovoy said in a radio interview. He is finance minister but acting head of government while Prime Minister Michel Rocard is on vacation. The government decided to leave the first gunboat in place ``and the one that was supposed to replace it will join it'' in the gulf, Beregovoy told Radio-Television Luxembourg in an interview broadcast in France. He did not say when the second ship would arrive. Iraqi troops and tanks swarmed across the border into oil-rich Kuwait early Thursday, shelling parts of Kuwait city and sending the country's leaders fleeing to Saudi Arabia. The U.N. Security Council denounced the invasion. ``We must now examine under what conditions the decisions of the United Nations can be respected, that is, the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait,'' Beregovoy said. He noted that France acted along with other Western nations in freezing assets of Iraq and Kuwait, the latter mainly to protect them from seizure by Iraq, and by halting arms sales to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower; Yen Remains Soft
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against the Japanese yen but retreated against other key currencies today. The dollar was well down from its peaks a day earlier in a flurry of reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Gold prices were lower. In Tokyo, the dollar finished trading at 149.35 yen, up 0.45 yen from Thursday's close of 148.90 yen. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 149.37. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday: _ 1.5925 West German marks, down from 1.5970 _ 1.3515 Swiss francs, down from 1.3570 _ 5.3375 French francs, down from 5.3510 _ 1.7950 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7985 _ 1,165.00 Italian lire, down from 1,168.50 _ 1.1518 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1519 In London, the British pound rose to $1.8583 from $1.8495 late Thursday. Dollar-yen trading continued to fluctuate nervously as market players were influenced by rumors about the Middle East, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. Following its overnight strength against the yen in New York, the dollar opened higher and continued to rise as market players saw little movement toward a peaceful settlement of the conflict between Iraq and Kuwait. ``Participants tended to buy the dollar because they think the dollar is a safe investment,'' Kanai said. The dollar had been falling recently because of gloomy predictions for U.S. economic growth. ``It's difficult to find any factor now to buy the yen,'' said Yuichi Tsuchiko, a dealer with Fuji Bank in Tokyo. Gold in London was quoted at $375.80 a troy ounce at the morning fixing, down from $378.75 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, gold was quoted at $375.75 from $379.00 bid late Thursday. Silver bullion in London was quoted at a bid price of $4.85 a troy ounce from $.87 bid late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Blast Away at World's Biggest Target Shoot
DOC.TEXT: The Swiss have lived up to their trigger-happy reputation at the ``symphony of shots,'' expending 4,450,000 bullets in a barrage of gunfire at the Federal Shooting Fest. The biggest recreational shooting contest of its kind worldwide has ended in the industrial city of Winterthur, 220 miles northeast of Geneva, and organizers called it a blazing success. For 17 days through last Sunday, more than 80,000 men and women took turns blasting away at 463 targets on 16 shooting ranges from 7:30 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. ``Winterthur has demonstrated that the interest in our sport is unbroken,'' said Hans Zuercher, central secretary of the Federal Shooters' Association. It was a ``refreshing contrast from the gloom and doom that has been spreading in the past few years,'' said Willy Loretan, a Swiss parliamentary deputy. ``It's high time for us Swiss to show more joy and optimism. We do not want to be viewed any longer as European champions of humorlessness,'' he said. The Tages-Anzeiger newspaper of Zurich described it as a ``symphony of shots.'' Target shooting is highly popular in Switzerland, although a national referendum last November showed an ebbing of popular support for the citizens' army, the main promoter of marksmanship. Shooting has been a hallowed tradition among the Swiss ever since _ as legend has it _ William Tell sent an arrow through an apple on his son's head about 700 years ago. The 580,000 organized shooters in a nation of 6.7 million have plenty of opportunity to practice their marksmanship. Even the tiniest village has easy access to one of the 3,000 ranges scattered throughout the country. On almost every weekend from April to September, firing echoes through Alpine valleys. Part of the practice is obligatory. Every soldier of the Swiss militia army between the ages of 20 and 42 annually is required to achieve a certain minimum score in shooting at targets during off-duty practice. This system means 423,000 automatic rifles are kept in Swiss homes. Every militia man discharged at age 50 can keep his weapon as private property, allowing him to continue practice unless he decides to sell the rifle on the second-hand market. It makes for a lot of guns in a nation pledged to permanent neutrality, which last saw fighting 143 years ago in a one-month civil war that claimed 138 dead. Yet military weapons are rarely used to commit crimes in this largely violence-free country. Participants at Wintherthur ranged in age from 16 to 95-year-old Sepp Walker, who scored above average with his carbine. Overall best marksman was Malcolm Cooper, Britain's double Olympic gold medalist in shooting. His foreign passport barred him from becoming a ``King,'' the title bestowed on the top finishers in the various categories of the competition. Attention focused on the debut of the 22-inch Model 90 automatic rifle, with which the army is replacing its current 33-year-old version. Tests suggest that what Swiss newspapers described as a ``wonder weapon'' is of very high precision. Demand for the private, non-automatic version, which sells for $,680, has outstripped supply. Delivery time is more than a month. So far more than 22,000 have been sold, compared with 30,000 delivered to the army. ``It's lighter and handier than the '57 model,'' said Zuercher. ``That is one reason why there is increasing interest in marksmanship among women and girls. There is a definite trend.'' One of the 3,400 female participants, 18-year-old Corinne Haas, turned in a better performance with the new rifle than two Swiss army generals.

DOC.HEAD: Government Tries to Restore Order; Parliament To Be Searched For Explosives
DOC.TEXT: The government struggled to restore order and prepared to search the Parliament building for bombs following the surrender of Moslem radicals who held government officials hostage. Security forces on Thursday fired warning shots at looters still plaguing the capital. A state of emergency imposed during the six-day hostage standoff that ended Wednesday remained in effect. Government spokesman Gregory Shaw said a regional security force of 300 led by a Jamaican colonel was to arrive today ``to guard installations, thereby freeing local forces to patrol.'' He did not specify which countries were involved. Soldiers said they would send demolition experts into the Parliament Building, which they have stayed out of because they feared time-delayed explosives. During the standoff, the radicals threatened to blow up their hostages. The government says at least 30 people died before the hostages were freed Wednesday, and authorities expect to find more bodies in the legislative building and the burned-out police headquarters. A government Cabinet minister held by Moslem radicals said Thursday she repeatedly believed ``I was going to die.'' ``They decided that all of us were expendable,'' she said. Jennifer Johnson, Minister of Sports and Culture, went on state television to discuss her hostage ordeal. The Moslem rebels launched their revolt last Friday by storming Parliament and broadcast buildings in the capital, and rebel leader Abu Bakr declared his forces to be in control of the Caribbean island off northeast Venezuela. However, the uprising never attracted popular support, and government forces surrounded the rebels and their captives. The standoff ended Wednesday with the release of the hostages and the surrender of 112 rebels. Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson, still recovering in a hospital from several ailments including a gunshot to the leg, was freed Tuesday. Bakr and his followers were being held at the Chaguaramas military headquarters, about 10 miles from the capital. Shaw said the government was studying what charges to bring against them. He indicated they could be accused of murder, kidnapping or treason, which carries the death penalty. Bakr is a former policeman who converted to Islam and considers himself a champion of the downtrodden. He had accused Robinson of corruption and blamed him for widespread poverty in this once oil-rich nation of 1.3 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Newsrooms Should Hire More Black Journalists, Group Says
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers should hire more black and other minority journalists to accurately reflect the country's racial composition, says the vice president of the National Association of Black Journalists. ``America is browner and tanner and is going to continue to be in the future and the industry must reflect that perspective and diverse view of the world through the people it hires,'' Denise Johnson said Thursday. Johnson made her comments at the association's annual convention, which some 2,000 people are attending. Hiring rates for minorities in journalism have increased little in recent years, according to a report by the American Society of Newspaper Editors released at the convention's start on Wednesday. The report found that 4 percent of newsroom employees, including reporters, editors, artists and photographers, were minorities in 1978, compared to 7.86 percent this year. Blacks now account for 4 percent of the newsroom population, the highest percentage among all minority groups. ``If you look at the percentages and how slowly the industry has moved to respond to a very rapidly changing population, the progress isn't nearly as impressive,'' said Johnson, an editorial writer and columnist for the Saint Paul (Minn.) Pioneer Press. The report also said that 4 percent of newspapers across the United States employ no minorities. ``Most institutions in this country are still pretty much dominated by white middle-age males and I think the tendency on their part is to look out over the staff of people they direct and take under their wing a person who reminds them of themselves,'' Johnson said. Editors surveyed by the ASNE said the most frequent reasons for not hiring more minorities include the lack of qualified journalism graduates, poor starting salaries and a lack of commitment to affirmative-action hiring. The study queried more than 300 newspaper editors, said Cornelius Foote Jr., minority affairs director of the ASNE.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinista Peasants Seize Agriculture Minister's Ranch
By FILADELFO ALEMAN
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Peasants loyal to the former leftist Sandinista government have seized a ranch belonging to the minister of agriculture, protesting the takeover of Sandinista cooperatives by backers of the new government. The pro-Sandinista newspaper Barricada published a picture Thursday of the peasants hoisting machetes at the ranch's main gate. The hacienda owned by Agriculture Minister Roberto Rondon, a member of the new conservative government, was seized Wednesday about 10 miles northeast of Juigalpa in Chontales province, about 100 miles southeast of Managua. ``We will stay at the hacienda until the government returns various haciendas that (government) sympathizers have invaded here and in other regions,'' vowed Carlos Espinoza, a member of the Association of Field Workers. Espinoza also said Thursday that government sympathizers and former Contra rebels have threatened to take over another Sandinista cooperative. The seizures follow complaints that the new government of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro that assumed power from the Sandinistas in April is not responding quickly enough to demands for land distribution. When the government took power, it said lands confiscated by the Sandinistas would be returned to their previous owners. The decree angered the Sandinistas and provoked a strike in July that grew into full-scale riots, killing at least seven people and injuring 100. As part of the settlement, the government agreed to suspend the decree. Gustavo Tablada, director of the Institute for Agrarian Reform, said a resolution to the dispute is being sought ``through dialogue and not coercion.'' The seizures began July 19 when peasants sympathetic to the National Opposition Union, which carried Mrs. Chamorro to the presidency in free elections, took over two haciendas in La Concepcion, 25 miles east of Managua. Pro-government peasants invaded the haciendas the day Sandinista cooperative workers traveled to Managua to commemorate the 11th anniversary of the revolution that brought the Sandinistas to power. When they returned, they found the pro-government sympathizers armed with machetes and rifles taking cover in trenches. A fight followed in which an opposition union sympathizer was shot to death, witnesses said. On July 27, pro-government peasants and recently demobilized Contra rebels took over another hacienda about 60 miles southeast of Juigalpa.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted of Killing Stepson to be Sentenced in Mid-August
DOC.TEXT: Jurors split over whether a man convicted of killing his stepson during potty training by repeatedly plunging him headfirst into a toilet should be sentenced to death in the electric chair. The tie vote Thursday is interpreted by the court as a recommendation for a life sentence for 23-year-old Thomas Coe. A simple majority of the 12 jurors was necessary to recommend the death penalty. Circuit Judge Randall McDonald set sentencing for Aug. 17. The judge can overrule the panel. Coe was convicted Monday of first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse in the July 28, 1989, death of Bradley McGee. ``That man deserves to die for murdering Bradley McGee,'' prosecutor John Aguero told jurors Thursday. Aguero said the 2-year-old was repeatedly slammed headfirst into the toilet, pulled out of the bowl and plunged into a cold bath, then forced into the living room and beaten unconscious. Defense attorneys appealed for compassion and understanding, urging the panel to spare Coe's life. He was a loner with suicidal tendencies who was an outcast among peers because of illnesses, and was subjected to abuse from his parents, they said. The final witness Thursday in the trial's penalty phase was psychologist Harry Krop, who testified the killer had been a severely abused child. He came from a home where his mother was critical and judgmental, his father hit him with a switch to teach him to defend himself, Krop said. Coe was born with painful kidney and hip defects, wore a catheter until he was 5, was hospitalized more than 30 times and walked with a limp, the panel was told. ``He even failed at suicide ... twice ... once with a gun and once with a rope,'' Krop said. Coe's 21-year-old wife, Sheryl McGee Coe, pleaded no contest to second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse in her son's death and testified against her husband. She is serving a 30-year prison term. Bradley had been under state care from the age of 4 months, when his mother abandoned him. The social worker who recommended Bradley be returned to his mother and Coe _ two months before his death _ was convicted earlier this year of child abuse.

DOC.HEAD: High Temperatures, Drought Hit Europe
DOC.TEXT: Unusually hot weather in Europe has killed five people in Spain and caused Greece's worst drought in 100 years. Between late June and late July, temperatures of up to 109 degrees were recorded twice in the southern region of Andalusia, where three people died because of the heat. Two more deaths occurred in the northwestern city of Vigo. Those have been the only fatalities reported so far, and temperatures in most southern European nations remain well below record levels. Dutch forecasters insisted Thursday that the nation was not facing what could be officially termed a heat wave. But temperatures of well over 86 degrees have hit France, Britain and the Netherlands, whose residents normally use the holiday season to flee their rain-prone climes for sunnier weather in southern Europe. The hot weather has been news on front pages in France and the Netherlands, where it was the lead story in several Thursday morning newspapers. ``Heat Becomes Nuisance,'' said a headline in the Rotterdam newspaper Algemeen Dagblad. Amsterdam's De Telegraaf said, ``Dutch Learning To Cope With Heat.'' A third newspaper, Trouw, used up almost half of its front page quoting what it called an ``interior environmental physicist.'' The expert, J. Vorenkamp, explained his ``window discipline'' theory _ opening windows at night and keeping them closed at day to make the most of a building's natural insulation. In England, authorities blamed the heat for stopping the famous Big Ben bell in London's Houses of Parliament for more than three hours Wednesday. At Colchester Zoo in England visitors were asked to bring leaves to feed its two baby elephants, Tania and Zola, because normal feed supplies of willow, sweet chestnut, poplar and oak leaves had been destroyed in the drought. More serious, however, is the drought that has been afflicting much of the continent since the spring. In Greece, authorities described the drought situation as the worst in 100 years and set up a plan to ship water to Athens by supertanker if the need should arise. Although water rates in the Greek capital have been tripled in an effort to cut consumption, reservoirs are expected to run dry by November, when the rainy season usually starts. In Italy, rainfall from Jan. 1 to July 20 this year was nearly 40 percent below the average of the last 30 years, according to a Weather Bureau spokesman, Lt. Col. Paolo Ernani. The national weather service reported that temperatures in Italy during late July and early August were 7.2 degrees higher than average. Forest fires fanned by the drought raged in Portugal and Spain, where many were believed to have been set by arsonists. Portuguese National Fire Service chief Cristiano Santos said his men were exhausted after fighting fires that have destroyed more than 61,750 acres of forest, bush and farm land since mid-June. Santos told Portugal's Lusa news agency there were 27 percent more fires between June 15 and July 23 than during the same period last year. Drought conditions in Belgium prompted authorities to ban watering gardens, washing cars and filling up private swimming pools in two of the nation's nine provinces.

DOC.HEAD: Lava is Covering Famed Black Sand Beach
DOC.TEXT: Lava from Kilauea Volcano crept along the Black Sand Beach, closing one of the island's most popular beaches to tourists and forcing some residents from their homes. A lava flow about 500 yards wide engulfed about half of Kaimu Bay and the beach on the southeast coast of the island of Hawaii, Glenn Sodayasu of the Hawaii County civil defense agency said Thursday night. The inland part of the flow was some 350 yards away from the closest of nine houses that have been evacuated, he said. Residents of 40 other homes nearby were told to prepare to leave. ``It's a stressful time for these people, who have to move out of their homes,'' civil defense spokesman Wendell Hatada said. ``They've lived there most of their lives, mostly, and a lot of them have lived there for generations.'' Visitors were prohibited from the area so residents could move their belongings without throngs of tourists clogging the narrow two-lane road. The area is one of the island's best surfing spots, with the exotic beach a favorite of residents, tourists and photographers. It is used often as a backdrop for commercials. Lava began flowing from the Kupaianaha vent 15 miles east of Kilauea crater Wednesday night after a two-day pause. Trade winds helped blow ``laze'' out to sea, Civil Defense spokesman John Katsky said. Laze, a mixture of lava and ocean water that forms hydrochloric acid, poses health hazards, especially to people with respiratory problems. Lava from Kilauea Volcano has destroyed 169 homes, parks, several businesses, a church and other historical sites since its current eruption began Jan. 3, 1983. Damage is estimated at more than $61 million, and the Kalapana area was declared a federal disaster area.

DOC.HEAD: Magistrate Gives Banks Two Weeks to Provide Noriega Records
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for Manuel Noriega says a magistrate's decision to order three European banks to provide records of his accounts should help find millions of dollars needed for the ousted Panamanian leader's defense. U.S. Magistrate William Turnoff on Thursday gave the three banks 14 days to provide detailed records. Noriega's lead attorney, Frank Rubino, subpoenaed the documents late last month. ``We're thrilled because this now gives us the ability to find out which accounts had the funds in them,'' Rubino said. ``We have the right to say which accounts are unfrozen. We don't want accounts unfrozen that have three dollars in them.'' The U.S. government agreed in June to help the defense unfreeze between $4 million and $6 million from various European accounts so Noriega could pay his lawyers. Rubino said it was the first time a federal court has backed a private litigant's effort to examine foreign bank records. ``It's the first time a private person has broken the banking secrecy law,'' Rubino said after the magistrate's hearing. Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. troops on Jan. 4 following the invasion of Panama, is being held in a jail outside Miami on charges he took $4.6 million in bribes to protect the Colombian cocaine trade. Turnoff heard more than two ho7.2. The index fell 34.5 points on Thursday. Volume came to 290.3 million shares at midday, compared with 339.2 million shares at the same time Thursday. Analysts said the price rise reflected some bargain-hunting and demand for oil stocks, dealers said. But one dealer said that some oil stocks have run their course and are meeting resistance as investors take profits.

DOC.HEAD: Drunken Burglar Gets One-Year Jail Term
DOC.TEXT: A drunken burglar who passed out while robbing a couple's home was sentenced to a year in jail after pleading guilty to felony charges. William Spencer Castro, 21, an undocumented alien from El Salvador, was also sentenced Wednesday to one year of house arrest, placed on five years' probation and ordered to attend Alcoholics Anonymous meetings. Castro admitted he had about 20 beers before he broke into the home in suburban Van Nuys in March, authorities said. Carrying a 7-inch kitchen knife, Castro filled his pockets with jewelry, money and other items. He then passed out next to the couple's bed, authorities said. Betty Bernds, 83, discovered Castro on the floor about 2 a.m. March 26 when she accidentally stepped on him as she got out of bed to help her husband, Edward, 84. Castro was still unconscious when police arrived.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Iraq's Move Could Threaten Israel; Jordan a Key
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Israel never ruling out possibility of invasion, CORRECTS sourcing to Israeli analyst sted newspaper on possible warning to U.S. Pickup 4th pvs, `The Hadashot...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's conquest of Kuwait increases the chances of another Arab-Israeli conflict and heightens Jordan's importance as a buffer state, Israeli analysts say. Amatzia Baram, an Iraq specialist at Haifa University, said today that the Israelis had warned U.S. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney last month that an Iraqi military strike against Kuwait was likely. Baram said the Americans apparently discounted the warnings as self-serving. But Defense Ministry spokesman Dan Naveh denied the report, saying Defense Minister Moshe Arens raised the subject of possible Iraqi aggression but did not specifically mention Kuwait when he met with Cheney in Washington. Naveh, however, said Israel never ruled out the possibility of an invasion. The Hadashot daily quoted a senior military intelligence officer, Brig. Gen. Dani Rothschild, as saying Israel expected an attack after Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein moved thousands of troops to the Kuwaiti border last month. ``You don't consolidate forces like that in order to do nothing,'' Rothschild was quoted as telling a parliamentary committee Thursday, the day of the invasion. But Rothschild and other intelligence officials reportedly said that the timing and scale of the invasion were unexpected. Experts said Thursday that the crisis could bring Israel together with moderate Arab countries and the United States in a tacit alliance to limit Iraq's future reach. Iraq, one of the Jewish state's fiercest foes, had escalated its anti-Israeli rhetoric before taking on neighboring Kuwait in a dispute over oil, borders and money. Israel is concerned that Jordan, which shares a 225-mile border with Israel, may be the next target for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in his quest for expanded influence in the region. ``Jordan has taken on tremendous importance as a buffer state now for Israel,'' said Joseph Alpher of Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies. Dore Gold, also of the Jaffee Center, said Iraq ``has demonstrated what happens to countries that try to oppose it.'' ``If Jordan sees the other Arab states and the United States are not supporting it against Iraq, it will not stand up to Iraq,'' he said. ``Jordan will then do anything Saddam Hussein requests.'' An Iraqi force backed by 350 tanks and warplanes invaded its oil-rich neighbor early Thursday morning. The invading army quickly assumed control of the small emirate and set up a provisional government. Politicians seemed to have hope Thursday that the United States and other Western leaders would take Israeli fears of Iraq more seriously than in the past. ``The character of Saddam Hussein has been revealed to the West and the democratic countries that had illusions about the man,'' said Arens, speaking on Israel radio. Iraq has threatened it would attack Israel with chemical weapons if Israel attacked any Arab nation. The invasion may also lead to greater ``strategic cooperation'' between Israel and the United States, said Eliyahu Ben-Elissar, chairman of the Parliament's Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee and a prominent member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc. Other analysts said the conflict would reduce U.S. pressure on Israel to make painful concessions in order to move the stalled peace process with the Palestinians forward. ``This is the biggest present Iraq could give Israel,'' said reserve Brig. Gen. Aharon Levran, a strategic analyst. ``Saddam has created a new focus of conflict and worry in the region.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Civic Leader Sentenced for Role in Drug Smuggling Ring
DOC.TEXT: A former Indianapolis civic leader received a nine-year prison sentence after a federal judge told her he couldn't understand how she could participate in sending marijuana to the same kinds of poor neighborhoods she helped. ``It's hard for me to look at this record and make some conclusion as to what in the world is going on in your mind,'' U.S. District Judge Larry J. McKinney told Linda Leary on Thursday. Leary, 59, pleaded guilty in February to being involved in a $50 million marijuana smuggling ring in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Her sons, Paul B. Heilbrunn, 35, and Richard S. Heilbrunn, 38, are accused of running the operation and are scheduled for a Feb. 13 trial. McKinney said he had received several letters from people who depicted Leary as a caring woman involved in child-care centers, inner-city school immunization programs and similar projects in poverty-stricken areas. He said it is ``incredibly ironic'' that at the same time she also was part of a conspiracy that brought marijuana into poor neighborhoods. A tearful Leary asked the judge to give her a chance to ``try to build a life with value.'' She added that she has to live with the problems she's caused her family. ``They have been so hurt and so troubled by all of this, and I can't undo that,'' said Leary, former president of the Indianapolis League of Women Voters and of the Indianapolis chapter of the National Council of Jewish Women. Her lawyer, Bernard L. Pylitt, had argued for leniency, saying Leary was a devoted mother and grandmother ``who closed her eyes to right and wrong'' because she loved her sons. ``I'm here to consider more than just one mother,'' McKinney responded later. ``I'm here to represent a lot of mothers, and fathers, and kids.''
