McKinney sentenced Leary to nine years for conspiracy to possess with intent to distribute marijuana and to a concurrent five-year term on a racketeering charge. The second charge stemmed from her control over a trust account in the Cayman Islands that was used to launder marijuana profits. McKinney also gave Leary credit for more than one year of prison time she already has served and ordered her to forfeit about $200,000 in assets obtained through drug money. The judge said he would recommend to the Bureau of Prisons that Leary serve the rest of her sentence at the Federal Correctional Institute in Lexington, Ky., where she has been held since February. Under the plea agreement, Leary could be required to testify against her sons. Thursday's sentencing modified a temporary 20-year sentence McKinney ordered for Leary in February so that she could go to the Kentucky prison for medical evaluation. Leary and her sons fled to Austria in 1985 after learning that a federal grand jury was probing allegations the Heilbrunns were directing a multistate smuggling operation. Leary, her sons and more than 30 other people were indicted Nov. 20, 1987. She and the Heilbrunns were arrested in May 1989 in Austria. They were extradited to the United States last December.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS first item to CORRECT that Ford got Oscar nomination, sted Oscar for ``Witness.''
DOC.TEXT: Harrison Ford worked as a carpenter before he struck gold as an actor, and finding a month to do nothing but make furniture is now one of his unfulfilled fantasies. Ford took up carpentry to pay the bills before landing a role in ``Star Wars'' in 1977, he tells US magazine in its Aug. 20 issue. His most recent foray into carpentry was about a year ago when he built a bed for his 3-year-old son, Malcolm. ``He watched me make it. But I'm sure he thinks that everybody's dad makes their bed,'' Ford said. Today, after an Oscar nomination for ``Witness'' and with the ``Indiana Jones'' series on his resume, he earns about $10 million per film. His latest is ``Presumed Innocent,'' in which he plays a big-city prosecutor accused of murdering a colleague-lover. Ford, 48, says carpentry is something he'd like more time for. ``I'd like to actually have a month and actually not do anything else but work on some furniture, work on honing those skills which I haven't practiced for so long,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Alleged Colombian Traffickers Extradited
DOC.TEXT: Two accused cocaine traffickers were extradited from Colombia today to be prosecuted by the Justice Department, the U.S. Marshals Service announced. K. Michael Moore, director of the service, said Colombian authorities turned over David Posada and Martin Alonso Gil in Bogota. The two arrived in Miami about 5 a.m., the announcement said. Posada, a 44-year-old Colombian also known as Humberto Vega, was arrested by Colombian police in February. An indictment returned in September charged that he and two other men knowingly possessed cocaine with intent to distribute it in Miami in 1985 and 1986. A separate indictment charged the 24-year-old Gil, a native of Colombia, and his brother, Jose Fernando Gil, with conspiracy to possess cocaine and possession of cocaine with intent to distribute it in the Miami area in 1989. At the time of the indictment, the brothers were living in Hialeah, Fla. They were arrested by Colombian authorities in Medellin in January. Jose Fernando Gil was extradited last month. Marshal Daniel J. Horgan of the Southern District of Florida said the defendants were being held pending arraignment. Twenty-two people have been extradited since Colombia began an anti-drug drive last August.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Says Archbishop May Have Been Victimized By Relationship With Woman
LaserPhoto AX2
DOC.TEXT: An ``intimate relationship'' with a woman lay minister who claims another priest fathered her child led to the resignation of Atlanta Archbishop Eugene A. Marino, the nation's highest-ranking black Roman Catholic. Marino resigned June 1 after the church began investigating his relationship with Vicki R. Long, said Bishop James P. Lyke, appointed acting administrator of the Atlanta Archdiocese. Lyke declined to say Thursday whether Marino would have been asked to quit, or whether the relationship was a sexual one. ``I assume that as the result of a two-year relationship, X-Y-Z would have happened,'' he said at a news conference. The relationship, first reported Wednesday, came to the attention of church officials in the spring with an anonymous tip, Lyke said. An investigation began May 3, and Marino agreed to relinquish administration of the archdiocese until the investigation was complete, he said. At the time, it was announced that Marino had relinquished his duties because of stress and a near heart attack. Church officials later said Marino resigned on July 10, but Lyke said Thursday he actually submitted his resignation to Vatican officials June 1. Lyke said church officials were not lying when they announced that Marino had resigned for ``personal reasons'' and to seek ``appropriate spiritual, medical and psychological therapy.'' ``That was true,'' Lyke said. ``What was not announced was that the personal reasons involved an intimate relationship with a woman, entered into shortly after his arrival in Atlanta in May 1988 and sustained during the next two years.'' Lyke would not reveal details, but said Ms. Long, a Catholic from suburban Riverdale, has made a monetary claim against the archdiocese. He would not disclose the amount she has sought. The archdiocese granted Ms. Long ``charity payments'' earlier this year for medical bills, but Lyke would not say how much, when or why. Ms. Long had been receiving $1,500 monthly payments apparently from Marino, and Lyke emphasized that those payments were not church money. He refused to speculate on how the archbishop could have afforded such an amount. Church officials have declined to say where Marino is; he was last said to be recuperating in New York. Ms. Long refused to comment Wednesday when asked about the allegations. She could not be reached Thursday because her telephone number is unlisted. Members of St. John the Evangelist Church, where she is a member, declined to reveal her whereabouts. In 1987, Ms. Long filed a $2.3 million lawsuit charging that a Catholic priest from Columbus fathered her child. Blood tests concluded that the priest, the Rev. Donal Keohane, with whom she had a four-year relationship, did not father the child born in May 1986, but the church is paying child support. ``Certainly priests are tremendously vulnerable from the inside because of their own sexual drives and from the outside because they become very attractive sexual targets,'' said A.W. Richard Sipe, a former Benedictine monk now practicing psychotherapy in Baltimore. Sipe conducted a 25-year study of priests, to be published next month, that concluded that half of all priests break celibacy vows. ``The unusual thing with this is it's being discussed,'' he said, noting that church officials usually don't comment on church scandals. The revelations have triggered anew the continuing debate over whether celibacy, a discipline required of Roman Catholic priests since the Middle Ages, is appropriate in the 20th century. Celibacy has not always been enforced _ three times in the 10th century popes were elected who were the sons of priests or former popes. The Rev. Thomas Reese at Georgetown University said the most recent bishop to leave the church and marry was James Shannon, an auxiliary bishop of St. Paul, Minn., in the late 1960s. In 1971, the National Federation of Priests Councils voted in favor of making celibacy optional. And support groups for women and priests who have had sexual relationships are starting _ one in Pennsylvania has about 1,200 members, three-fourths of whom are priests.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Trial Jury Begins Deliberations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with jury deliberations resuming. Picks up 6th graf pvs `The mayor ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: The jury in Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial began its first full day of deliberations today after a six-week trial at which the mayor's defense team admitted that he occasionally used cocaine. ``No one can suffer any more pain or shame or hurt than me,'' Barry said outside the U.S. District Court building Thursday. In closing arguments, the government accused him of having ``lived above the law.'' Barry engaged in ``occasional'' cocaine use, but the government failed to prove the drug possession, conspiracy and perjury charges against him, defense lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy told the jury in closing arguments. The jury of two whites and 10 blacks spent about an hour deliberating Thursday after being instructed not to consider ``politics or race'' when deciding the 14 criminal charges. The nine-woman, three-man jury's first decision Thursday was selecting a foreman, Edward Eagles, one of the two whites. The mayor said he is ``rather anxious, obviously, with the fate of Marion Barry in the hands of 12 people.'' Barry's public anti-drug stance ``was someone trying, in his own frailty, to say, `This is wrong,''' said Mundy, adding that the mayor's accusers are ``facile liars'' and ``little Lucifers.'' Charles Lewis, a convicted cocaine dealer, is ``the eternal salesperson selling himself to the jury,'' the defense attorney said. Restaurateur Hassan Mohammadi _ who testified he and Barry used cocaine together _ is a frequent government witness who played the ``notes to the tune that the government wrote for him,'' Mundy said. Mundy asserted the mayor was a victim of entrapment by the FBI, which had an undercover agent supply the crack cocaine that Barry smoked in a videotaped sting operation that culminated in his arrest Jan. 18. The exhaustive federal investigation of Barry's drug use amounted to ``using a sledgehammer to kill a fly,'' the defense lawyer said. ``If Mr. Barry's drug use were so rampant, he could have been discovered in a more traditional way,'' Mundy said. ``The cure is many-fold worse than the ailment.'' Assistant U.S. attorney Richard Roberts responded by saying that ``Marion Barry lived above the law. ``He lived one step ahead of anyone who was looking at him,'' Roberts added. The mayor ``lied to the public. ... The sad fact is, Marion Barry was out to get himself,'' said the prosecutor, who urged the jury to return a guilty verdict on all counts. Roberts, who is black, scoffed at suggestions that the mayor was the victim of a political or racial vendetta. Roberts urged the jurors to remember the 10 government witnesses who testified about Barry's alleged cocaine use and not join his ``conspiracy of silence and deceit.'' ``Mr. Barry is asking you to shut your eyes, cover your ears, to close your mind,'' Roberts said. ``Really, he's asking you to insult your intelligence by forgetting the facts.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Considers Alternative Redistricting Plans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearing begins at 11 a.m. EDT. Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has started to examine redistricting plans that could radically shift the power balance in the nation's most populous county. U.S. District Judge David Kenyon began reviewing alternative district maps Thursday after he tossed out a county plan as illogical and insensitive to minorities. The judge examined plans submitted by the American Civil Liberties Union, the Justice Department and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund _ all plaintiffs in the federal lawsuit against Los Angeles County. Those plans seek to create a Hispanic majority district but without an incumbent. They could overturn the conservative majority and possibly lead to profound changes in financing in such areas as health and social services programs. Civil rights lawyers today planned to discuss how the plans would be implemented. The county Board of Supervisors was ordered to redraw the districts after Kenyon found supervisors violated the federal Voting Rights Act by conspiring in 1981 to draw district lines that diluted Hispanic voting strength. But the remapping effort approved by the five-member board's conservative majority was not in good faith, Kenyon ruled Wednesday. Though Hispanics make up about 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million residents, the five-member board has not had an elected Hispanic member in 115 years.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Invasion Awakens US to Resurgent Role of Oil Exporters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `I don't...,' with Bentsen speech. Picks up 6th graf pvs `Iraqi President ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's capture of Kuwaiti oil fields is awakening the United States to a shift in the balance of global oil power and the prospect of higher prices, analysts say. U.S. dependence on oil from the volatile Persian Gulf has grown rapidly in recent years as American production has fallen. That leaves the United States increasingly vulnerable to supply disruptions and gives the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries more influence over prices. In 1985 the United States relied on the gulf countries for about 10 percent of imports; this year the gulf share of the American market is about 25 percent. One-half of all U.S. oil supplies are imported. While Britain and other non-OPEC oil exporters had snatched part of the American market from the Middle East producers in the early 1980s, some of that non-OPEC supply is drying up. ``I don't think the average American has understood how rapidly our dependence has increased,'' Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said Thursday. ``We've really been asleep at the switch in terms of the national security implications'' of relying heavily on Middle East oil exporters. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, called today for new incentives for domestic oil production, including tax breaks for those who squeeze oil from formations now considered unrecoverable. ``This week's news makes our vulnerability more evident and our response more urgent,'' said Bentsen, chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee. ``By failing to learn from this history, we are condemning ourselves to repeat it.'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's quick strike into Kuwait highlighted U.S. vulnerability to oil market pressures and to the possibility that OPEC _ with Iraq in a leading role _ may regain its price-fixing clout, analysts said. ``In a night's work, Hussein has irrevocably altered not only the balance of power in the Middle East, but the supply and demand balance in the world oil market,'' said Christopher Flavin, vice president for research at the Worldwatch Institute in Washington. Iraq immediately doubled its share of world oil reserves by taking control of Kuwait, which estimates its reserves at 94 billion barrels. Iraq now ranks second in the world to Saudi Arabia, which has estimated reserves of 255 billion barrels. The United States holds 26 billion barrels. Flavin said the Bush administration has little prospect for stopping Iraq from further military conquests in the gulf, despite the importance of oil to the U.S. economy. ``Ironically, any effort by the United States to directly prevent Iraqi military action would itself provoke the kind of conflict almost certain to disrupt oil supplies, and quite possibly throw the world into a severe recession,'' Flavin said. With Iraq now playing the role of enforcer, OPEC may be in a position to tighten world oil supplies over the coming decade, possibly enabling the cartel to raise its prices and make them stick, analysts said. Perhaps most troubling for the United States and other large oil-consuming nations: oil market clout is becoming increasingly concentrated in the gulf, where no nation has enough military might or political leverage to challenge Iraqi ambitions. ``All of the OPEC countries, at least all of those in the Middle East, will be intimidated by Iraq,'' said Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee. ``Iraq will be able to set such prices it wants.'' Throughout the eight years of the Iran-Iraq war, which ended in 1988, both countries were neutralized on the oil scene, leaving Saudi Arabia and Kuwait to dominate in OPEC and ensuring that the West would again become hooked on the cartel's oil. After emerging victorious over Iran, Iraq began seeking to convert its regional military predominance into added oil clout. The invasion of Kuwait was the first dramatic proof to analysts that Baghdad is intent on supplanting Saudi Arabia as the main power in OPEC and leading a drive toward higher oil prices.

DOC.HEAD: Biplane Crashes During Air Show
DOC.TEXT: A biplane went into a 400-foot nose dive during an air show and crashed, killing the pilot, on the final day of the Experimental Aircraft Association's annual convention. Witnesses said the Stearman biplane was making barrel rolls Thursday afternoon when it crashed near a runway at Wittman Regional Airport. The show was interrupted, then resumed about a half-hour later, using other runways. ``It got quiet _ everyone stood up and it got very, very quiet,'' said Marge Kaepplinger of Chicago. Witnesses said the pilot was about halfway through his 15-minute show when the plane crashed. No other planes were involved. Winnebago County Coroner Michael Stelter identified the victim today as John Lewkowitz of Walled Lake, Mich. He was pronounced dead at Mercy Medical Center. Five people died in two crashes July 25 while en route to the convention, which opened July 27. Three died when a plane from the state of Washington crashed in Wyoming and two were killed when a plane from Alabama crashed into Lake Winnebago less than 1{ miles from the convention site.

DOC.HEAD: More Countries Condemn Invasion; Japan Considers Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with Jordan's King Hussein flying to Baghdad, Italy suspending arms shipments, EC foreign ministry officials to meet in Rome, Japan to await U.N. moves. Pickup 14th graf pvs, `Japan, which...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More nations today joined the chorus of condemnations of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and Japan considered joining the United States and other countries in imposing sanctions on the Baghdad government. The invasion Thursday brought rival nations together in calls for Iraq to immediately withdraw its forces from the oil-rich Persian Gulf sheikdom. Japan, West Germany, Italy, Belgium and Luxembourg announced they would move to freeze Kuwaiti assets to protect them from Iraq. Officials in the Netherlands said they were likely to impose an asset freeze as well. On Thursday, France froze Kuwaiti and Iraqi assets, while Britain put a hold on Kuwaiti assets. The Soviet Union, Iraq's largest arms supplier, suspended shipments, called for Iraq to withdraw its troops, and said it would issue a joint statement with the United States on the invasion. Italy also suspended arms shipments, and called a meeting of European Community foreign ministry officials in Rome on Saturday to discuss the invasion. Italy holds the 12-nation community's rotating presidency. ``We will let Europe's weight be felt,'' said Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis. The insurance company Lloyd's of London introduced war risk premiums for shipping in the gulf for the first time since the Iran-Iraq war ended in 1988. President Bush, who froze Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets, denounced the invasion and said he had not ruled out any responses, including military. A U.S. aircraft carrier was on its way to the Persian Gulf to join other American warships, and France said it planned to send another warship to the waterway. At least two Arab nations cautioned against outside intervention in response to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's takeover. Most Arab states appeared reluctant to speak against Iraq. Iran, a Persian state, condemned the invasion and said it threatened regional security. Jordan's King Hussein flew to Baghdad today to meet with Saddam, a longtime friend. State newspapers in Jordan supported Iraq's invasion. Today South Korea, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and China urged a peaceful solution to the conflict. Singapore, an island nation, issued an especially strongly worded condemnation of the invasion, saying it was ``a threat to the security of small states everywhere.'' South Korea _ which imports all its oil, nearly 12 percent of it from Kuwait and Iraq _ was setting up an emergency task force to deal with possible disruptions in the oil supply. President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines said her government, too, would ``pursue all possible ways'' to deal with any supply disruption. But the Philippine government's immediate concern was the safety of the 40,000 to 50,000 Filipinos working in Kuwait. New Zealand Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer today called the invasion ``an outrage.'' He said his country would ``join in fully'' if the U.N. Security Council calls for economic sanctions. Taizo Watanabe, a spokesman for Japan's Foreign Ministry, said the government had asked banks and other financial institutions to freeze Kuwaiti assets. Although the government does not have the legal authority to order the freeze, the institutions were likely to follow the instructions. Watanabe said Japan would consider taking further measures after deliberations by the Security Council later today. Japan, which was taking 260,000 barrels a day from Iraq during the first quarter of the year, or 6.2 percent of its oil needs, may boycott Iraqi crude, Kyodo News Service reported. Japan also may block loans to Baghdad, it said. Bush said Thursday Washington would freeze all Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets and impose a trade embargo including a halt to imports of Iraqi oil. The United States was importing an average of 600,000 barrels of Iraqi oil a day in the first five months of this year. But the United States, which relies on Iraq and Kuwait for about 5 percent of its total oil needs, holds about 26 billion barrels of oil reserves. Switzerland ordered its banks to increase vigilance over Kuwaiti assets to prevent their seizure. France, Iraq's second-largest supplier, had already suspended arms deliveries because Baghdad failed to pay about $4.5 billion in debts, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said. On Thursday, the United Nations demanded Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal. China, Iran, Australia and Algeria were among nations echoing the call. Israel said it was ready to meet any military threat posed by Iraq but would not act unless attacked. Other statements of condemnation were issued Thursday by the 12-nation European Community, by Austria, Singapore, Romania, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Algeria, Venezuela, Mexico, Turkey, Norway, Morocco and Niger. The Arab League Council met in emergency session in Cairo on Thursday to consider a Kuwaiti demand to send a joint Arab force ``to defend Kuwait against the Iraqi invasion,'' Egypt's state-run Middle East News Agency reported. But the council adjourned without condemning the overthrow, the first by one Arab nation against another in modern history. Another council meeting was scheduled today. Hamed el-Ghabid, secretary-general of the 45-national Organization of Islamic Conference, issued a statement in Cairo asking Iraq to withdraw. Libya said any foreign intervention would be considered ``an aggressive act.'' Jordan's official news agency said King Hussein was also concerned about avoiding foreign intervention.

DOC.HEAD: Friend of Souter's May Be Nominated to Legal Services
DOC.TEXT: Tom Rath, a lawyer in Concord, N.H., and close friend of Supreme Court nominee David Souter, is likely to be named to the board of directors of the Legal Services Corp., a Legal Services source said today. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Rath would succeed John Erlenborn on the 11-member board if nominated by President Bush and confirmed by the Senate. The source said Legal Services had been told the nomination would probably be announced next week. In Concord, Rath said he had applied for the job but had not been told whether he would be nominated. ``I haven't caused anyone to gag yet, and from what I've heard, they are favorably inclined,'' he said. Congressional Quarterly reported this week that Rath has already been selected. Erlenborn resigned in June after the American Farm Bureau Federation said he was working against the interests of his law firm's agricultural clients. The board oversees funding of local legal aid programs that handle civil lawsuits for the poor. Souter, whose Senate confirmation hearings begin in September, was Rath's predecessor as state attorney general in New Hampshire.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Declares Infestation Over
DOC.TEXT: Florida agricultural officials today declared an end to a 3{-month Medfly infestation with a slap at California for taking so long to get rid of its pests. Helicopters sprayed up to 20 square miles of suburban Miami with malathion in eight aerial treatments to kill Mediterranean fruit flies, considered the most destructive farm pest because it can attack 250 fruits and vegetables. California's year-old infestation has spread to more than 900 square miles with limited aerial pesticide spraying at a cost of more than $38 million, said Florida Agriculture Commissioner Doyle Conner. ``It is absolutely vital to move quickly and aggressively, which is exactly what we did,'' he said. Florida's $1.6 million eradication effort began after a fly was trapped near Miami International Airport on April 16. By May 21, 23 Medflies were found at 21 locations. ``The bottom line is that we've turned back a serious threat to our food supply in an environmentally sound program involving a limited geographic area,'' Conner said. Unlike California, where malathion spraying produced a public outcry, the spraying in Virginia Gardens, Miami Springs and parts of Hialeah went on with little fuss.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Skirmish Over Abortion Amendment to Defense Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with debate over abortion at military hospitals. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `In the...'
DOC.TEXT: Senators clashed today over a contentious amendment to allow abortions in military hospitals, as one Republican lawmaker charged the measure would facilitate ``a procedure many Americans find repugnant.'' Two members of the Senate Armed Services Committee, Sens. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., and John Glenn, D-Ohio, tried to add the provision to the $289 billion defense bill for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. The Senate is rushing to finish the legislation before it breaks for its August recess. On Thursday, lawmakers left intact President Bush's budget request for the B-2 bomber but imposed restrictions on the $4.6 billion. During debate on the Senate floor today, Wirth told of a Navy petty officer and his wife, who while pregnant with her first child learned that the fetus was severely deformed. Despite recommendations from U.S. and Japanese physicians that they have an abortion, the woman was unable to obtain one at U.S. facilities in Japan, where the Midway was stationed. Instead, they used all their savings, $2,400, to have an abortion performed by a Japanese doctor. ``This is not a complex issue. It does not get into public funding for abortion,'' Wirth said. The amendment would reverse a 2-year-old regulation that bans abortions in military hospitals, except when the life of the mother is endangered. Under the provision, abortions for military personnel and their dependents would have to be paid for by the individual. ``This unsettles a long-settled policy with regard to government involvement in abortions,'' said Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., who complained that the provision would make it easier for an individual to have a ``procedure that many Americans find repugnant.'' On Thursday, the Senate met the challenge from Bush to save the B-2 bomber as Republicans argued that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is a sobering reminder against wholesale cuts in military spending. In the House, meantime, Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., was trying to force a pre-recess vote today on campaign spending limits, but was meeting stiff opposition from colleagues who object to having only 90 minutes of debate. The House also faced votes on final passage of a bill to strengthen oil spill liability laws and on a major civil rights bill. The Senate on Thursday endorsed Bush's B-2 budget request for fiscal 1991, beginning Oct. 1, by a 53-45 margin. But it also voted, 97-2, to restrict use of the $4.6 billion earmarked for the radar-evading plane until critical tests have been met. Earlier this week, the House Armed Services Committee dealt a serious blow to the embattled plane, as it approved a $283 billion defense bill that would halt production of the bat-winged planes at the 15 in development. The president wants a 75-plane fleet. Opponents of the aircraft argued that with the demise of the Warsaw Pact as a military alliance and the budget deficit increasing, spending billions on the strategic bomber was questionable. Republican Sen. William Cohen of Maine proposed stalling the B-2 program at the 15 planes until the Air Force could certify that the aircraft had met certain tests. ``Let's fund what we have on line right now but no more B-2s until you prove them,'' Cohen argued. The senator cited the increasing cost of the plane, which could skyrocket to more than $1 billion apiece, and the Justice Department's recommendation that the government prohibit the plane's manufacturer, Northrop Corp., from future defense contracts amid charges of fraud and mismanagement. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, conceded that the aircraft could cause sticker shock but argued that the changes in the Soviet threat is no reason to abandon the B-2. ``These changes do not mean the millennium has arrived,'' he Republicans used Iraq's invasion and control of Kuwait to drive home their point that the end of the Cold War in Eastern Europe did not justify deep cuts in the nation's defenses. ``We need a wake-up call. We need to be alerted that we're not going to be able to control the events in the world,'' said Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas. Across the Capitol, House Speaker Foley said he wanted to bring a pair of competing Democratic campaign finance proposals along with a Republican substitute to the floor for quick votes today. But Rep. Anthony Beilenson, D-Calif., and others called the plan for only 90 minutes of debate ``ridiculous'' and unfair. The Senate, by a largely party-line 59-40 vote Wednesday night, approved a Democratic bill that would cap Senate candidates' campaign spending at $2 million to $10 million, based on their states' population. The House also moved toward a vote today on a major cvil rights bill that Bush has threatened to veto because the administration believes it could lead to hiring quotas. The bill advanced Thursday night with approval of a cap on damages courts can award female victims of job discrimination. The oil spill legislation before the House increases federal liability limits but still allows states to enact tougher laws. The bill had languished for years but was given new life after the March 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska, considered the worst in U.S. history.

DOC.HEAD: Former Political Prisoner Elected as Hungary's New President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 2 grafs to ADD with more Goencz comments. Arpad Goencz is pronounced AHR-pahd GERNTS
DOC.TEXT: Parliament today elected Arpad Goencz, a prominant writer and former political prisoner, as president in a move that completed the country's break with its Communist past. Goencz had been sentenced to life in prison for his role in the 1956 anti-Communist uprising that was crushed by Soviet troops. ``All my life ... I have served and will serve the nation's independence, free thought, free speech, free ideas and social justice,'' Goencz told lawmakers after his election. ``I serve Hungarian democracy.'' Goencz, 68, had been appointed interim president May 2 by the newly elected, democratic Parliament. Today's parliamentary vote came less than a week after the failure of a referendum that would have mandated a popular vote for the post of president. Goencz is the first president of the Republic of Hungary, which was declared last year after the Communists agreed to relinquish power and compete in multiparty elections. Of 310 deputies present and voting, 295 voted for Goencz, the only candidate for the post, in a secret ballot. There are 386 deputies in the unicameral legislature. His election was expected after the failure of the referendum on holding a popular vote. Participation by more than 50 percent of the electorate was required for approval, but fewer than 14 percent went to the polls. Goencz referred indirectly to the failed referendum, saying the parties who supported him in Parliament represented the majority of the Hungarian people. ``Thus I can consider myself someone chosen not only by Parliament, but the whole of the people,'' he said in his acceptance speech. The referendum was sponsored by the Socialist Party, heir to the now disbanded Communist Party, which has only a small minority in Parliament. A referendum victory would have meant a chance for the party to regain some of its lost political prestige. Former Premier Miklos Nemeth, who ran as an independent in the March parliamentary elections, still enjoys considerable popularity, and observers said he would have had a good chance of becoming president in a direct election. In a similar referendum in November, Hungarians voted overwhelmingly in favor of postponing the election of the president until after the parliamentary elections. That meant the president would be elected by Parliament. The parliamentary elections were held March 25, and a runoff on April 8. Goencz, who headed the Hungarian Writers' Union before his election as interim president in May, spent six years in jail after Soviet troops crushed the 1956 revolt against Stalinism and rule from Moscow. He won a reprieve on his life sentence under a 1963 amnesty. He worked translating Britsh and American novels into Hungarian, and eventually published several novels and short stories. Goencz is the third intellectual and former dissident to assume an Eastern European presidency. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, a prominent playwright, was jailed and harassed for years before his election. In Bulgaria on Wednesday, Zhelyu Zhelev, a respected leader of the opposition and a man of letters, was elected the country's first non-Communist president. Goencz was one of the founding members of the reformist League of Free Democrats. With 94 seats in Parliament, the Free Democrats are the second largest party in Parliament after the Hungarian Democratic Forum, the senior party in the coalition government. In a brief acceptance speech after his election, Goencz suggested his varied past would enable him as president to understand a broad strata of Hungarian society. ``I have been lucky to live as a worker, as a peasant and as a free intellectual. Thus I am not suitable to serve class interests,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Decry Foley Plan for Quick Vote on Spending Limits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs `One Democratic ...' to CORRECT figures to $275,000 and $220,000, sted $275 million and $220 million respectively
DOC.TEXT: Speaker Thomas S. Foley wants to force a pre-vacation vote on limiting House members' campaign spending but is meeting stiff opposition from his fellow Democrats as well as Republicans. Rep. Anthony Beilenson, D-Calif., called ``ridiculous'' and unfair his party leader's plan to allow only 90 minutes of debate and then a vote today before the House begins a month-long recess. Foley, D-Wash., said Thursday he wanted to bring a pair of competing Democratic campaign finance proposals along with a Republican substitute to the floor for quick votes today. The Senate, by a largely party-line, 59-40 vote Wednesday night, approved a Democratic bill that would cap Senate candidates' campaign spending at $2 million to $10 million, based on their states' population. The Senate bill also would end the practice by which senators can annually pocket $27,000 in speaking fees from special interest groups, prohibit incumbents from mailing newsletters to voters at government expense in election years and ban corporate, labor and trade association political action committees. House Democratic leaders want to cap spending on House races at $550,000 but have been reluctant to curb PACs, which provided 52 percent of the money raised by Democratic incumbents in their last campaigns in 1988. One Democratic proposal would limit PAC donations to $275,000 or 50 percent of the spending ceiling. The other would cut them to 40 percent, or $220,000. Although any changes in the law would not take effect until after this year's election, several Democrats don't like what they portend. At a party caucus earlier this week, some cited how they had already spent $300,000 in fending off opponents in primaries and, under the proposed ceilings, would have only $250,000 left to run their general election campaigns in the fall. ``I don't know of a single person in the House who is not for campaign finance reform,'' said Rep. Al Swift, D-Wash., author of one of his party's two proposals. ``And I also know there are 435 plans to achieve that end.'' Citizen action groups such as Common Cause and Public Citizen, while generally praising the Senate's bill, have vehemently criticized House Democrats' reluctance to give up PACs. Because of that opposition, Democratic leaders just want to get the vote over with, said House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia. ``They know all the reform groups are going to be enraged at them,'' he said. ``So they want to take their beating and go home.''

DOC.HEAD: Student Leader of 53-Day Protest Freed From Detention
DOC.TEXT: A student who led a 53-day anti-government rally has been freed after six weeks' detention and today denied charges that he incited protesters to violence. Marian Munteanu, whose beating and detention drew domestic and international protest, was released Thursday night. In an interview in his apartment today, he called his time in jail ``a nightmare'' and pledged to continue working with the student movement. ``These six weeks of detention have aged me many years. I am physically weak. I feel 80 years old,'' he said. Munteanu, 28, the president of the Bucharest student union, was a leader of an anti-government rally that police violently dispersed June 13 after 53 days. The authorities' decision to use force against the peaceful protesters led to angry riots. More violence broke out when miners loyal to President Ion Iliescu came to the capital to help restore order. Six people were killed and scores injured in three days of unrest in the capital. Munteanu was hospitalized after being badly beaten by miners and then arrested days later. His release came shortly after the prosecutor-general issued a statement saying the circumstances that led to Munteanu's ``preventive detention'' had changed and his release would no longer represent a threat to public order. Demonstrations demanding Munteanu's release were held in Bucharest and in the central town of Sibiu earlier this week. Last month, prosecutors said Munteanu and some 80 others would be tried for ``inciting violence.'' But Munteanu said he had not been informed that the decision to try him was final. He maintained that on June 13, the day demonstrators attacked police headquarters with firebombs, he ``asked the people not to go (to police headquarters), but unfortunately they allowed themselves to be maneuvered... I don't know by whom.'' He said he hoped the parliamentary commission appointed to investigate the events would ``uncover the truth.'' Munteanu said he did not contest the right of Iliescu _ who won a massive victory in the May 20 elections _ to rule Romania. One of the demands of the protesters was the exclusion of all former Communists from power. Iliescu was a Communist functionary for a time under Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. He eventually fell into disfavor with Ceausescu, who was driven from power and executed in the December revolution. Iliescu has repeatedly stated his rejection of Communist ideals and his commitment to democracy. ``But the government's not doing enough to remove the residue of Communism in Romania or to reveal the truth about what has been happening since the revolution,'' Munteanu said. He said he would continue to be associated with the student movement ``to ensure they (students and intellectuals) are understood and tolerated.'' Munteanu said he still suffers headaches from his clubbing that doctors said could last two to three years.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Request To Stop Shark Hunt
DOC.TEXT: Just when surfers and swimmers thought it may have been as safe as usual to go in the water this weekend, a judge rejected an attempt to stop a shark-fishing tournament. A group known as Safe Harbors and Recreational Choices filed a lawsuit Wednesday to stop the Columbia River-Pacific Ocean Shark Tournament, scheduled for today and Saturday off the northern Oregon coast. Clatsop County Circuit Judge Pat Dooley refused to issue a temporary restraining order Thursday because the suit was filed so close to the start of the tournament. ``It would be a complete misuse of my discretion to issue an order on this short notice,'' Dooley said. Competitors plan to chum, or toss ground fish and blood into the water, to attract sharks. Tournament opponents said the event could draw sharks close to shore, increasing the danger that swimmers or surfers might be attacked. ``It would increase the risk potential, however small it may be,'' said California biologist Mark Marks, a graduate student at Humboldt State University who specializes in shark studies. ``Undoubtedly, this kind of behavior is not conducive to safe swimming.'' Ron Miller, a charter boat owner and vice president of the tournament, said in a telephone interview after the hearing that the entire episode had been blown out of proportion. ``The whole thing has gotten the media into a feeding frenzy,'' he said. ``It's just a handful of guys going out fishing.'' Organizers said when they announced the tournament that they hoped for 200 boats. They said prizes would run to $80,000 with a $35,000 top prize. But Miller said Thursday that only about a dozen boats were expected. Prizes will be much lower, based on a percentage of the $600 per boat entry fee. He said individuals were being allowed to enter for $10 each and could make their own arrangements to go out on a boat. Most of the boats planned to go 60 to 100 miles offshore and some will combine an albacore tuna fishing trip with the shark hunt, Miller said.

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Agree to Talks on Supreme National Council
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's Khmer Rouge guerrillas agreed today to discuss speedy formation of a council that would help govern Cambodia until elections could be held in the Vietnam-controlled country. The Cambodian factions agreed to form the council during talks two months ago in Tokyo, but the Khmer Rouge complained it was not being treated as an equal and boycotted the agreement. Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan agreed to new discussions in a broadcast over his group's radio, monitored in Bangkok. However, Premier Hun Sen of the Vietnamese-installed government has said the formation of the council already has been decided and has refused resistance calls for new talks on it. Khieu Samphan said the group will follow the urging of Southeast Asian foreign ministers and participate ``in the meeting of all Cambodian parties ... to discuss the composition of the Supreme National Council in a reconciliation spirit to most speedily set up this council.'' In a July 23 joint statement, the ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or ASEAN, called for the urgent formation of the council. They noted that some proposals have called for the council to work with the United Nations in governing Cambodia in the period before elections. The council would comprise representatives of the three-party guerrilla coalition and the government Vietnam installed in Cambodia after a late 1978 invasion. After the Tokyo talks, representatives were named by the Vietnamese-installed government and the Khmer Rouge's two guerrilla allies _ the forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and of Son Sann's Khmer People's National Liberation Front. But the Khmer Rouge refused to name any representatives. In today's broadcast, Khieu Samphan called the council ``the only legitimate organ of Cambodia and the sole authority in the transition period.'' He said it would cooperate with the United Nations in the interim administration. However, the government wants interim authority and a largely symbolic council. Khieu Samphan said his group agreed that ``no one Cambodian party would be allowed to seize or maintain power through the force of arms, no one Cambodian party could dominate other Cambodian parties, and that no party is to be discarded.'' He apparently was reacting to the international isolation of the Khmer Rouge, and to fears by various Western countries that it would try to retake power militarily. The Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of people in fanatical communist policies in Cambodia before Vietnam's invasion ended its nearly four-year reign. The group's isolation grew after the United States announced last month it was withdrawing recognition of the guerrilla coalition's U.N. seat.

DOC.HEAD: Escaped Wallaby is Found
DOC.TEXT: Nearly two weeks after his great escape, Aardu the wallaby was back home at the Stone Zoo today. Zoo keepers found Aardu Thursday night, according to Kim O'Keefe, a secretary at the zoo. ``He's fine,'' said O'Keefe. ``He should be back in his cage today.'' It was not immediately clear where or how Aardu had been found. Aardu, a male Australian wallaby, leaped to freedom from the Stone Zoo in suburban Boston on July 23. A wallaby is a cousin of the kangaroo. Within hours of his escape, Aardu escaped to the nearby Middlesex Fells Reservation, 3,000 wooded acres. Zoo officials said Aardu, a hardy vegetarian, could have survived for months. There had been a number of sightings of the 35-pound marsupial by zoo personnel, police and citizens looking to help. But Aardu, reaching speeds up to 30 mph, had been able to elude his would-be captors. Aardu shared his home at the zoo with three female wallabies, and zoo officials hope he will eventually father wallaby offspring.

DOC.HEAD: Fishing, Shipping Idled By Spill; Governor Downplays Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with barge moved, ship channel reopening, hearing resuming. Picks up 7th graf pvs: ``We're still ...
DOC.TEXT: Fish might be contaminated, shipping has been halted and a 12-mile slick remains on Galveston Bay from a 500,000-gallon oil spill, but Gov. Bill Clements says things aren't so bad. ``We're fortunate,'' Clements, a former oil man, said after viewing the spill Thursday. ``It's not near as serious a problem as was first anticipated.'' Clements declaration that spill's effects were ``greatly exaggerated'' angered fishermen and local officials less willing to downplay potential economic and environmental damage. The spill occurred Saturday when the Greek tanker Shinoussa collided with two barges in the Houston Shipping Channel. One of the barges nearly sank. Last night, salvage crews moved the barge a short distance to put it out of the channel and onto a ledge in shallower waters in the bay, Coast Guard Chief Warrant Officer Rick Meidt said today. ``It was not very far. They just had to get it to a slightly more stable location,'' he said. The ship channel was reopened this morning to allow one deep-draft ship out of the area to determine if its wake would cause further damage to the barge, he said. But the ship passed without incident and the Coast Guard planned to allow another vessel to pass later. ``We're taking it slow and easy,'' Meidt said. The spill occurred in one of the barge's three cargo tanks. Since then, salvage crews have pumped out a tank that had 20,000 gallons of oil. About 200,000 gallons is believed to still be in another tank. A third tank is believed to be empty. Workers planned to inspect both tanks today. Meidt also reported that additional oil has washed ashore at Houston Point, a marshland north of the slick. A hearing into the cause of the crash resumed today in Houston. The bay pilot assigned to the Greek freighter was scheduled to testify. Coast Guard officials were worried about a crack in the barge that occurred during the accident. ``We're still concerned about the structural integrity of the barge,'' Coast Guard Petty Officer Mark Sedwick said. ``It could break apart.'' Ship owners were losing at least $1.5 million per day while the channel was closed, officials said earlier in the week. The Coast Guard took over cleanup efforts Thursday because Apex Towing Co., owner of the two barges damaged in the collision, was nearing its insurance liability limit. Cleanup crews used skimmers and vacuum trucks to suck up oil off the water's surface and workers also dumped oil-eating microbes on an oil-soiled marsh. The state Health Department imposed a fishing ban Thursday because of fears that fish, shrimp and other marine life could be contaminated by the spill. It idled multimillion-dollar commercial and sport industries as worried shrimpers await the Aug. 15 opening of the fall season. Clements said the ban could be lifted soon. Critics were skeptical. ``I hope he's right, but realistically, I think he's full of baloney,'' said C.L. Standley, past president of Professional Involvement of Seafood Concerned Enterprises. ``I think it could possibly be weeks, and if it is, that's going to be devastating,'' he said. The spill, once 17 miles long, thinned to about 12 miles by afternoon. Clements said he had trouble finding any oil during a flyover by helicopter, saying that much of the oil evaporated before reaching sensitive marshlands. At least one official disputed Clements' contention. ``Obviously, much of the oil has sunk to the bottom of the bay, endangering all the marine and bird life and devastating a productive commercial and recreational fishery,'' said Texas General Land Commissioner Garry Mauro. Coast Guard officials, however, said samples taken from the bay bottom by the Army Corps of Engineers had not yet revealed signs of oil, except in one small sample. Wayne Johnson, a Galveston County commissioner, also criticized Clements. ``I'm outraged. He came out here and declared victory and went back to Austin,'' Johnson said. ``I don't like this idea of declaring victory and calling off the troops, said state Sen. Chet Brooks. ``This war is far from over.'' In 1947, Clements founded SEDCO Inc., an oil supply firm that specialized in offshore drilling. It made the Gulf of Mexico oil rig that exploded in 1979 and spilled about 100 million gallons of oil. The company settled lawsuits by fishermen and businesses seeking $350 million for $2.1 million.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Cancels Viewer Choice Segment Due to Breaking Kuwait Story
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network, which began experimenting with a viewer choice segment on its ``Newsnight'' program just last week, said today it will cancel the segment when necessary because of breaking news. The interactive news format, which allows viewers to choose two secondary or feature stories using a special 900 telephone line, was suspended for the first time Thursday night because of the breaking story on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``The interactive segment is still very much alive. However, we will cancel it on nights where there is a big breaking story,'' said CNN spokesman Steve Haworth. CNN said it received some calls from viewers Wednesday night complaining that the network didn't show enough on the Iraqi invasion while it did use the viewer choice segment on ``Newsnight,'' which airs for an hour beginning at midnight Eastern time. ``We had the Kuwait story at 10:18 p.m. when it broke, and on our midnight show had it at 12:25 p.m.,'' said Haworth. The interactive news experiment began July 23. Viewers see a summary of six feature stories at the beginning of the show and are invited to dial a 900 number to vote on which of the stories they would like to see. The two with the most votes are shown during the program. ``We were wall-to-wall with Iraqi stories Thursday night, which was the first time the viewers choice segment was not shown. No decision has been made yet on tonight's show. It will depend on the breaking news,'' Haworth said.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Council Votes Against Anti-Obscenity Pledge
DOC.TEXT: The advisory council to the National Endowment for the Arts broke with its chairman today, voting overwhelmingly to drop an anti-obscenity pledge for artists that it likened to McCarthy era loyalty oaths. The council vote is not binding on the endowment. NEA Chairman John E. Frohnmayer said, ``I'm going to consider it and take my action in due course.'' The 19 members of the National Council on the one member said that requiring artists who get grants to pledge that their works will not be obscene amounts to ``a loyalty oath reminiscentArts voted after of the McCarthy era.'' Only two dissenting votes were recorded. Frohnmayer, responding to a controversy over federal grants that go towards controversial art, had inserted congressional language barring obscenity into the conditions that grant recipients must promise to obey before they can receive federal funds. Congress imposed the obscenity ban on the endowment last October after conservative lawmakers led by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., complained that an exhibition of sexually explicit works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe contained obscenity and should not be financed by taxpayers' money. he ban prohibits use of NEA grant money for works that the endowment chairman deems obscene, including dease of 15 failed Texas thrifts.
