DOC.HEAD: The AP
Investigation of Ritter Found Sexual Misconduct
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Covenant House statement, picks up 13th graf, `In December, ...
DOC.TEXT: Investigators have concluded that the Rev. Bruce Ritter engaged in sexual misconduct with young men at the shelter for young runaways that he founded, Covenant House announced today. The four-month inquiry, ordered by the Covenant House board of directors, discovered ``cumulative evidence ... supporting the allegations of sexual misconduct on the part of Father Ritter,'' Covenant House said. If Ritter had not resigned as Covenant House president in February, the statement added, ``the termination of his relationship would have been required.'' The four-month investigation was conducted by Robert J. McGuire, a former city police commissioner. Covenant House officials said his full report would be issued later in the day. The findings first were reported by The New York Times today. Some Covenant House residents told investigators they spurned sexual overtures the priest made toward them, while others described sexual activities they engaged in with Ritter, the Times said, quoting people who had read the report. Ritter, 63, who founded the shelter that annually serves 28,000 youths, has vehemently denied the allegations of sexual impropriety. He is believed to be living in New Jersey and is considering leaving the Franciscan order. A statement today from Ritter's lawyer, Stanley Arkin, said the report ``gives emphasis to an alleged few sporadic incidents, washing away more than 20 years of uncompromising and unstinting accomplishment.'' Noting that Ritter has resigned from Covenant House, Arkin added: ``revisiting these allegations now is wholly unnecessary, either for Covenant House or for the public.'' The investigation found no evidence Ritter misappropriated funds at Covenant House, which runs shelters in 15 U.S. cities, Canada and Central America. The Manhattan district attorney found ``some questionable financial transactions,'' but no charges were brought against Ritter. The state attorney general's office is still investigating the organization's finances. But the Covenant House statement said the board should have been made aware of loans by Ritter to two senior staff members, of contracts between Covenant House and Ritter's niece and of a secret personal fund where Ritter deposited most of his $98,000 salary. The fund, called the Franciscan Charitable Trust, had accumulated nearly $1 million. Plans now call for it to be liquidated with the assets going to Covenant House, as Ritter says he intended all along. In December, a 26-year-old drifter from Texas, Kevin Lee Kite, accused Ritter of luring him into a sexual relationship. That public accusation was followed by similar allegations by two others, including Darryl Bassile, 31, who McGuire concluded was the most credible of Ritter's accusers. More than half of the organization's 17 board members have resigned since the allegations surfaced. Donations have fallen, the $86 million budget was cut back $14 million and a fourth of the 420-person staff was laid off. Sister Mary Rose McGeady, a social services worker and associate director of Catholic Charities in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, was named to replace Ritter on Sept. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Big Ben's Bearing Blamed for Clock's Third Stoppage
DOC.TEXT: It's not the heat but a faulty bearing that has stopped the clock of Big Ben three times this week, the government said Friday. The hands of the famous clock on the tower of the Houses of Parliament stopped at 5:11 a.m. Friday, which is about where they snagged on Wednesday and Thursday nights. ``We believe, as a result of investigations carried out this morning, that the problem is to do with a bearing in the eastern face of the clock, and that once that bearing has been replaced or lubricated, that the problem will go away,'' said Toby Sargent, spokesman for the Department of Environment. Big Ben is the name of the bell that tolls the hours, but the name is informally applied to the clock as well. Sargent said it apparently was just a coincidence that the clock broke down during the hottest days of the London summer. On Thursday, the temperature reached 97 degrees.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Jolts Eastern Part of West Java
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake jolted parts of the main Indonesian island of Java but no damage or casualties were reported, the Meteorology and Geophysics Agency said Friday. The quake, measuring 6 on the Richter scale, struck Thursday night in West Java, the agency said. The epicenter was placed at about 120 miles west of Jakarta, the capital, and was 19 miles below the surface in the Malacca Straits. Tremors were felt in Jakarta. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake measuring 6 on the Richter scale can cause severe damage in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Military Options in Mideast Conflict Difficult Ones
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs `He declined ...' to UPDATE with source in Brussels saying U.S. has contingency plan if Iraq goes beyond Kuwaiti borders. Picks up 7th graf pvs `President Bush ...' ^With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A third U.S. aircraft carrier was being readied today to head toward the troubled Mideast to bolster U.S. forces already scattered outside the Persian Gulf region, the Pentagon said. The move comes a day after Iraq invaded Kuwait. However, Pentagon officials said the USS Saratoga had been scheduled to relieve the USS Eisenhower, which was deployed in the Mideast in March. The aircraft carrier Independence already is headed from the Indian Ocean toward the Persian Gulf to strengthen the eight-ship U.S. Navy presence already there. The Saratoga, based in Mayport, Fla., earlier had been scheduled to relieve the USS Eisenhower and will leave Tuesday. In addition, a Marine amphibious readiness group aboard the assault ship USS Inchon was scheduled to sail to the region Monday, for a total deployment of 15,000 sailors and Marines. ``This has been planned for months,'' said Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams. He declined to tie Saratoga's movement to the Mideast crisis, but said it was possible that the Saratoga and Eisenhower might overlap for a time and remain in the Mediterranean. In Brussels today, a source said the United States told its NATO allies that it has prepared contingency plans in case Iraqi troops push beyond Kuwait. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said American officials did not explain what actions were under consideration. President Bush has said no options _ military or otherwise _ have been ruled in or out. But if the 3,000 Americans in Kuwait came into harm's way, the president said it would affect the United States ``in a very dramatic way.'' ``If they are threatened or harmed ... I have certain responsibilities,'' Bush said after conferring Thursday with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Aspen, Colo. The State Department said today that invading Iraqi troops rounded up at least eight American oil field workers near the border of Kuwait. Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told NBC today that the United States could ``dominate the gulf from a naval standpoint.'' ``We can keep the Iraqis off the water, we can dominate them in the air,'' he said, but added that putting U.S. troops on the ground ``would be a major problem.'' Top Pentagon military officers and intelligence analysts insisted they were not caught off guard by Iraq's sudden sweep into its southern Arab neighbor, but the Independence was thousands of miles away from the tense region. Military sources said the Independence was ``several days'' from reaching a staging area outside gulf waters. But it will serve as a potent symbol of U.S. military strength with its squadrons of FA-18 jet fighters, F-4 attack aircraft and A-6E bombers. Meanwhile, members of Congress and others worried that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein could aim next at an invasion of Saudi Arabia. The 120,000 Iraqi troops massed along Iraq's southern border for the invasion of Kuwait could easily be sent there next, said lawmakers who attended classified briefings late Thursday. U.S. forces in the gulf had come to Kuwait's aid during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war when it reflagged the oil-rich nation's tankers in 1988 and protected them from attack from Iran. But it would be difficult for the United States to parry Iraq's drive with a major assault of troops, Pentagon military sources say. Even though Marine and Army forces stand ready for use in Western Europe and at bases in the Indian Ocean and the Pacific, it would take massive numbers of flights, access to air bases and numerous ships to supply such an endeavor. ``Our forces are very far away. It would take weeks for them to get there,'' one high-ranking military officer said. A massive landing force would be needed to counter Iraq's war-tested soldiers and their thousands of tanks and sophisticated weaponry. ``Iraq is a Third World nation with First World weapons,'' one senior intelligence analyst said. ``They are the Prussians of the Middle East. They have mechanized armament you wouldn't believe _ they kicked the stuffing out of the Iranians with it.'' Flying U.S. ground combat forces into the Persian Gulf from European bases would be extremely difficult in view of Libyan air defenses and problems posed by getting permission to fly over Egypt and other nations in the region, another source said. Inside the gulf, the U.S. military presence is represented by eight warships of the Joint Task Force Middle East, led by the command ship USS LaSalle. Those vessels include a cruiser, destroyer and frigates that lack the punch of the carrier group's attack and bomber aircraft. U.S. carriers stay out of the Persian Gulf, not only because of their size but to increase their security against attack.

DOC.HEAD: Man Receives $475,000 for Racial Attack
DOC.TEXT: A black man attacked by a white man yelling racial slurs has been awarded $475,000 in damages under a rarely used state law that forbids racial intimidation. A Cook County Circuit Court jury on Thursday made the award to Mack Green, 55, one of the first beneficiaries of the Illinois Ethnic Intimidation Act, according to his lawyers. The law, adopted in 1982 but rarely used, allows victims of racial, religious or ethnic hostility to file civil lawsuits against their assailants, independent of criminal prosecution. During a one-day trial, Green testified that he was attacked by Stephen Windy, 30, on Jan. 22, 1988, after his tow truck broke down in a predominantly white neighborhood on Chicago's South Side. According to the lawsuit, Windy tried to set the truck on fire, grabbed a piece of lumber from the back of the truck, shattered windows and tossed a gas can at Green. Windy pleaded guilty to criminal charges of attempted arson, damage to property and ethnic intimidation in 1988. He was given a year's probation, ordered to pay for truck repairs, and required to perform 60 hours of community service. Windy, representing himself in the civil trial, argued he had been punished already by the criminal case and that Green was not physically injured during the attack. He could not immediately be reached for comment after the verdict. Green's attorney, Frederick Sperling, said the civil suit ``sends a clear message that anyone engaging in racial or religious violence will have a steep price to pay.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Sidesteps Abortion Issue in Rush to Finish Defense Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 6 grafs to include passage of aviation bills.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate, rushing to adjourn for the summer, today sidestepped a potentially volatile fight over abortion as it laid aside a measure that would have allowed abortions in military hospitals. Sen. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., chief sponsor of the provision, withdrew his amendment after the Senate fell two votes short of curtailing debate, clearing the way for the Senate to move ahead on a $289 billion defense bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. ``This is not a complex issue. It does not get into public funding for abortion,'' Wirth said. The amendment would have reversed a 2-year-old regulation that bans abortions in military hospitals, except when the life of the mother is endangered. Under the provision, abortions for military personnel and their dependents would have to be paid by the individual. ``This unsettles a long-settled policy with regard to government involvement in abortions,'' said Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., who complained that the provision would make it easier for an individual to have a ``procedure that many Americans find repugnant.'' Senate GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas said that if the measure was included in the defense bill, President Bush would veto the legislation. On Thursday, the Senate met the challenge from Bush to save the B-2 bomber as Republicans argued that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is a sobering reminder against wholesale cuts in military spending. In the House, meantime, Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., was trying to force a pre-recess vote today on campaign spending limits, but was meeting stiff opposition from colleagues who object to having only 90 minutes of debate. The House also faced votes on final passage of a bill to strengthen oil spill liability laws and on a major civil rights bill. The Senate on Thursday endorsed Bush's B-2 budget request for fiscal 1991 Oct. 1, by a 53-45 margin. But it also voted, 97-2, to restrict use of the $4.6 billion earmarked for the radar-evading plane until critical tests have been met. Earlier this week, the House Armed Services Committee dealt a serious blow o the embattled plane, as it approved a $283 billion defense bill that would halt production of the bat-winged planes at the 15 in development. The president wants a 75-plane fleet. Opponents of the aircraft argued that with the demise of the Warsaw Pact as a military alliance and the budget deficit increasing, spending billions on the strategic bomber was questionable. Republican Sen. William Cohen of Maine proposed stalling the B-2 program at the 15 planes until the Air Force could certify that the aircraft had met certain tests. ``Let's fund what we have on line right now but no more B-2s until you prove them,'' Cohen argued. The senator cited the increasing cost of the plane, which could skyrocket to more than $1 billion apiece, and the Justice Department's recommendation that the government prohibit the plane's manufacturer, Northrop Corp., from future defense contracts amid charges of fraud and mismanagement. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, conceded that the aircraft could cause sticker shock but argued that the changes in the Soviet threat is no reason to abandon the B-2. ``These changes do not mean the millennium has arrived,'' he Republicans used Iraq's invasion and control of Kuwait to drive home their point that the end of the Cold War in Eastern Europe did not justify deep cuts in the nation's defenses. ``We need a wake-up call. We need to be alerted that we're not going to be able to control the events in the world,'' said Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas. Across the Capitol, House Speaker Foley said he wanted to bring a pair of competing Democratic campaign finance proposals along with a Republican substitute to the floor for quick votes today. But Rep. Anthony Beilenson, D-Calif., and others called the plan for only 90 minutes of debate ``ridiculous'' and unfair. The Senate, by a largely party-line 59-40 vote Wednesday night, approved a Democratic bill that would cap Senate candidates' campaign spending at $2 million to $10 million, based on their states' population. The House also moved toward a vote today on a major civil rights bill that Bush has threatened to veto because the administration believes it could lead to hiring quotas. The bill advanced Thursday night with approval of a cap on damages courts can award female victims of job discrimination. The oil spill legislation before the House increases federal liability limits but still allows states to enact tougher laws. The bill had languished for years but was given new life after the March 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska, considered the worst in U.S. history. Legislation to require infants and toddlers to use child safety seats on airline flights cleared the Senate on a voice vote late Thursday. The bill goes to the House. The measure, sponsored by Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., would direct the Federal Aviation Administration to require the seats on domestic airline flights. It would be left to the FAA to determine a height and weight limit for children needing the seats. Currently, infants under 2 can fly free by traveling on the laps of a parent or guardian. The airline industry and consumer safety groups support mandatory child restraints. On another aviation issue, the House approved a bill that would tax airline travelers with a passenger facilities charge at each airport where they embark. The fees would raise $1 billion a year for airport improvement. The measure, which now goes to the Senate, was part of a $18.5 billion bill, two-year funding of FAA operations and airport development.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Condemns Iraqi Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with more on Egyptian statement; DELETES reference to King Hussein saying Saddam will attend meeting, UPDATES with report he probably won't attend. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `Libya warned...' ^With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Egypt and a council representing Saudi Arabia and five other smaller Arab nations today condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and called on Baghdad to immediately withdraw its troops. In its denunciation, Egypt warned that the invasion could have dangerous consequences throughout the Middle East. The statement by the Gulf Cooperation Council _ which includes Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Oman and Kuwait _ contained the first condemnation by Saudi Arabia, which borders Kuwait. Egypt, in a statement issued by its Foreign Ministry, spoke of its surprise at Iraq's lightning invasion of its small Persian Gulf neighbor. Thursday's invasion came only days after Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak stepped in to try to mediate the Iraq-Kuwait dispute. Iraq allowed him to believe his efforts were succeeding. The Egyptian condemnation came as an emergency Arab League Council was preparing to reconvene in Cairo to discuss the crisis. The council, at Kuwait's request, met Thursday for six hours but issued no statement and adjourned its meeting for 24 hours. On the day of the invasion, the Arab world was conspicuously silent except to warn against foreign intervention in Kuwait. Egyptian government sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, have said Mubarak and other Arab leaders were initially reluctant to condemn Iraq because they hoped the situation could be resolved without the use of more force. But their silence made it appear to the rest of the world that they feared the wrath of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein if they speak against him. Meanwhile, King Hussein of Jordan held talks today in Baghdad with Saddam and said upon his return that an Arab summit would be held in Saudi Arabia on Sunday to discuss the invasion. Speaking on state-run radio and television, he did not say which leaders would attend. Later, Egypt's Middle East News Agency quoted the Kuwaiti minister for cabinet affairs, Abdel-Rahman el-Awadi, as releasing a list of leaders who would attend. Saddam's name was not among them. Jordan has not taken a stand on the invasion, but state newspapers supported Iraq and said the United States should not intervene militarily ``in our Arab region.'' The Egyptian sources said neither Mubarak nor King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, who are leading a diplomatic campaign to try to end the crisis, believed Iraq's claim that it invaded at the request of Kuwaiti revolutionaries who had already overthrown the government. Other nations strongly condemned the invasion. The United States and the Soviet Union imposed sanctions on Iraq, and the United Nations demanded Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait, a call heard from many nations including China, Iran, Australia and Algeria. Some Palestinian leaders in the Israeli-occupied lands expressed support today for the invasion, but others expressed fears it would divert attention from the Palestinian struggle against Israel. Libya warned that any foreign intervention would be considered ``an aggressive act.'' King Hussein on Thursday met Mubarak for five hours in the Mediterranean port of Alexandria in Egypt. The two conferred by phone with King Fahd, Saddam and other Arab leaders, and with President Bush. No details of the discussion were divulged and no statement was issued afterward. In Saudi Arabia, a statement by the official Saudi Press Agency said Fahd was following the situation with extreme concern and that he was in intensive contacts ``seeking to calm the situation and restore matters to normalcy.'' Only Salim Hoss, prime minister of war-torn and ineffectual Lebanon, has condemned the invasion. The Iraqi-Kuwaiti conflict erupted July 17 when Saddam accused his small gulf neighbor of pumping $14 billion worth of oil from Iraqi territories. He also accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of overproduction, which had created a glut in the world oil market, and threatened to take military action. Mubarak, who has just recently cemented Egypt's return to the Arab fold, immediately flew to Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. On July 25, he proudly announced that his mediation efforts had succeeded and that the two parties would meet in Saudi Arabia to discuss their conflict. A meeting did take place on Tuesday, but the talks collapsed. Less than 48 hours later, thousands of Iraqi troops crossed the border and overran Kuwait. Egypt's role as political leader in the Arab world was frozen following the late President Anwar Sadat's 1977 trip to Jerusalem, which led to the U.S.-brokered Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty in 1979. Since becoming president in 1981, Mubarak has worked hard to restore his country's status in the Arab world. Jordan was the first of the Arab nations to resume diplomatic ties with Cairo in 1984, and today Egypt boasts close relations with all countries, including hard-liners Syria and Libya.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
U.S. Tells NATO Allies It Has A Plan if Iraqi Invasion Spreads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs background at end. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The United States today alerted its NATO allies that it has prepared contingency plans in case Iraqi troops push beyond Kuwaiti territory, an alliance source said. ``The United States informed the allies that it was aware that Iraq may have designs beyond Kuwait and informed the allies that it has drawn up contingency plans of action to respond to that eventuality,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said American officials did not explain what actions were under consideration. They made their remarks during a special meeting of the political committee of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which is made up of top officials from each of the alliance's 16 member nations. During the meeting, he said the allies expressed ``very strongly broad support for moving toward some coordinated action'' through the United Nations. There was a sense, he said, that the allies were prepared to move quickly. NATO's political committee, which meets regularly, held a special meeting on Thursday to discuss the Iraqi invasion and was expected to do so again on Monday. At the Thursday meeting, the United States urged the allies to begin a commerical embargo, including arms shipments, and to freeze Iraqi assets and take measures to prevent Baghdad from taking Kuwaiti assets, sources said. On Friday, the allies reviewed what action their governments had taken to protest Iraq's aggression against its Persian Gulf neighbor, said the NATO source. Some had moved to freeze Kuwaiti assets but ``most were not yet prepared to join in a broader trade embargo,'' said the source. Those nations which are members of the European Community were waiting to see what joint action might be recommended by the trading bloc. Eleven of the community's 12 members belong to NATO. Only neutral Ireland remains outside.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Highly Vulnerable To Economic Sanctions
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Swift action to freeze Kuwaiti assets overseas after Iraq's invasion of its oil-rich neighbor will prevent strongman Saddam Hussein from reaping immediate economic benefits. If Western nations also take additional moves to cut Iraq's oil lifeline, Baghdad's already strapped economy will be dealt a harsh blow. The United States took the lead by freezing billions of dollars of Kuwaiti and Iraqi assets, banning imports of Iraqi oil and imposing other trade sanctions. Oil accounts for 97 percent of Iraq's exports to the United States. Kuwait had about $4.2 billion invested in the United States at the end of 1989 and Iraq had almost nothing invested, according to the U.S. Department of Commerce. Britain and France froze Kuwaiti assets to keep the country's new Iraqi-installed government from seizing them. Japan, West Germany, Italy, Belgium and Luxembourg have announced plans to do so. The Netherlands was considering an assets freeze, but there were no immediate indications whether the Dutch were prepared to bar Iraqi oil from the major European port of Rotterdam _ a potentially crippling blow. Senior officials from the 12 European Community nations were to meet in Rome on Saturday to discuss economic and other sanctions against Iraq, an EC source said Friday. But so far only the U.S. and French governments have blocked Iraq's assets in their countries, and the United States has been the only country to move firmly against Iraq's oil. Analysts stress that speed was essential in any successful move to prevent Kuwait's $100 billion of assets overseas from getting into the hands of the new Kuwaiti government. ``The priority today is to freeze Kuwaiti assets,'' said Andrew Cunningham, associate editor at the Nicosia-based Middle East Economic Survey. ``If you don't do it now, they'll get the assets,'' he said. In contrast, the United States and its allies have slightly more time at their disposal to shape a collective policy to isolate Iraq's own economy. ``Iraq is in an extremely vulnerable position,'' Cunningham said, adding that Baghdad relies significantly on Western credits but ``oil is the main thing.'' Iraq uses three export routes for its oil: pipelines across Saudi Arabia and Turkey, and the Persian Gulf sea outlet. The pipelines were built during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, when Baghdad's traditional oil route through the gulf was repeatedly attacked by Iran. After the war, Saddam hoped to found an ambitious reconstruction program on oil income, but sagging oil prices undermined recovery efforts. The uncertainties after Saddam's invasion of Kuwait are pushing up oil prices, but with a big question mark over his ability to sell it this may not be a benefit. It was unclear whether the invasion would slow or halt Kuwait's oil production. Iraqi control of Kuwait's 94 billion barrels of crude oil reserves, added to Baghdad's own 100 billion, will be of little use to the Iraqis if they cannot market their oil. The war with Iran left Saddam a foreign debt from $60 billion to $70 billion, including about $30 billion to Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and other oil-rich Arab countries that helped finance his war. A desire to erase part of the debt burden was one reason behind Saddam's sudden invasion. Iraq is saddled with overcentralized state industries and an annual inflation rate conservatively estimated at 15 percent. Despite Saddam's attempts to revitalize the economy by selling off $2.2 billion worth of public companies to private individuals and removing some price controls, the recovery has been anemic. Using fear as a weapon to push for efficiency, Saddam has fired state officials for inefficiency or corruption, but the hoped-for economic boom did not materialize. Iraq also announced plans to slash public expenditure, and it discharged more than 200,000 soldiers from the army, although with the remobilization in the wake of the invasion, this saving will be eliminated. Iraq relies significantly on financial credits from the West. Baghdad responded to the U.S. sanctions by freezing repayment of $2.4 billion in Iraqi debts to the United States, a move it is certain to duplicate against any other countries that block Iraqi credits. Suspending repayments helps Iraq in the short term, but in the long run Cunningham said ``they have been a net receiver of funds, not a net payer,'' so the cutoff is sure to hurt. In addition, key Western technicians and consultants are likely to be ordered out of Iraq, further crippling the economy.
EDITORS: Martin Marris has covered the Middle East from Nicosia for The Associated Press since 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Asset Freeze Has Negligible Impact on Iraq; Safeguards Kuwaiti Holdings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New graf 3 with seizure of Iraqi oil off Texas; pickup graf 3 pvs, bgng, ``The asset....
DOC.TEXT: Iraq will suffer little from President Bush's order freezing its U.S. assets, but the freeze on Kuwait's U.S. investments should prevent Iraq from looting them, government officials and private analysts say. Bush's response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait also included a trade embargo against Iraq. That shuts off the source of more than 7 percent of U.S. oil imports while blocking exports _ primarily food _ to a $1 billion-a-year trading partner. The embargo prompted the Customs Service to seize more than 13 million gallons of Iraqi crude oil after it was unloaded from a tanker in international waters off Texas, Customs spokeswoman Sharon Goodson. The asset freeze announced Thursday will be implemented by the Treasury Department, which spent much of the day trying to identify Kuwaiti and Iraqi assets in the United States or under U.S. control abroad. Department officials said they received hundreds of calls from financial and business concerns likely to be affected by the asset freeze and trade embargo. The latest government figures supported speculation by private analysts that Kuwait's U.S. holdings are extensive, Iraq's slim. Commerce Department figures show $4.2 billion in Kuwaiti direct investment in the United States at the end of last year. The comparable figure for Iraq was essentially nothing. Direct investment includes real property and stock holdings of more than 10 percent of a corporation's shares, but excludes smaller stock holdings, bank deposits and holdings of government bonds. In March, U.S. banks reported $12.5 billion in holdings, including U.S. government bonds, of eight oil-producing Middle Eastern countries lumped together in government statistics. ``This is not going to be anything more than a minor financial burden on the Iraqis,'' said Stephen D. Cohen, an international economist who lectures at the American University School of International Service. Once Kuwait's U.S. assets are frozen, Iraq will be unable to draw cash from or sell them even if it gains control of Kuwait's central bank and other financial institutions, administration officials said. A handful of analysts contacted Thursday said it was unlikely Iraq would attempt to dip into Kuwaiti assets. ``I don't think the Iraqis are trying to kidnap the Kuwaiti treasury,'' said Cohen. While it appears to have few holdings in the United States, Iraq owes the U.S. government $2.24 billion, according to Treasury Department figures. Iraq responded to the U.S. announcement by freezing repayment of that debt to the United States, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. Private analysts said any successful effort to pressure Iraq with economic sanctions would depend on cooperation from allies in Europe, where the oil-producing nations of the Middle East make most of their foreign investments. Ralph C. Bryant, a former Federal Reserve official now with the Brookings Institution, said any extended attempt to impose an asset freeze might bring legal cases because of murky laws on whether the United States can prevent overseas branches of U.S. banks from releasing deposits to their owners. Bush's decision to impose a trade embargo put Iraq in the company of South Africa, Libya, Cuba, Vietnam, North Korea and Cambodia among nations under some form of U.S. trade sanctions. U.S. imports from Iraq totaled $2.4 billion in 1989, $2.3 billion of that in crude oil at 450,000 barrels a day. In the first five months of 1990, the total was more than 600,000 barrels a day. U.S. exports to Iraq totaled $1.1 billion in 1989, mostly wheat, rice and other agricultural products.

DOC.HEAD: Target of Berendzen Phone Calls Sues for $11 Million
DOC.TEXT: The Virginia woman who received obscene phone calls from former American University President Richard Berendzen said Friday she is seeking $11 million in damages for emotional stress on her and her family. Susan Allen of Fairfax, Va., demanded $4 million from Berendzen and $7 million from the university in a suit filed Thursday in District of Columbia Superior Court. Allen said Friday that the calls had inflicted ``a life-altering amount of stress and damage'' on her and her family, and had caused her to be hospitalized. ``Ever since the day after the first phone call, I've been on heart medication and other medication to sleep,'' Allen said. ``My life has definitely taken a very negative turn. My smallest child is terrified of any man she sees.'' Berendzen's calls to Allen began in March in response to an advertisement for home child care that she had placed in The Washington Post. Allen said he asked her if she would include her son in her sexual relations with her husband and said he had a female sex slave in his basement. Berendzen, who remains a tenured professor at American, resigned the presidency and entered the sexual disorders clinic at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore when an investigation revealed his office was the source of the calls. He later pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor counts and was placed on probation. Allen's lawsuit alleges American University did not act quickly enough once the calls were traced to Berendzen's office on the Washington campus. John Clifford, her attorney, said the school first confronted Berendzen with its findings, and he then called Allen and ``said she had destroyed his life.'' Clifford said university officials did not pass their information to investigators until two days after they had discussed the matter with Berendzen. Anita Gottlieb, American University's assistant vice president, said Friday that the school had not received a copy of the court papers and had no immediate comment on the matter. Gerard Trainor, Berendzen's attorney, also was not available for comment on the suit.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Oil-Rich Iran Province Jolted By Quakes
DOC.TEXT: A powerful earthquake jolted Iran's oil-rich province of Khuzestan today, a little more than a month after a devastating earthquake in the north killed 40,000 people. The Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the tremor struck in mid-afternoon and measured 5.5 on the open-ended Richter scale. The dispatch said reports of possible damage or loss of life were not immediately available. Khuzestan is located on the oil-producing belt in southern Iran. IRNA said a series of strong jolts had also shaken the town of Ardebil and surrounding areas in the northwestern province of East Azerbaijan over the past three days. It said the strongest jolt, measuring 4.5 on the Richter scale, occured Thursday night. The jolts caused considerable panic after the June 21 quake, which registered 7.3 on the Richter scale, killed 40,000 people, left 60,000 injured, and rendered half a million homeless in northern Gilan and Zanjan provinces.

DOC.HEAD: ABA Officials Urge Group To Adopt Neutral Abortion Stand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf to CORRECT vote total to 21-9, sted 21-0.
DOC.TEXT: The American Bar Association has nothing to gain by its abortion-rights position, the group's president-elect said today in supporting the governing board's push for a neutral stance. ``We have lost 1,500 members'' since the nation's largest group of lawyers adopted its position in February, president-elect John Curtin of Boston said today in a telephone interview. On Thursday, the group's board of governors voted 21-9 to recommend that the ABA House of Delegates, its policy-making group, reconsider the abortion issue and take a neutral stance at its meeting in Chicago next week. Officials said more than $300,000 in annual fees have been lost as a result of member resignations from the 365,000-member group since it adopted the position favoring abortion rights. Curtin said the stance would have negligible affect on the abortion issue as a whole. ``There couldn't be a more debated issue in the whole history of the country,'' Curtin said. ``The fact that the ABA has a position on it will have no effect.'' Curtin said he could not predict how the group's House of Delegates would respond to the push for neutrality, but said he believed there was a chance its stance would be overturned. Some groups said the neutrality stance would be a backwards step. ``Neutral is a cloak for retreating from pro-choice,'' said Patricia Dougherty, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League of Illinois.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Girl Revived After Rescue from River
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old girl who was pulled from the Ohio River after more than 30 minutes underwater was hospitalized in critical condition Friday. Rachel Nation of East Liverpool, Ohio, had no heartbeat when she was pulled from the river Thursday afternoon, but paramedics revived her, said chief sheriff's deputy Alex Stakias. The child fell into the river on the Ohio side, across from Newell, W.Va., authorities said. She was found by a Newell firefighter who plunged into the river to look for her, said sheriff's spokesman Joe Geisse. The child was treated at East Liverpool City Hospital before being transferred to the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. She was listed in critical condition in the intensive care unit Friday, said spokeswoman Toby Trosky.

DOC.HEAD: PGA To Prohibit Tournaments at Clubs Where Bias `Raises a Question'
DOC.TEXT: The Professional Golfers Association Tour, reacting to threats of protest and sponsor pullouts at the PGA Championship, said today it will prohibit tournaments at clubs where membership even ``raises a question'' of discrimination. The policy would affect tournaments on the PGA Tour, the Senior PGA Tour and Ben Hogan tour events. The statement comes after more than a week of controversy concerning the national championship, which starts Thursday, and its site, the previously all-white Shoal Creek country club in Birmingham, Ala. Bowing to pressure from civil rights groups and planned demonstrations, Shoal Creek awarded honorary membership to a black businessman this week and said it was considering another black for admission. ``In the event a golf club indicates its membership practices and policies are non-discriminatory, but there is information that raises a question as to such practices and policies ... the staff is authorized to require on a case by case basis that as a condition of hosting an event, the applicable golf club take appropriate action to encourage minority membership,'' the PGA statement said. The statement also said that no contracts for a tournament will be extended ``unless the PGA Tour is satisfied that its non-discriminatory policies are being enforced.'' Although the Shoal Creek racial controversy has centered on the PGA Championship, the Tour does not have jurisdiction over that tournament.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Hints at Boycott of Prime Ministers' Talks
DOC.TEXT: North Korea, upset by rival South Korea's moves to improve ties with the Soviet Union, indicated Friday it might boycott historic talks between the two Koreas' prime ministers. A South Korean government delegation is in Moscow discussing issues that Seoul officials say include economic cooperation and establishing diplomatic ties. North Korea's official Communist Party newspaper Rodong Sinmun hinted at the possibility of a boycott of the prime ministers' talks in a commentary carried by the Korean Central News Agency and monitored in Tokyo. The newspaper denounced the South Korean delegation's visit to Moscow as a divisive act ``going against the desire for reunification.'' It said if Seoul and Moscow open formal relations, it would perpetuate the division of the Korean peninsula, bitterly divided since 1945. The Soviet Union is a close ally and arms provider for North Korea. In an unprecedented move last month, the rival Korean states signed an accord setting up the first talks between their prime ministers. The first meeting is to be held in Seoul beginning Sept. 4 and the second is scheduled beginning Oct. 16 in North Korea's capital of Pyongyang. Before signing the agreement, North Korea's chief delegate, Paik Nam Jun, issued a veiled warning that any attempt by Seoul to improve ties with Moscow would hurt the prime ministers' talks. The Seoul government believes expanded ties with Communist nations will help open North Korea's closed society and thus ease tension on the peninsula. South Korea has made great strides in improving ties with socialist countries since the 1988 Olympics in Seoul. It has opened formal relations with all East European nations except Albania and East Germany. North Korea also charged that the Seoul government is trying to disrupt a unification rally to be held with South Korean dissidents at the border village of Panmunjom on Aug. 15. In Seoul, about 1,500 radical students and dissidents held a demonstration pledging support for the Aug. 15 rally. They called for an end to the U.S. military presence in South Korea and the signing of a peace treaty to replace an armistice agreement that ended the 1950-53 Korean War. The protesters said the stationing of 43,000 U.S. troops in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty hurts efforts to unify the peninsula. They also demanded efforts by the two Korean governments to open their border and allow free travel for the 62 million people on the two sides. South Korea has proposed a trial five-day border opening in mid-August for unrestricted free travel. North Korea has in effect rejected the suggestion.

DOC.HEAD: Two Little-Known Candidates Virtually Tied in Senate Primary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with county election registrar saying some votes won't be tabulated until Monday. Picks up 2nd graf pvs: `With 2,293 ...'
DOC.TEXT: Two candidates in a down-to-the wire GOP primary for the right to challenge incumbent Democrat Sen. Albert Gore Jr. must wait after this weekend to find out the outcome of the election. About 3,000 votes in Madison County will not be tabulated until Monday, said Madison County Registrar Spence Dupree. ``We're going to count it as soon as we can, but we've got every county position except for tax assessor to count first,'' Dupree said. He said the county races would be tabulated first. As late returns came in today, only 11 votes separated the two leading GOP contenders; so the Madison County votes could determine the winner. With 2,293 of 2,415 precincts counted, or 95 percent, bankrupt businessman Ralph Brown led conservative political economist William Hawkins. Brown had 50,189 votes, and Hawkins 50,178 votes, or 39 percent for both. In other races, the state's only black congressman crushed two Democratic challengers in his second re-election campaign conducted under the cloud of a federal bank-fraud indictment. Gore, 42, ran unopposed for the Democratic berth and was expected to handle easily whichever Republican he faces in the Nov. 6 general election. He garnered 424,747 votes with 100 percent of the precincts in. The 73-year-old Brown, who was forced to declare bankruptcy a year ago, didn't wait up for the results of his campaign, on which he spend less than $100. He turned in about midnight, said his wife of 50 years, Marie. ``He was very excited. But it got late. You don't know who won, do you?'' she asked a late-night caller. Gov. Ned McWherter received 376,123 Democratic votes and will face Dwight Henry, a Republican freshman state lawmaker who suspended his campaign in June and resumed it less than a week before the election at the request of legislative colleagues. Henry said: ``I don't think there's any question about who the David is in David vs. Goliath.'' U.S. Rep. Harold Ford defeated state Rep. Pam Gaia and Memphis businessman Mark Flanagan for the Democratic nomination. With 116 of 187 precincts counted, Ford had 28,380 votes, or 78 percent, to 6,946 votes, or 19 percent, for Gaia. Flanagan had 1,201 votes, or 3 percent. Ford, 45, will face Republican Aaron C. Davis, a 79-year-old political newcomer, in the general election. He was indicted by a federal grand jury in 1987 on bank and mail fraud charges. Jurors deadlocked in April after an 11-week trial. Prosecutors say a second trial will be held, but no date has been scheduled. The eight-term congressman's backers have remained loyal. He contends the U.S. Justice Department targeted him for prosecution because he is a prominent black leader. All nine of the state's congressional representatives are up for re-election, but only one beside Ford faced primary opponents. U.S. Rep. Marilyn Lloyd, the state's only female member of Congress, defeated David Ray Stacy, a pipe fitter. Like Ford, she has been in Congress since 1975. A three-way Republican primary in the Sixth Congressional District, which surrounds the Nashville area, included Jack Nugent, a white supremacist from Columbia who has gathered little support. The seat is held by U.S. Rep. Bart Gordon, a Murfreesboro Democrat.

DOC.HEAD: German Leaders Urge Earlier Unity Vote; Berlin To Be New Capital
LaserPhoto BER2
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of both Germanys on Friday urged joint elections two months earlier than planned, and the countries agreed to make Berlin their united capital. The early election plan ran into immediate objections from the leftist Social Democrats, who form part of the East German coalition government but are the opposition in West Germany. The Soviets said it could disrupt international talks on German unification. East Germany's prime minister, Lothar de Maiziere, made the proposal to advance all-German elections from Dec. 2 to Oct. 14. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl welcomed it, saying the earlier vote ``corresponds with the wishes of the people in East Germany and also in West Germany.'' Kohl's comments came in a statement released by his office in Bonn. He was on vacation in Austria. Under pressure for early unification, De Maiziere said he sought ``unity that was as quick as possible, but as good as needed'' and hoped early elections would improve the climate for investment. He said the all-German elections should create ``political clarity and with that also economic security.'' The Dec. 2 date was informally approved by political groups in both Germanys, and it may take complicated parliamentary maneuvering to move up the vote. Social Democrats in both Germanys immediately criticized the proposal. Oskar Lafontaine, the Social Democrats' challenger to Kohl in the upcoming election, called the latest proposal a ``transparent manipulation attempt'' for Kohl and de Maiziere to quickly capitalize on their popularity. He said the proposal for earlier elections breached an agreement that was reached with the Social Democrats on a Dec. 2 election date. The East German Social Democrats, de Maiziere's coalition partners, accused the prime minister of ``election fraud'' and trying to improve the chances of the Christian Democrats, both de Maiziere's and Kohl's party. In Moscow, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitsky said the call for early elections was an ``unexpected turn'' that could disrupt international talks on German unity. The Soviet Union has been East Germany's largest military and trading partner. The decision on making Berlin the new capital came as negotiators for the two Germanys ironed out remaining points of joining the two countries. The announcement in East Berlin left open the question of whether all government offices would move there. ``The capital of Germany is Berlin. The question of the seat of government will be settled after unification,'' the statement said. The terse declaration, which is expected to win easy approval in both countries' parliaments, is unlikely to calm the storm surrounding the capital. East Germans, joined by the West Berlin goverment, are demanding the entire government return to the historic capital of Germany and Prussia. Others object, with some saying that Berlin's shameful, 12-year tenure as the seat of Nazi tyranny tainted the city in the world's eyes. Currently, East Berlin is the capital of East Germany and Bonn is West Germany's capital. In another development, West Germany's defense minister said West German officers will run what is now the East German military after unification. Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg said West German officers would take charge of East German units in a unified army. He also said the future army will be made up of 320,000 of the current West German armed forces with 50,000 from the East German military. Kohl had said the combined German armed forces would be at 370,000. He made the comment during a meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in southern Russia last month. De Maiziere's appeal came just one day after the two Germanys signed a treaty for the first elections in a unified Germany in nearly 60 years. Pressure for quicker unification has been building as East Germany makes the difficult transition from communism to capitalism. The shift from a centrally planned economy to the free market has already put more than 250,000 East Germans out of work. Experts say 3 million could be left jobless as companies and factories are unable to compete in the new market now that they are losing state subsidies. De Maiziere said the all-German vote should coincide with East German elections that will create five state governments to mirror West Germany's federal system. According to law, those states can then immediately seek unity with West Germany. The all-German vote will be the first ballot in a united Germany since March 1933, when Adolf Hitler's National Socialists won a plurality of seats in the Reichstag.

DOC.HEAD: Jury: Film May Be Pornographic, But Not Obscene
DOC.TEXT: After watching a sexually explicit movie in court, a jury agreed that the X-rated ``Spermbusters'' may be pornographic, but it's not obscene. Walter M. Epler, a clerk at Pussy Cat Adult Bookstore in Largo, was acquitted Thursday on a misdemeanor charge of distributing obscene material. He was charged after renting a ``Spermbusters'' videotape to an undercover sheriff's detective. ``It's wasting tax dollars to be trying to persecute this type of movie,'' said Stephen Bennett, a computer consultant who served as foreman of the six-member Pinellas County Court jury. Epler was one of 15 people arrested last month in Pinellas County Sheriff Everett Rice's crackdown on X-rated videos, during which deputies also seized 39 videotapes from several adult bookstores. He was the first to be tried. Epler did not dispute renting the film to the detective, so the case centered on whether ``Spermbusters'' was obscene. Defense attorney Frank de la Grana called it an ``average, all-American, X-rated film.'' ``You are a barometer for this community,'' de la Grana told the jury of three men and three women. The panel included a banker, an electrician, an assembly worker, a factory foreman and an analyst. The jurors, who ranged in age from 29 to 50, all said they had seen X-rated films before. The movie was billed as a parody of the hit ``Ghostbusters,'' although the connection was obscure. Many scenes featured sexual intercourse and male and female genitalia. ``I realized why we had to view it, but it's not something that you expect when you come in to do jury duty,'' said Bennett. Prosecutors argued that ``Spermbusters'' fit the U.S. Supreme Court's three-part test for obscene material by appealing to prurient interests, depicting sex in a patently offensive way and lacking any serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. ``Art? Come on, ladies and gentlemen,'' said Assistant State Attorney Joe Mueller. ``Was there even a plot?'' But de la Grana said the availability and demand for such movies in the western Florida county was one way of measuring contemporary community standards. The Supreme Court has held that such standards should apply in judging offensiveness. Bennett said jurors did not consider the film art and were divided over whether it appealed to purient interests, defined as a ``shameful or morbid interest in sex.'' But they agreed the movie was not patently offensive. He said such a description fits depictions of child pornography, bestiality or sado-masochism. ``I do agree there is some limit,'' he said. ``But I don't think this film went beyond that limit.''

DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Tumbles More Than 100 Points At Mid-Afternoon
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices plummeted in afternoon trading today amid continued tension over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, with the Dow Jones industrial average skidding down more than 100 points. ``The Middle East remains a tinderbox,'' said Alan Ackerman, a market strategist with Gruntal & Co. ``It's unstable and unpredictable.'' The key Dow Jones average of 30 big industrial stocks was down about 118 points in sustained selling shortly before 2 p.m. on Wall Street. In the broader market, traders said over-the-counter stocks were swamped with sell orders. The stock market was battered by fears that higher energy prices worldwide resulting from the Iraqi invasion would trigger inflation and further destabilize the U.S. economy. Already in a downslide because of recent reports of underlying economic weakness, the market was hit with more bad economic news this morning as the government reported higher unemployment in July. The Labor Department said non-farm payroll employment fell by 219,000 in July, surprising analysts who had been looking for a modest increase. The civilian unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent. But market participants had their eye on Iraq, concerned that while Kuwait's oil reserves may not be critical to world supplies, further moves by Iraq could threaten oil from Saudi Arabia and other nations. ``The real concern is how far will Iraq go in the Middle East,'' Ackerman said. ``There's an absence of superpower intervention. Obviously there's a lot of nervousness worldwide.'' The Dow industrials fell 34.66 points Thursday on fears that a possible disruption of oil supplies could spark inflation and recession in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Korean Sweaters Sold Too Cheap
DOC.TEXT: Sweaters made of man-made fibers in South Korea are being sold in the United States at less than fair market value, the Commerce Department said Friday. The finding clears the way for the International Trade Commission to consider whether to impose import duties that would bring prices for the cut-rate sweaters into line with American-made garments. The National Knitwear & Sportswear Association in New York had filed complaints last September against sweater manufacturers in South Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan. The department ruled on July 21 that sweaters from Hong Kong were being dumped in the United States. It is scheduled to rule Aug. 17 on the imports from Taiwan. If the ITC finds the South Korean products are harming U.S. industry, the government can impose duties on the imports to make their prices comparable with those of U.S. companies. The department said imports represent 72 percent of the $1.3 billion U.S. sweater market and the three countries represent 55 percent of the imports. It said the value of the sweaters imported from South Korea in 1989 was $476.1 million; from Hong Kong, $208.8 million, and Taiwan, $485.5 million. The department said the imports are made predominantly of acrylic fiber. Sweaters containing at least 23 percent wool are excluded.

DOC.HEAD: Soyuz Capsule Docks With Orbiting Mir Space Station
DOC.TEXT: The manned spacecraft Soyuz TM-10 docked with the orbiting Mir space station on Friday, two days after it was launched, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. The docking was ``made neatly and precisely on time,'' Tass said. Flight commander Lt. Col. Gennady Manakov and engineer Gennady Strekalov will spend one week working with the old crew which has been on board since Feb. 11. They replace cosmonauts Anatoly Solovyev and Alexander Balandin, who are scheduled to return to Earth on Aug. 9, following a mission plagued by problems with the spacecraft's thermal insulation and a broken hatch. Watching from mission control center were two employees of the Tokyo Broadcasting system who are vying to fly into space in December: television camerawoman Ryoko Kikuchi and former Washington bureau chief Toyohiro Akiyama. Manakov and Strekalov will spend 132 days in the Mir and will conduct 250 experiments, including the growing of pure crystals to be used as semiconductors and computer chips. They will make at least two space walks, Tass said. Their craft was launched Wednesday from the Baikonur Space Center in Soviet Central Asia.

DOC.HEAD: House Rebuffs Bush and Approves Landmark Civil Rights Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES pvs
DOC.TEXT: The House approved a landmark civil rights bill today, brushing off a last-minute veto threat by President Bush, who contends the minority-hiring provisions in the legislation would lead to quotas. ``Stand up for what you know is right, stand up for America's values,'' Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., urged as the House approved the bill, 272-154. The measure goes to a House-Senate conference committee, where prospects for compromise appear good. The Senate two weeks ago approved a version similar in all but a few features. Approval came minutes after release of a letter from Bush, threatening a veto and offering to sign an alternative version that he called a ``sound, practical compromise.'' He said that without changes the bill ``will have the effect of forcing businesses to adopt quotas in hiring and promotion.'' ``It will also foster divisiveness and litigation rather than conciliation and do more to promote legal fees than civil rights,'' Bush said. The alternative was rejected, however, as the House pressed ahead with the measure that would effectively overturn five Supreme Court decisions last year and that tops the civil rights community's congressional list. Major provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to barriers to reopening court-approved fair-hiring agreements. The alternative version proposed by Rep. John LaFalce, D-N.Y., and praised by Bush would have tempered language designed to make it easier to win job bias suits against employers based on statistics. It also would have capped at $100,000 punitive damages for intentional discrimination that courts could award to women, religious minorities and the disabled. The bill places no limit on such damages. The LaFalce plan represented the major effort of critics to change the bill. It was rejected, 238-188. Lawmakers spoke of fierce last-minute lobbying on the plan. ``The pressures have been enormous, the intimidation has belied the vision and hope of civil rights, but in the end it is my face in that mirror,'' said Rep. Nancy Johnson, R-Conn., a supporter of LaFalce. Democrats were harshly critical of the amendment. ``It rips the heart out,'' said Judiciary Chairman Jack Brooks, D-Texas. ``We need some truth in labeling around here. You can't just slap on the label civil rights.'' The bill's chief House sponsor said Thursday night it was strengthened against the alternative version after supporters adopted their own version of cap on damages for women, religious minorities and the disabled. ``The southern Democrats voted with us on this cap and most of them will now be with us, so I think we'll have a whopping good vote,'' said Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., chairman of the Education and Labor Committee. The cap, approved 289-134, would limit punitive damages for women who are victims of intentional job discrimination to $150,000 or the amount of compensatory damages, whichever is larger. Women's rights groups say there should be no cap, because unlimited punitive damages are allowed in cases of racial discrimination. Sponsors supported a similar cap when the Senate passed the measure but were outmaneuvered. Doing the job in the House was regarded as crucial to the long-run efforts of sponsors to send the bill to Bush. In the short run, Hawkins said, the buttressing of southern Democratic support cleared the way for defeat of the LaFalce amendment. The LaFalce plan was similar to a proposal sponsored in the Senate by Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., but which never was brought to a vote.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soviets, US Condemn Iraq; Soviets Say Iraq Will Withdraw Soon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines 4th and 3rd ledes, ADDS comment on Soviet TV. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and the United States today demanded that all countries cut off arms supplies to Iraq because of its invasion of Kuwait, and the Soviet foreign minister predicted Iraq would soon withdraw from Kuwait. The minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, and Secretary of State James A. Baker III read a joint statement demanding the arms cutoff to reporters after a hastily scheduled, one-hour meeting at a Moscow airport. The U.S.-Soviet statement, a rare case of superpower cooperation in pursuit of peace, noted that the Soviet Union had cut off arms supplies to Iraq on Thursday and that United States had frozen Iraqi assets. The two superpowers also demanded in the statement that Iraq withdraw its troops from Kuwait. Shevardnadze also told reporters, ``We have been assured that very soon the Iraqis will pull out their troops.'' He said the Soviets, until this week Iraq's largest arms supplier, learned this through contacts in Baghdad. After Iraq overran Kuwait Thursday, ostensibly because a dispute over oil and a border region, it said its forces could withdraw within a week or two. But fighting continued today in Kuwait, especially in oil fields near the border with Saudi Arabia, prompting fears that Iraq would expand its invasion. Shevardnadze said the Soviet leadership had sent a message to Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein on Thursday, but he did not reveal the contents. The U.S.-Soviet statement demanded that other countries stop sending arms to Iraq, but it did not mention by name the Middle East nation's other major weapons suppliers. Shevardnadze opened the news conference by saying the Kremlin's decision to cut off its arms supplies to Iraq was difficult. ``It wasn't so easy for us to make the kind of statement we made yesterday,'' because Soviet relations with Iraq had been good for decades, he said. Shevardnadze said the invasion ``contradicts the principles of new political thinking and the principles of civilized relations between nations.'' A report on Soviet TV news said: ``The statement contains an appeal to the international public to come out together in condemnation of the act of aggression.'' Washington and Moscow have condemned the invasion on their own. Baker's plane arrived in Moscow from Mongolia today more than an hour late because a tire blew when it landed for refueling in the Siberian city of Irkutsk. Baker cut short his state visit to Mongolia for the Moscow talks. Before leaving the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator, Baker told reporters: ``I just hope that the United States and Soviet Union could join in a joint statement regarding this matter. The fact, I think, of our doing that would be quite unique and rather significant.'' In Mongolia, Baker said the United States is offering that Communist country $1.1 million and special trade status to help transform the economy into a democratic free-market system. Baker completed the official portion of his trip, a sign of the United States' interest in promoting ties with the longtime Soviet satellite, before leaving ahead of schedule to stop in Moscow. He had planned to spend the weekend hunting and fishing in Mongolia's Gobi Desert. Baker's visit to Mongolia was the first by a top U.S. official since Vice President Henry Wallace came in 1944.

DOC.HEAD: Block-by-Block Fighting Reported in Liberian Capital
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based partly on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith was among them.

Government troops and rebels loyal to Prince Johnson fired rockets and shells Friday in block-by-block fighting for the ravaged Liberian capital. The bodies of several pedestrians killed by the cross-fire were left lying on the sidewalk. Branches were blown off trees. Damaged downtown shop fronts were blasted anew by the indiscriminate firing. The clashes followed a one-day lull in the 7-month-old civil war, when Johnson's men had apparently pulled back to face a possible threat from forces loyal to rival rebel leader Charles Taylor. There was no sign that Taylor's men had progressed from the suburb of Paynesville, six miles east of the city, where they have been blocked by President Samuel Doe's troops for more than a month. Artillery shells started a fire several blocks away from a huge exibition building that was razed Thursday. No firefighters were seen, and the blaze raged unchecked. Rockets and shells were fired at the city center by both sides as the front line repeatedly shifted from street to street. Reporters cruising by car through the deserted streets briefly came under fire, but the source of the shooting could not be determined. On Bushrod Island, several thousand hungry people stood in line in hope of buying a ticket that would get them a bag of rice. One woman said she had been waiting for three days. Most of Monrovia's 500,000 inhabitants have been without food, running water or electricity since last month. About 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have died since rebels invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast in December. The rebels accuse Doe, who took power in a 1980 coup, of corruption and human rights abuses. The insurgents have since split into two factions _ those led by Johnson and those of Taylor, who led the original invasion. Johnson's army has emerged as the stronger force, according to foreign diplomats. A peace feeler was put out by one of Doe's ministers, who asked that his name not be used. He said he was eager to talk to Johnson about possible ways to end the fighting, ``which is killing untold numbers of people.'' The minister stressed the offer would include Doe's unconditional resignation, but would require the nomination of a provisional government. ``He can't resign without having someone replace him,'' the minister said. But he said he was acting on his own initiative, and had not advised Doe of his move. Johnson, informed of the proposal at his headquarters in a roadside cafe on bushrod island, scorned the minister's offer and said he was interested only in getting Doe, ``not in his maneuvers to save himself.'' ``When I get him, he will be put on trial for killing Liberians,' he said. ``But if he is convicted, we will imprison him for life. We will not kill him.'' On Monday, up to 600 civilian refugees were killed in a Lutheran church compound. Witnesses said the slayings were committed by government troops. Doe said rebels dressed as government soldiers were to blame. The victims were members of the Gio and Mano tribes, from which the rebels get most of their support. Soldiers accused of the massacre were said by witnesses to belong to Doe's Krahn tribe or the Mandingo tribe.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Forces Tighten Grip; Soviets-US Demand Arms Cutoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd pvs, `The Soviet...' to CORRECT to Iraqi, sted Soviet troops. Pickup 4th, `In Washington...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos WX7,8,NY8
DOC.TEXT: Shelling and gunfire today shook portions of Kuwait's capital, indicating a last-ditch attempt by Kuwaiti forces to hold out against the more powerful Iraqi army. World reaction toughened against Iraq's invasion. President Bush met with advisers amid concerns Iraq would try to push into Saudi Arabia. A NATO source said the United States had alerted allies it had ``contingency plans'' if the Iraqis pushed beyond Kuwaiti territory. The Soviet Union said it had been told through contacts in the Iraqi capital, Baghdad, that Iraqi troops would soon withdraw from Kuwait. In Washington, the State Department said Iraqi troops were within 5 to 10 miles of the Saudi border. The department also said 14 Americans are now known to be missing in Kuwait and Washington believed they were in Iraqi hands. The USS Independence, backed by six U.S. warships, headed to the Persian Gulf to back up eight warships already there. France also announced it was sending a second warship to the gulf. The United States and the Soviet Union, in a rare joint statement issued in Moscow, demanded an international cutoff of arms supplies to Iraq and pressed for an early Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. Major nations, including some heavily dependent on Iraqi oil, today followed the superpowers in announcing measures aimed at pressuring Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Egypt joined in the condemnation. In other developments: _A missile landed on Saudi territory near the convergence of the Saudi, Iraqi, and Kuwaiti borders, diplomats in Saudi Arabia said. No injuries or damage were reported. _Fourteen American oil workers were missing in the wake of the invasion. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad has pressed the foreign ministry to account for them ``on an immediate basis,'' but so far Iraq had not responded. _Jordan's King Hussein said an Arab summit would be held in Saudi Arabia on Sunday to discuss the crisis. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in an unprecedented display of superpower cooperation, issued a joint statement in Moscow calling for all nations to stop shipping arms to Iraq and pressing for a pullout of Iraqi troops. At the Moscow news conference, Shevardnadze predicted that withdrawal would occur soon. Iraqi troops backed by 350 tanks and air cover swept into Kuwait before dawn Thursday and penetrated as far as Kuwait's southern oil fields near the border with Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest producer of oil. A well-informed diplomatic source said there had been no movement of Iraqi troops across the Saudi frontier today. But some members of Congress expressed fears Thursday that Saudi Arabia could be the next target of Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein. The State Department said today Iraqi troops were within five to 10 miles of the Saudi border. ``Their presence there clearly raises significant concern,'' said Boucher. The NATO source, speaking in Brussels on condition of anonymity, said the United States informed allies during a special meeting ``that it was aware that Iraq may have designs beyond Kuwait and informed the allies that it has drawn up contingency plans of action to respond to that eventuality.'' He said American officials did not explain what actions were under consideration. Details of the situation in Kuwait, an oil-rich sheikdom on the Persian Gulf, were hard to come by. Telephone operators in Bahrain said it appeared phone lines were cut this afternoon. A curfew was in force, all ports were sealed, the airport remained closed and the three main land crossings into Kuwait were impassable, said a British Embassy official, reached by telephone in the morning. Diplomats said shelling was heard through the night at the country's main military barracks in Shuwaikh, in the northern part of Kuwait city. Residents woke to what one described as ``as very active gunshots and louder explosions than at any time'' since the invasion. There was also shelling on the coast, 16 miles from Shuwaikh, and two military vehicles were on fire, said residents reached by telephone. The British Embassy official, quoted by the British news agency Press Association, reported explosions and gunfire along the seafront and around key installations, including the emir's palace. The reports indicated stiffer resistance than on the first day of the invasion, when Iraqi quickly soldiers seized all government buildings in Kuwait city. However, Kuwait's entire military has about 20,300 soldiers, most of whom have never seen combat. Iraq's armed forces number 1 million and are battled-hardened after eight years of war with Iran. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait after two weeks of threats stemming from a dispute over oil and land. Saddam accused Kuwait of stealing oil from a field that includes land both sides claim. He also blamed Kuwait for a drop in world oil prices, saying it cheated on OPEC production levels. Oil is Iraq's main revenue source, and the invasion could double Iraq's oil supplies. Within hours of the assault, Kuwait's ruler, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, had fled his palace, reportedly for Saudi Arabia. Despite seemingly impossible odds, the sheik's government vowed to fight to win back the country. His radio station, beaming from an unknown location, appealed for help from the Arab world. In a break with its major Arab neighbors, who remained conspicuously silent, Egypt today strongly condemned the invasion and called for the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops. The official Iraq News Agency today said ``massive demonstrations'' were held in Baghdad and other Iraqi cities to support the invasion. There was no further word on casualties. Diplomats said at least 200 Kuwaitis were killed or wounded the day before, most of them from the government's Emiri Guard. Officials in Washington said the number of missing Americans was unclear. On Thursday, State Department officials said eight American workers were seized. Today, White House spokesman Douglas Davidson said an oil company reported eight people missing, six of them Americans. An embassy official in Baghdad was dispatched to Iraq's Foreign Ministry to inquire about the Americans. Word of the detentions came from a U.S. oil company for whom the Americans worked. U.S. officials refused to identify the company. There are about 3,000 Americans living in Kuwait, where an estimated 60 percent of the 1.9 million people are foreigners. Most of the Americans work in the oil business. The invasion occurred a day after talks intended to resolve the Iraqi-Kuwaiti dispute collapsed. It drew immediate worldwide condemnation and harsh sanctions. The Soviet Union, Iraq's main arms supplier, announced a halt to weapons sales to Baghdad. Bush froze Iraqi assets and blocked most Iraqi imports, including the all-important oil. He also froze Kuwaiti assets to protect them from Iraq. France froze Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets, while Britain put a hold on Kuwait assets only. Japan, West Germany, Italy, Belgium and Luxembourg were among the nations announcing similar moves today. Japanese officials met to decide how far to go in matching the U.S. economic sanctions. South Korea _ which imports all its oil, nearly 12 percent of it from Kuwait and Iraq _ was setting up an emergency task force to deal with possible disruptions in the oil supply.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
