DOC.HEAD: Bush Presses Baghdad on Missing Americans; Iraqi Troops Near Saudi Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, addding Aspin account of Iraqi troop movements and replacing source account of NATO contact with Fitzwater confirmation; edits to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The White House today pressed Iraq for information about Americans missing in Kuwait and said Iraq's ``ruthlessness and disregard for international law'' raised serious concerns that its conquering troops might move next into Saudi Arabia. ``We are extremely concerned about the possibility of Iraq broadening its invasions plans to any other country. ... They are close enough to the Saudi border to indicate cause for concern. But we don't know what their intentions or motives are,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. On Capitol Hill, Rep. Les Aspin, chairman of the Hous Armed Services Committee said that since Thursday's invasion Iraq has moved two additional military units from their positions along the Iranian border to the staging area near the junction of Kuwait, Iraq and Saudi Arabia. ``I think it means war'' if Iraqi forces cross into Saudi Arabia, Aspin said. ``I say that not as a threat but as a prediction. The world cannot sit back and watch a person like Saddam Hussein take over half of the oil reserves in the world.'' The United States informed Western allies today that it did not rule out military action should Iraqi troops push beyond Kuwaiti territory, Fitzwater told reporters. President Bush spent 75 minutes this morning with top advisers reviewing intelligence on the tense situation in the Middle East and the progress in implementing U.S. economic sanctions against Iraq, including a trade embargo that already had led to the seizure of Iraqi crude oil, Fitzwater said. Also discussed was the potential impact of the sanctions on U.S. oil supplies and prices, with a consensus emerging that the harm would be ``moderate or slight,'' Fitzwater said. The immediate efforts were aimed at a diplomatic solution to the crisis, but Fitzwater said there was no indication Iraq planned to heed international demands that it withdraw from Kuwait. ``At this point we have received only scorn from Iraq and no indication that they intend to comply,'' Fitzwater said. The State Department today said 14 Americans were missing in Kuwait and believed to be held by Iraqi troops. Spokesman Richard Boucher said some Iraqi forces were positioned 5 miles to 10 miles from the Saudi border. Saudi diplomats also reported a missile landing in the border area but reported no injuries. As tensions rose in the troubled region, the State Department advised the 3,000 Americans in Kuwait and the 500 in Iraq to leave as quickly as possible. In Kuwait, however, airports and ports are closed. Fitzwater said the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Thomas Pickering, was pushing for U.N. sanctions against Iraq that include ``the full range of action by air, sea or land forces that may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace or security, including blockade.'' Fitzwater said the administration had demanded from the Iraqi ambassador to the United States a full and immediate accounting of American citizens missing in Kuwait. In Moscow, where the United States and the Soviet Union issued a rare joint statement condemning the invasion, Soviet officials predicted Iraq would soon withdraw its troops. Fitzwater was not as optimistic. ``Clearly the actions of Iraq at this point indicate a ruthlessness and disregard for international law that must make us concerned about all the other countries in the region and their security,'' the White House spokesman said. As Bush mulled his options, an irate Congress pressed for a worldwide embargo on Iraqi oil and some members worried aloud about the potential for Iraqi leader Hussein to strike against other oil-producing nations. ``If there's an intention of Iraq to overrun Saudi Arabia, then I think this would call for a direct military response by the United States, Western Europe, maybe even the Soviet Union,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said today on NBC. ``This would be an action that could not be ignored.'' Bush's immediate military options are considered limited because U.S. forces in the area lack sufficient attack power to mount a formidable challenge to the battle-tested Iraqis. One aircraft carrier, the USS Independence, was ordered Thursday to head to the Persian Gulf to add firepower to the U.S. presence but was said to be several days away. The Pentagon today said another carrier, the USS Saratoga, and the assault ship USS Inchon were to head for the Mediterranean within the next few days for deployments the Defense Department said had been planned for months. The administration also dispatched an embassy official in Baghdad to Iraq's foreign ministry to ask about the Americans missing since Wednesday. The State Department said the official would ``remind them of their commitment to safeguard American lives.'' The president warned Thursday that any harm to American citizens would drastically change the U.S. posture toward Iraq, which continued today to consolidated its control over the oil-rich Kuwait emirate. Iraq's invasion was a dash of cold water to international diplomats still basking in the end of the Cold War. No superpower appeared to be influencing Iraq today; Secretary of State James A. Baker III was in Moscow for the unusual joint U.S.-Soviet declaration against the invasion. Bush said he hoped an international effort could persuade Saddam to restore Kuwait's autonomy. ``We're not ruling any options in, but we're not ruling any options out,'' the president said Thursday when asked whether he was ready to use military might to force a withdrawal of the Iraqi invasion that sent worldwide oil prices upward. Bush spoke by telephone with Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, and Fitzwater said ``they agreed that the attack on Kuwait was absolutely unacceptable.'' Pentagon officials said it would take at least several weeks to deploy a signifcant counterforce. The aircraft carrier Independence _ with jet fighters, attack aircraft and bombers aboard _ and six escort ships were dispatched to the Persian Gulf from the Indian Ocean, a journey of several thousand miles. The Navy already has eight warships in the gulf, but they lack attack and bomber aircraft and pose no significant threat to the Iraqi force. The Saratoga, based in Florida, was to head for the Mediterranean on Tuesday; the Inchon, now at Norfolk, Va., carries a Marine amphibious assault group and is due to leave for the Mediterranean on Monday, the Pentagon said. Although said to be routine, those deployments would significantly add to the U.S. forces in the area. Bush returned after midnight from a visit to Colorado, where he met with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. Both leaders pressed for worldwide sanctions against Iraq. Bush dropped plans for a weekend at Camp David, returning instead to the White House. The Congress moved quickly to support Bush's economic sanctions, even as some members doubted they would deter Hussein. The Senate, in a 97-0 vote endorsing sanctions, urged Bush to help organize an international economic boycott. The House voted 416-0 to cut off Iraq's $200 million a year in Export-Import Bank credits and tighten restrictions on U.S. exports with possible military applications. The president's order froze all Iraqi assets and banned nearly all commerce _ including the 588,000 barrels of Iraqi oil purchased daily by the United States. The impact was felt immediately as the Customs Service seized more than 13 million gallons of Iraqi crude off the coast of Texas. Iraq swiftly retaliated, saying it would suspend payments on its $2.4 billion debt to the United States. The United States gets half of its oil from abroad, and 10 percent from Iraq and Kuwait. America imported about $2.4 billion in oil and other goods last year from Iraq; U.S. exports to Iraq, chiefly agricultural commodities, totaled $1.17 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Invasion Spurs New Concerns for Hostage Families
With AM-US-Iraq bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait created new worries Friday for the families of Americans held hostage in Lebanon because of a complicated link between the captives and a group of Kuwaiti prisoners. ``What has always frustrated the families is that anything that happens in the Middle East has a ripple effect,'' said Peggy Say, the sister of Terry Anderson, the longest held of the six U.S. hostages in Lebanon. Say and others said they are concerned because the fate of 15 prisoners in Kuwait _ the so-called Dawa prisoners _ are connected to American hostages in Lebanon. Experts say that Imad Mugniyeh, a Moslem Shiite accused of masterminding American kidnappings in Lebanon, is the brother-in-law of Mustafa Yousef Badreddin, one of the prisoners in Kuwait. Badreddin and 14 others are serving life sentences in Kuwait for the 1983 bombings of the U.S. and French embassies in Kuwait. Mugniyeh, who operates under cover of the shadowy Islamic Jihad movement, has insisted the American hostages in Lebanon will not be freed until the Kuwaiti prisoners are released. The status of the Kuwaiti prisoners was unclear after Iraqi troops overran the oil-rich emirate. But one report said the prisoners had been taken to Baghdad, the capital of Iraq, according to Shireen Hunter, a Middle East expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. The State Department said it could not confirm the report. ``We don't want to speculate'' on where the prisoners are, said Joe Reap, a department spokesman. ``We have no idea what effect this might have on the hostages (in Lebanon),'' he said. ``It's a crap-shoot,'' said Bill Foley, who works with the Journalists Committee To Free Terry Anderson, a group formed to seek freedom for Anderson and the others. Anderson, who was seized in March 1985, is a correspondent for The Associated Press. But Hunter said moving the prisoners to Baghdad would ``complicate the situation even more'' because the prisoners are no friends of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. If any harm came to the Kuwaiti prisoners, the fear is that Islamic Jihad might retaliate against the Americans. On the other hand, Hunter said, removing the Kuwaiti prisoners from Kuwait might actually bode well for the hosages. The prisoners are thought to be pro-Iranian, even though 12 of them are Iraqis who belong to the fundamentalist Shiite Dawa Islamiya movement. The other three, including Badreddin, are Lebanese. The volatile nature of politics in the Middle East is upsetting to families of the U.S. hostages because it keeps them on emotional tenterhooks, Say said. The Iraqi invasion is just another example, she said.

DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE CIVIL RIGHTS ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Arizona Man Survives Three Days in Desert
DOC.TEXT: A 65-year-old epileptic man stranded in the Arizona desert survived for nearly three days by eating cactus and crawling in search of shade, his daughter-in-law said. Manuel Cantu of Wittmann became so desperate that he tried to blow up his disabled car with a gunshot to the gas tank in hopes someone would see the fire, said Diane Cantu. Cantu, who was reported missing Monday, was rescued Thursday after a rancher heard his call for help on a citizens band radio, a spokesman for the Maricopa County Sheriff's Office said. He was treated for dehydration and sunburn at Phoenix General Hospital and Medical Center but was in good condition Friday, family members said. ``He's a real cowboy in the truest sense,'' said Diane Cantu. ``He's spent a lot of time in the desert, and he knows survival skills.'' Cantu left home Monday morning to go target shooting in the surrounding desert, said his daughter-in-law. His car got stuck in sand in a deserted area about 30 miles northwest of Phoenix, where temperatures soared well above 100 degrees this week. Cantu has epilepsy and was not carrying medicine, but did not have a seizure during the ordeal, she said. When his small container of water ran out, Cantu ripped apart cactus and chewed the inside for moisture. During the day, he crawed under palo verde trees, which provide little shade, she said. Diane Cantu said her father-in-law tried to set a signal fire by shooting his car's gasoline tank but ``the thing wouldn't blow up.'' A rescue plane spotted Cantu's car Thursday morning, after he reached a rancher via his CB radio and the rancher called authorities, said sheriff's spokesman Duane Brady.

DOC.HEAD: Oil-Rich Iranian Province Jolted By Quakes
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake jolted the oil-rich Iranian province of Khuzestan on Friday, a little more than a month after a devastating earthquake in the north killed 40,000 people. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the temblor struck at mid-afternoon and measured 5.5 on the open-ended Richter scale. Reports on damages or casualties were not immediately available, the dispatch said. Khuzestan is located on the oil-producing belt in southern Iran. IRNA said a series of strong jolts had also shaken the town of Ardebil and surrounding areas in the northwestern province of East Azerbaijan over the past three days. The recent temblors caused considerable panic in the wake of the June 21 earthquake that registered 7.3 on the Richter scale. That quake killed 40,000 people, injured 60,000 and left half a million people homeless in northern Gilan and Zanjan provinces.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sets Record for Solo Transatlantic Crossing
DOC.TEXT: A 33-year-old Frenchwoman on Friday set a record for a solo sailboat crossing of the Atlantic Ocean, French media reported. The woman, Florence Arthaud, beat the old best time, set by a Frenchman, by nearly two days, according to the reports. Ms. Arthaud arrived at Lizard Point in southwestern Britain in the pre-dawn hours after a voyage of nine days, 21 hours and 42 minutes, said Louis Bodin, a friend of Arthaud's who helped guide her across the Atlantic. The previous record of 11 days, 11 hours and 47 minutes _ about 40 hours slower than Ms. Arthaud's time _ was set by Bruno Peyron of France aboard a catamaran in 1987. ``I'm happy I've arrived. It's the first time I'm really happy it's over because it was really tough,'' she said in a French radio interview. ``It's really trying on the nerves to make a crossing like that,'' she said. ``I don't get seasick, but during the whole trip my stomach was tied in knots.'' Ms. Arthaud set out from New York City on July 24 aboard the 60-foot trimaran Pierre Premier. She averaged a speed of 12.1 knots, or 12.5 miles per hour, over the 2,800-mile route, Bodin said. The crossing would have taken less time except there was little wind during the last 80 miles, he said. ``For me, the record is no more and no less than a regular sailing trip,'' Ms. Arthaud said in a radio interview. ``It wasn't routine but it's part of my daily life. It's my life, always trying to go faster.''

DOC.HEAD: Mysterious Illness Confirmed in 54 Cases
DOC.TEXT: Since March, physicians throughout Texas have reported 149 cases of a mysterious new illness called Palestine Syndrome. The malady mostly strikes children and is characterized by high fever and temporary arthritis. Dr. Jeffrey W. Jundt, a physician at Scott and White Memorial Hospital who first identified the illness, said Thursday that experts still know little of its origins and are uncertain of how, or if, it can be prevented or cured. It has not been fatal and victims recover completely, Jundt said, but some patients have been hospitalized as long as six months. ``We have no idea whether it's increasing, but we're not being swamped with cases,'' said Jeffrey Taylor with the Texas Department of Health. ``There are some new ones that have onset in July, and we are following up on those.'' The illness was named after a town about midway between Dallas and Houston where it was first encountered last March. Although the ailment is named for Palestine, so far only four confirmed cases have come from there. Taylor said cases have been identified in 34 Texas counties, most in the north central and eastern sections of the state. Scott and White hospital spokeswoman Charlene Lee said the hospital has received inquiries about Palestine Syndrome from other sections of the country. The federal Centers for Disease Control are investigating, but there is no nationwide accounting of how many people have the illness. Jundt prefers to call Palestine fever the STAR complex, an acronym for its major symptoms: sore throat, temperature greater than 100 degrees for seven days, arthritis in three different joints and a hivelike rash. Symptoms have been reported in 149 people, including three adults. Of those, 54 cases have been confirmed and 25 of them have been recommended for aggressive blood sample studies by the state health department and the CDC. Most of the confirmed cases have been in children under age 15. But some have been in women in their 20s and 30s. So far no cases have been confirmed in adult males. The illness does not appear to be contagious. Doctors are testing bodily secretions, including saliva, urine and nasal secretions taken from the 25 patients in hopes of isolating viral particles that could help identify other viruses that might be associated with the syndrome. Five of the 25 patients in the survey group tested positive for the rubella virus and two were positive for parvo virus, which is commonly associated with puppies but causes arthritis, Jundt said. Like the progression of the syndrome itself, the recovery period is variable, he said. Once the virus runs its course, recurrent episodes are considered unlikely, although there have been exceptions.

DOC.HEAD: Cease-Fire Allows Red Cross to Remove Bodies In Battle Zone
DOC.TEXT: A cease-fire took hold Friday between rival Shiite Moslem militiamen, and Red Cross workers collected 60 corpses from a south Lebanon battle zone. Also Friday, the Amal militia held a mass funeral in the southern port city of Tyre for eight Shiites killed in a car bomb explosion Thursday. No one claimed responsibility for the blast. Convoys of the International Committee of the Red Cross moved into the villages of Jarjou, Ein Qana and Kfar Milki in Iqlim al-Tuffah, or the Apple Province, at midafternoon to collect corpses left after fierce fighting. A Red Cross statement said that during the operation no shots were fired by militiamen of the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the more secular Amal, which is Arabic for hope. Police said the 60 dead already had been included in the overall casualty toll, which stood at 189 killed and 570 wounded since the current round of fighting between the two factions broke out July 16. Amal, which is allied with Syria, and the Iranian-backed Hezbollah have been fighting on and off for three years for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. At least 1,049 people have been killed and nearly 3,150 wounded in the power struggle. The Red Cross did not say whether any new operations would be mounted in the Apple Province, which covers 50 square miles of rocky highlands near Israel's security enclave in south Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan sent his regards Friday to a 12-year-old Brooklyn boy who was set on fire by a bully earlier this year. ``Please know that you're still in our thoughts and prayers,'' Reagan said in a taped message to David Opont that was broadcast on ``CBS This Morning.'' ``Thank you _ a lot,'' Opont replied emphatically. The appearance marked Opont's first interview since he was released June 8 from Jamaica Hospital in Queens. He was given a 50-50 chance of survival after he was attacked on his way to school March 7. During his hospitalization, which included six skin grafts and intensive physical therapy, he received cards, letters, gifts and good wishes from around the nation. Reagan was among his hospital room visitors. Opont was asked what Reagan's visit had meant to him. ``Everything,'' he replied. Although Opont still undergoes therapy, ``He's coming along quite nicely,'' said Dr. Craig Rosenberg, director of rehabilitation medicine at Jamaica. ``He's an extremely courageous person.''

Screenwriter Bruce Joel Rubin remembers dreaming that he would be able to stay in Indiana and still have a successful Hollywood film career. Those hometown hopes are gone now, but Rubin is thrilled with the success of his critically acclaimed film, Paramount Pictures' ``Ghost,'' and the direction of his career. ``I would have loved to have made films in Bloomington,'' he reflected from his Southern California office this week. ``When I first went out there I had some hopes I could write material from Indiana and ship it off to Hollywood and people would send me checks.'' Rubin came to Bloomington in 1974 to be part of the Ashram spiritual center. It was there that he wrote his first screenplay, which later became ``Brainstorm,'' Natalie Wood's last film. ``When `Brainstorm' premiered out here I had lunch one day with (director) Brian DePalma. He told me, `If you want to make it out here, you have to come here.''' Rubin followed the advice. ``Happiness is a relative thing,'' he mused. ``It's just too bad there's no perfect, ideal arrangement for everybody. You just have to trust something deep inside and have the courage to follow it where it leads.''

When chef David Bouley got the word that his restaurant had been awarded four stars by The New York Times, he celebrated with an after-midnight, five-course meal for his staff of 60. There was lots of champagne and singing, Bouley said Friday. For desert, the pastry chef, Peter Sioti, turned out a delectable chocolate souffle, fittingly topped with four candles. Bouley, whose restaurant in the trendy Tribeca neighborhood bears his name, learned of the award late Thursday from early editions of Friday's newspaper. He called it ``a dream come true.'' Times restaurant critic Bryan Miller elevated Bouley from two to four-star status. David Bouley's ``potential for greatness has been realized,'' he wrote in his review. The chef describes his food as French-inspired but heavily influenced by American tastes and regional products. ``I don't use cream or butter in sauces,'' explained Bouley, 37, whose French parents raised him in Storrs, Conn. A five-course fixed-price lunch is $32; the fixed-price dinner is $65. New York City now has six restaurants that have been awarded the coveted four stars by the Times: Bouley, The Quilted Giraffe, Lafayette, Le Cirque, Le Bernardin and Lutece.

Retired businessman Edward Piszek, who spends most of his time promoting Polish causes, has been playing host to the 17-year-old son of Poland's Lech Walesa. Included was a fishing trip to Alaska's Kenai River last week. Slawek Walesa caught his first American fish, a 45-pound king salmon, and said it was ``the most exciting time of his life.'' He posed for a photograph with his catch like any other happy teen-ager. No one else in the party caught anything, Piszek reported. ``I was just lucky,'' said young Walesa, now winding up his U.S. visit at Piszek's home in Miami Shores, Fla., where he is enjoying the beach prior to returning to Poland next week. Piszek, whose primary residence is Fort Washington, is the former owner of Mrs. Paul's Kitchens, which produce fish products. Besides his strong ties to Poland, he also is a friend of Pope John Paul II.

The bass player for the Kentucky HeadHunters country music band was hospitalized Friday in South Carolina, a spokeswoman said. Doug Phelps, 29, was undergoing tests for a suspected stomach virus, spokeswoman Kathy Gangwisch said. As a result of the illness, the five-member band canceled appearances Friday night in Richmond, Va., Saturday night in Charlotte, N.C., and Sunday in Charleston, S.C. The concerts, headlined by country star Hank Williams Jr., will go on without the Kentucky HeadHunters. The band has a top-selling country album, ``Pickin' on Nashville.''

DOC.HEAD: US Demands Information on Missing Americans
With US-Iraq bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Friday demanded that Iraq provide immediate information about the fate of 14 American oil workers missing from Kuwait and believed to have been rounded up by Iraqi troops. U.S. officials were also trying to confirm rumors that other Americans might have been picked up by Iraqi troops who invaded Kuwait in the pre-dawn hours Thursday, said one official. A U.S. diplomat in Baghdad went to the foreign ministry and presented a list of the 14, the companies they worked for, and the three sites from which they were taken on Thursday when Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait, said a U.S. official. The diplomat asked that Iraq account for the 14 ``as soon as possible on an immediate basis,'' said State Department spokesman Richard Boucher. The U.S. diplomat in Baghdad reminded the Iraqis ``of their commitment to safeguard the safety of Americans,'' said Boucher. The commitment was given to U.S. diplomats in Baghdad during the early hours of the invasion, Boucher said. In Washington, Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly summoned Iraq's ambassador to demand an accounting of the missing Americans, said an official who asked not to be named. As he left the short meeting, Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat denied his country was holding any Americans. Pressed about reports of Americans being seized, al-Mashat answered, ``This is again one of your rumors which has no basis whatsoever.'' However, Boucher said that ``we can't confirm they're in Iraqi control but we believe they are.'' The U.S. Embassy in Kuwait has been in touch with many of the 3,000 Americans estimated to be in the country, and the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad has contacted the 500 Americans believed to be in Iraq, Boucher said. Americans in both countries were being advised to leave as soon as they could, he said. For some, it was unclear when that might be. The airport in Kuwait was rendered inoperational by Iraqi bombing and Iraqi troops had closed off roads leading from the country, said another official. Neighboring Saudi Arabia has promised to allow free entry to any Americans able to flee Kuwait, the official said. The administration, citing privacy laws, has refused to provide the names of the missing or the companies for which they work. But John Mika, vice president of the Santa Fe International Corp. in Alhambra, Calif., said the company had been informed that eight of its employees were ``detained by Iraqi troops. Of the eight employees, six are Americans, one British and one is Canadian.'' He declined to elaborate. Doris Whatley of Shreveport, La., said she received a call from Santa Fe telling her that her husband, Donald, was missing. He had been working as a drilling supervisor in Kuwait, she said. ``They took him from his rig this morning and they took him across the border (to Iraq),'' she said Thursday. In Gilmer, Texas, the family of Charles Amos, 56, said he was among those rounded up by Iraqi soldiers. Amos also works for Santa Fe, the family said. ``We were set to have a family reunion this weekend, and Dad was going to fly out of Kuwait'' early Thursday morning, said his daughter, Karen Amos. An American woman who fled Kuwait to Saudi Arabia confirmed that Whatley and Amos were among six Americans taken by Iraqi troops from the Ahmadi oil town where her husband worked. The woman, Elizabeth Thames of Glenrock, Pa., identified the others as Rainard L. Walterscheid of Dallas, Texas; Gary Carr and Bobby G. Parker, hometowns unknown; and B.J. Tinch, originally from Nashville, Tenn. and now living in Britain. Thames quoted oil field superintendent Ibrahim Mustah as telling her that before the six were taken, Iraqi jets shelled their facility. ``They were terrified and the camp where the workers were was ransacked by tank-borne troops who took food, blankets, water, anything they could find,'' she quoted him as telling her. ``The six were grabbed and taken to Iraq as far as he knew, but the Iraqis left the rest of the group, who were Arabs, completely alone,'' she said. Thames spoke by telephone to The Associated Press after reaching Saudi Arabia with her husband and son.

DOC.HEAD: Rock Groups To Raise Money for Orchestra
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Humen and Rokks are cq
DOC.TEXT: Buffalo's financially strapped symphony orchestra is getting some help from musicians who don't play Mozart or Bach. Fat Brat, Only Humen and Wile E. Rokks are among the six local rock groups playing at ``Rock for the Symphony II'' Monday night to raise money for the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, which has a $2.2 million deficit. A similar event in February raised about $1,000 for the orchestra, said spokesman Steve Paschang. ``Not a significant amount, but in our condition, we'll take anything.'' The orchestra has missed its payroll several times and canceled the last eight concerts of the season to save money. Its musicians have been asked to take pay cuts until a $20 million fund-raising drive is complete.

DOC.HEAD: Rap Duo Kid 'n Play Arrested, Fined, Freed
LaserPhoto AUG2 of Aug. 2
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested the rap duo ``Kid 'n Play'' for ``simulating sex'' during a performance. Christopher L.``Play'' Martin, 28, and Christopher P.``Kid'' Reid, 26, were freed after each paid a $550 fine. Reid called the offending motions Thursday night ``a little extra gyration stuff _ nothing offensive, we thought.'' They were arrested after performing at the Augusta-Richmond County Civic Center, police said. ``Kid 'n Play'' was one of the openers for a concert featuring the rap group ``Public Enemy.'' No other rappers on the bill were arrested and no fans were involved in the ``simulated sex,'' police said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet, Norwegian Border Guards Have First Soccer Match
DOC.TEXT: Norwegian troops watched Soviet soldiers march across the heavily-guarded frontier into this NATO-country Friday, but the only shots fired by either side were at a soccer goal. In the spirit of glasnost, the Norwegians invited the Soviets to cross the border, closed to them for 46 years, for a friendly soccer game in the arctic border village of Kirkenes, Norway. Not a goal was scored in the match. ``We wanted to ease the tension a little bit,'' said Norwegian border commissioner Hugo Overgaard. The opposing soldiers, mainly young conscripts, usually scowl and grab for weapons upon sighting each other anywhere along the 120-mile fenced frontier in the far north. This summer was marked by border incidents, including Soviet troops chasing and shooting at fishermen in Norwegian territory. The tensions seemed to fade when the uniformed soldiers met on the border, slapped each other's backs and exchanged smiles and addresses, reported the Norwegian news agency NTB. ``This is the high point of my military service,'' said border guard Igor Gerasimov, one of 11 Soviet players. ``I hope the border can be even more open in the future,'' he told NTB. The Norwegian and Soviet troops marched into Kirkenes, a 15 minute walk from the border, to look around before the game. ``It's small but interesting,'' said Gerasimov. ``There are so many products for sale.'' The 19-year-old soldier returned to base with the other Soviets after the game. ``Everything went great. To be honest, the thing I worried most about was the game's final score. Something like 9-0 would have been terrible,'' the border commissioner said. The game ended in a perfect zero-zero tie, he said. The game won't change much on the border, however, he said. ``The soldiers still won't be allowed to talk or wave at each other,'' Overgaard said. ``But they can smile.''

DOC.HEAD: Escaped Wallaby Is Returned To Boston Area Zoo
DOC.TEXT: Aardu the wallaby, on the lam for 11 days, was back in his cage at the Stone Zoo on Friday after zookeepers lured him home with a hint of female companionship. Zoo officials found Aardu at about 7:30 a.m., trapped in a cage in a nearby wooded area that they had baited with straw carrying the scent of female wallabies. Back at the zoo, the small cousin of the kangaroo was sound asleep when about 20 reporters appeared at his cage for a news conference. ``I think he had a lot of food but he certainly wasn't happy being alone, especially without females,'' said Mark Goldstein, executive director of Metro Parks Zoos, which operates the zoo in this northern suburb of Boston. Aardu bounded out of his cage July 23 and headed for the Middlesex Fells, a 3,000-acre wooded preserve nearby. Zoo officials said the 18-month-old Aardu, a hardy vegetarian, could have survived for months in the woods if necessary. Whether he will survive state budget cuts is another matter. The zoo is due to close in April 1991. Ilyas Bhatti, commissioner of the Metropolitan District Commission, said it was unclear whether Aardu could be transferred to another zoo. State Rep. Paul Casey said he was worried Aardu might be put to death. ``If that's the case I'd rather Aardu had remained free,'' Casey said. ``At least he has a fighting chance out in the fells.'' Goldstein said officials were exploring the possibility of keeping the zoo operating by making it a non-profit organization.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Iraqi Troops to Begin Withdrawing From Kuwait Sunday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines ugt series, ADDS background; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today its troops will begin withdrawing from Kuwait in two days, Baghdad Radio announced. An Iraqi government spokesman said all Iraqi troops in Kuwait will be withdrawn according to a timetable, beginning Sunday, said the radio broadcast monitored in Cyprus. In Amman, Jordan, a senior Iraqi diplomat said: ``We believe that the national government in Kuwait can take over all the responsibilities now and they are capable of defending their national security.'' The broadcast, which was also carried by a station calling itself the Provisional Government of Kuwait Radio, said the Al-Sabah royal family that ruled Kuwait for almost 250 years will never return to power. ``The bygone regime is finished forever and will never come back,'' the spokesman said. Iraq said it sent its troops into Kuwait Thursday to provide security for the provisional government and would withdraw when the situation stabilized. The international diplomatic community scorned the claim. The British ambassador to the United Nations accused Baghdad of setting up a puppet regime in Kuwait. Earlier today, an Iraqi missile slammed into Saudi Arabia and thousands of Iraqi troops pushed to within a few miles of the Saudi border, heightening world concerns that their invasion would not stop in Kuwait. Iraq's invasion followed two weeks of threats and accusations against its small Persian Gulf neighbor. On July 17 Saddam accused Kuwait of stealing oil from a field that includes land both sides claim. Saddam also blamed Kuwait for a fall in oil prices, saying it contributed to the oil glut by cheating on its OPEC production quotas. Details from Kuwait today were sketchy. Public communication was severed and a radio station opposed to the invasion was knocked off the air. Its last message was a desperate appeal from Kuwait for fellow Arabs to ``rush, rush to their help.''

DOC.HEAD: Cult Member Pleads Guilty In Slaying Of Five
DOC.TEXT: A religious cult member who sat in on meetings where the ritual murder of a five-member family was discussed pleaded guilty Friday to conspiracy to commit aggravated murder. Susan Luff, 31, told Common Pleas Court Judge James Jackson that she should have told authorities about cult leader Jeffrey Lundgren's plan to kill Dennis and Cheryl Avery and their three daughters. ``It was morally and legally wrong'' not to do so, she said. At the pre-trial hearing, Ms. Luff said she was present at scripture meetings where Lundgren discussed killing the Avery family. Mrs. Luff was among 13 members arrested in January for the 1989 murders. The bodies of the victims were buried under a barn at a farm in Kirtland, about 30 miles from Cleveland, where the cult members lived commune-style. All five had been bound with duct tape, gagged and shot. The Averys were considered less steadfast in their support of Lundgren's beliefs, prosecutors say, and may have been killed as a sacrifice before the cult members left the Kirtland area in April 1989 for a wilderness trek in West Virginia. Jeffrey Lundgren, 40, who prosecutors allege shot the Averys, could get the death penalty if convicted at his trial, set for Aug. 13. Prosecutors said they would drop five counts of complicity to commit aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping once Ms. Luff has cooperated in other cases. No sentencing date was set on the five counts against Ms. Luff, who could face life in prison. Her 30-year-old husband, Ronald Luff, is charged with aggravated murder and kidnapping. Alice Lundgren, 39, the cult leader's wife, was convicted Wednesday on five counts each of complicity and conspiracy to commit aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping. She faces life in prison. Four other cult members have entered guilty pleas on various charges. Lundgren, a defrocked lay minister from the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, formed his own group in 1988.

Democrats _ Andrews, N; Brooks, N; Bryant, N; Bustamante, N; Chapman, Y; Coleman, N; de la Garza, N; Frost, N; Geren, Y; Gonzalez, N; Construction payrolls fell by 50,000 jobs, after seasonal adjustment, the fifth consecutive decline and a reflection of continued weakness in the housing market. Construction jobs are more than 100,000 below the level of last fall, the government said. The nation's manufacturing slump also continued in July, as factory payrolls fell by 7,000 jobs. It was the 15th time in 16 months that manufacturing jobs declined. Since reaching a post-recession peak in March 1989, nearly 350,000 factory jobs have been lost. Health services, which had added an average of 50,000 jobs each month in the first half of this year, expanded by only half that amount in July, adding 25,000 new jobs. Labor costs continued to increase. Average hourly earnings posted a 0.6 percent rise in July to $10.09, up from the $10.03 the average worker earned per hour in June. Overall, total civilian employment was about 118 million in July, down from the 118.4 million employed in June. The jobless numbered 6.8 million, up from 6.4 million employed in June. Last month's big jump in unemployment was a major departure from the steady nature of the jobless rate over the past two years. Before July, the jobless rate had fluctuated within a tenth of a percentage point of 5.3 percent since September 1988. The only exception was March of last year, when it hit a 15-year low of 5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: `thirtysometing' Star Returns to Work
DOC.TEXT: Timothy Busfield, who plays an ad executive in the yuppie ensemble show ``thirtysomething,'' has settled a dispute with the makers of the ABC series and will return to work, the studio said Friday. The announcement by David Gerber, chairman of the MGM-UA Television Production Group, came two days after his company sued Busfield in Los Angeles Superior Court. The suit alleged breach of contract and said that the actor, who wanted a raise, had threatened to boycott the show. The suit said Busfield wanted $36,375 an episode, while MGM-UA had offered him $28,750 per episode. The acclaimed ABC series chronicles the lives of a group of young urban professionals as they marry, separate, have children of their own and deal with death and disease. ``There will be no further comment,'' said MGM-UA spokeswoman Lori Gerson when asked if the company's lawsuit was dropped. Production of the series' fourth season began Friday in Los Angeles. Busfield was nominated Thursday for an Emmy award for his portrayal of the advertising executive whose wife's battle with ovarian cancer is expected to be a key part of the show's coming season. He recently wrapped up a co-starring role in Broadway's ``A Few Good Men.''

DOC.HEAD: Drug Warehouse Discovered; Linked to Drug-Smuggling Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: An underground warehouse raided by Mexican police may have been used to store drugs later smuggled into Arizona through an elaborate tunnel, authorities said. Like the tunnel, the warehouse was concealed beneath rooms that could be raised by sophisticated hydraulic lifts, Mexican federal police said. Police seized 5{ tons of marijuana in the raid Sunday, but men guarding the cache escaped. The tunnel, which linked Agua Prieta, Mexico, and Douglas, Ariz., was discovered in May. Authorities said it was used to smuggle cocaine and marijuana. Nogales, a border town, is about 80 miles west of Agua Prieta. About 15 agents were met with gunfire during the raid, but no one was wounded, Mario Alberto Torrijos, head of the Nogales office of the Federal Judicial Police, said Thursday. The tunnel and warehouses _ including a similar one found recently in Guadalajara _ are probably linked, Mexican police said. Drugs may have been stored in the Nogales warehouse before being smuggled through the tunnel, they said. The hydraulic system in Nogales, the first one discovered here, was more sophisticated than in the tunnel, Torrijos said. ``We were at the Agua Prieta tunnel, and when the covers were down, you could still smell the drugs,'' he said. ``When we close this chamber, it is so hermetically sealed you can't smell the marijuana.'' A small office, which could be lifted about six feet, sat atop two underground rooms, one 22 feet by 22 feet and the other 22 feet by 36 feet, police said. The movable office was next to a 10,000-square-foot paper plant, with the whole complex surrounded by a concrete block wall. The large warehouse contained several hundred rolls of toilet paper, but no drugs, said Torrijos. Agents found 5{ tons of marijuana wrapped in 601 plastic packages in one of the underground rooms, said Mario Torrijos Rascon, police group chief in Nogales. Police also seized three shotguns, four automatic weapons, two silencers, two rifles and a radio transmitter, he said. In Mexico City, the attorney general said in a statement that two Agua Prieta men were arrested in the case and an American and another Mexican were being sought. It was unclear, however, whether they were the escaped guards. The underground cache sat on the four-acre Rios Paper Distributing Co. site in Nogales' Casas Palenque neighborhood, a residential and industrial area. Torrijos said investigators were trying to determine who owned the property. An informant's tip led police to the stash, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Officials Say More Oil Missing From Barge
DOC.TEXT: Coast Guard officials said Friday a barge that collided with a tanker in the Houston Ship Channel may have spilled 700,000 gallons, or nearly all of its cargo, into Galveston Bay. The Coast Guard had said earlier that 500,000 gallons of oil spewed into the bay after the accident. But officials considered adjusting that estimate after salvage crews found nothing in a once-submerged cargo tank they expected to contain about 200,000 gallons of oil. ``It looks like a lot of the oil may have escaped from it,'' Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said. Greene said officials were rechecking ship manifests to determine exactly how much oil was aboard the vessel. ``It could be close to 700,000 gallons (spilled), but I'm not willing to say that yet. The total capacity of that barge was 750,000 gallons. They're telling us they had 716,000 gallons actually on board,'' Greene said at a press conference at Eagle Point, a real estate development where oil has washed ashore. The state health department, meanwhile, announced that a ban on fishing in the bay, begun Thursday, would be partially lifted Saturday in several areas apparently unaffected by the oil. The accident occurred a week ago when the Greek tanker Shinoussa collided with two barges in the Houston Ship Channel, causing one barge to nearly sink. Oil from both barges bubbled into the seafood-rich bay, threatening sensitive marshes, birds and other wildlife. The oil has washed ashore on several beaches. The latest was Houston Point, a marshy area north of the leading edge of the 12-mile oil slick, where oil was reported Friday morning. Coast Guard officials say they are perplexed by what appeared to be relatively small amounts of oil spotted on flyovers this week. While part of the oil may have evaporated, Greene said another possibility is that some sank just below the surface. Tests have shown no evidence that the oil has reached the bottom, he said. Cleanup crews continued scooping oil off the surface Friday, while salvage team worked on the damaged barge. Oil-eating microbes were poured into a small marshy area near Pelican Island, adjacent to Galveston Island, on Thursday afternoon. There was no word Friday on whether the microbes were gobbling up the oil as intended. The spill has halted traffic in the Houston Ship Channel for most of the week. Limited traffic was allowed Friday morning after the damaged barge was lifted out of the channel into shallower waters in the bay. ``It was not very far. They just had to get it to a slightly more stable location,'' said Chief Warrant Officer Rick Meidt. One deep-draft ship was allowed out of the channel Friday morning, in part to find out if a large ship's wake would further damage the barge, Meidt said. The ship passed without incident and at least one other ship was permitted to pass through the area. ``We're taking it slow and easy,'' Meidt said. Greene said that for the first time, officials were able to see the damage on the ruptured barge and it is ``extensive.'' After the Shinoussa struck the barge it appears to have plowed into the center of it, he said. ``It's completely bashed in for probably 100 feet,'' Greene said. An investigative hearing into the accident resumed Friday morning in Houston. The second mate of the Shinoussa testified the tanker's pilot was ``racing'' before the accident, and then tried to cover up how fast the ship was traveling. Later, he softened the accusation, saying he had never been told to lie about the tanker's speed. The pilot, Raymond Fincher, has denied speeding through the channel.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Deliberates Barry Verdict After Wild Drug Sting at Hotel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with court session on sting and other matters, Barry comments, subbing 2 grafs for 3rd graf pvs, inserting new grafs 7-8 and adding 7 grafs at end
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in Mayor Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial spent their first full day of deliberations Friday in the relative calm of the U.S. Courthouse after a wild drug sting at their hotel the night before. Like a scene from a movie, there were helicopters, search dogs and an escape car ramming police cruisers. The presiding judge in the Barry case said he was assured by U.S. marshals that ``our jurors were oblivious'' to the sting, but the mayor's lawyer still said he might ask for a mistrial in connection with it. The Barry jury has been secretly staying at the hotel in suburban Maryland for the past 6{ weeks. But reporters covering the drug sting story and its aftermath discovered that the jury was there, raising the possibility it would have to be moved. The jurors, meanwhile, said they would deliberate Saturday in an effort to move toward a verdict as quickly as possible. They began deliberation late Thursday. Barry is charged with 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession counts, including one in connection with a hotel sting in which the FBI videotaped him smoking from a crack cocaine pipe. He also faces three perjury charges and a misdemeanor conspiracy charge. The mayor shrugged off questions about the trial Friday, saying only, ``I feel fantastic.'' He spoke to about 200 teen-agers at a youth forum, then returned to his District Building office for a meeting with top staff members and cabinet officials. It was the first time Barry visited city hall without having to rush back to the federal courthouse since jury selection in his trial began June 4. Thursday night's unconnected drug sting was aimed at Brian Tribble, a former friend of the late University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias who died in June 1986 of cocaine poisoning, authorities said. Peter Gruden, special agent in charge of the federal Drug Enforcement Administration's Washington field office, said he was ``pretty sure that it was not known'' by the DEA that the Barry jury was sequestered at the hotel. Tribble was lured to the hotel to purchase cocaine but as authorities moved in he fled, officials said. An associate was taken into custody and faced arraignment on drug possession charges. Tribble drove off, rammed two police vehicles blocking his escape, drove back to the hotel and fled into a wooded area, said Prince George's County police, who were called in. Police brought in search dogs and helicopters equipped with infrared lights to search the area but Tribble was still free Friday. The District of Columbia Police Department also took part in the sting operation, said Lt. Reginald Smith, who added that information on where the jury was staying ``was only available on a need to know basis.'' The FBI also assisted in the operation. During a brief court session Friday, Barry lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy said he wanted ``a representation on the record'' that the jurors weren't made aware of the sting operation of the night before. Jackson said he was assured they weren't aware of it. Mundy said someone would have had to ask them a question about the sting in order to make the determination that they hadn't been aware of it. ``They may have been aware there was a commotion,'' said Jackson. Mundy was asked later, outside court, whether he might ask for a mistrial because of the incident. ``Yes,'' he said, without elaboration. During the day Friday, the jury asked for complete sets of the 32-page instruction booklet read to them Thursday by U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. Jurors also asked to see a huge magnetic calendar in the courtroom on which the prosecution listed the times Barry was accused of using drugs. Jackson also said he would allow the jury to return piecemeal portions of the verdict, rather than waiting until it reached a conclusion on all 14 charges.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Justice Marshall Hospitalized After Fall
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall was hospitalized for observation Friday after a fall the day before in Chicago, a court spokeswoman said. Marshall, 82, was admitted to the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., where he was listed in stable condition, said Toni House. She said Marshall, who was in Chicago to speak at the annual convention of the American Bar Association, stumbled in the lobby of his hotel Thursday evening. He flew back to Washington Friday ``because he prefers consulting with physicians he knows,'' said House, adding it did not appear he had broken any bones in the fall. She said Marshall does not plan to return to Chicago, where he was scheduled to address a dinner of the ABA's Judicial Administration Division Monday night. Marshall, a staunch liberal on the court, has had several health problems in recent years. He had a heart attack in 1976 and has suffered bouts of pneumonia and bronchitis. He was treated at the National Naval Medical Center in 1987 for a blood clot in his right foot.

DOC.HEAD: A Summer Pattern Of Showers And Thunderstorms
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rains in parts of the nation's midsection, raising river levels and bringing the threat of flooding. A flood warning was posted Friday along Johnson Creek and the north fork of the Guadalupe River above Kerrville, Texas. More than four inches of rain fell overnight and several highways were closed by flooding. There was also locally heavy rain during the night across parts of Kansas. No flooding was reported but precautions were advised because of rapidly rising rivers and streams. Rainshowers and thunderstorms continued during the afternoon Friday, reaching from southeast Nebraska across eastern Kansas, northern Oklahoma, parts of Arkansas, Missouri, southern and central Iowa, and western Illinois. Showers and thunderstorms extended from eastern Wisconsin into Michigan, over northern Mississippi, Louisiana, parts of Texas and Florida. There were scattered showers over south-central New Mexico, central Colorado, north-central Nebraska, north-central South Dakota, eastern North Dakota and northern Minnesota. Rainshowers and thunderstorms also were scattered along the South Carolina coast and from northwestern South Carolina into east-central Georgia. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states Friday morning was 33 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. Portland, Maine set a new record of 90 degrees for the date. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 55 at Arcata and Crescent City, Calif. to 100 at Needles, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Testing And Faked Records Cloud Some Communities' Drinking Water
DOC.TEXT: Drinking water in many small communities violates federal health requirements and in some cases violations are being hidden by improper tests or falsified records, a congressional study concluded Friday. The General Accounting Office said an investigation of compliance to drinking water standards at 75 community water systems in six states showed many local authorities are not complying with the federal requirements. The study also said that efforts by the Environmental Protection Agency to uncover violations and take enforcement actions against the local water officials frequently are ineffective. ``We found that many water systems, particularly smaller systems, are violating requirements for monitoring water quality and meeting drinking water standards,'' Richard Hembra, the GAO's director for environmental issues, told a House Government Operations subcommittee. The Environmental Protection Agency acknowledged problems with getting small community water systems to comply with federal clean water requirements. ``The small communities is where the biggest compliance problems lie'' because of a shortage of money and technical people to operate water systems, testified Lajuana Wilcher, the EPA's assistant administrator for water issues. She also acknowledged that some violations of federal drinking water standards go unreported because of erroneous information from local officials or inadequate monitoring by states. Nevertheless, Ms. Wilcher maintained that said the most serious violations have been resolved and in that available reports showed that 73 percent of the community water systems, serving 183 million people, were complying with federal health standards for drinking water in 1989. According to the GAO report, however, those statistics may overstate compliance nationwide. The GAO study said investigators found that local water officials frequently test water samples incorrectly because employees are not adequately trained to deal with increasingly technical federal regulations. At other times, the GAO report said, samples are deliberately falsified. ``While the extent of this problem is unknown, we found that falsifying data and manipulating test results are relatively easy to accomplish, and ample evidence exists that the practices are occurring,'' Hembra told the House subcommittee on environment, energy and natural resources. The GAO report cited examples where local water officials were told to eliminate bacteria by boiling or microwaving water samples before conducting tests. In other cases employees were told to specifically search for samples that would pass a test, while in yet other cases employees admitted they simply put false information on reports. ``How much credence can you give these (compliance) figures giving the GAO findings?'' Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., chairman of the subcommittee, asked the EPA officials. ``Certainly not 100 percent,'' responded Ms. Wilcher. The GAO report examined water systems in Massachusetts, Vermont, Oklahoma, Texas, Oregon and Washington. It did not identify the individual communities.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Senate Race Ends With Weekend Cliffhanger
Leads with 3 grafs to CORRECT that Brown trailing by 158 votes, sted leading; picks up 4th graf pvs, `Scattered precincts...
DOC.TEXT: A 73-year-old political newcomer said he was thinking of conceding the Republican Senate primary until he learned Friday that the race was closer than he thought. ``I don't have too many fingernails left. I guess I'll have to start chewing my toenails,'' candidate Ralph Brown said. It will be Monday at the earliest before Tennesseans learn who won Thursday's GOP contest between Brown and conservative political economist William Hawkins, who was leading by only 158 votes. Scattered precincts remain uncounted around the state, and in one county _ Madison _ election officials said they wouldn't begin counting statewide races until next week. Madison County officials said their ballot was extremely long, and county races took priority over the Senate race. ``We're going to count it as soon as we can, but we've got every county position except for tax assessor to count first,'' county Registrar Spence Dupree said. With 96 percent of the state's precincts reporting, Hawkins had 50,979 votes to Brown's 50,821. Businessman Patrick Hales trailed with 29,743 votes. The winner will face the Democratic incumbent, Sen. Albert Gore Jr. State Election Coordinator Will Burns said the delays underline the need for a statewide computerized election system. In other races, U.S. Rep. Harold Ford, the state's only black congressman, defeated state Rep. Pam Gaia in a Democratic primary despite the cloud of federal bank fraud charges hanging over his head. Ford, 45, will face Republican Aaron C. Davis, a 79-year-old political newcomer, in the general election. Dwight Henry, a freshman state legislator from Cookeville, beat five opponents in the Republican gubernatorial primary after returning to the race during the last week of the campaign. He will face the incumbent governor, Ned McWherter, who like Gore received a large complimentary vote in an uncontested Democratic primary. Brown, who estimated he had spent about $250 on his Senate primary campaign, said he was told by a television station that Hawkins had won Thursday's election. He said he was considering conceding when he learned at least 33 of 95 uncounted precincts would probably not be tabulated until Monday. Hawkins, a 41-year-old former college professor, said he hadn't expected the race to be so close and thought that some voters who had not paid much attention voted for Brown because he came first on the ballot. ``I wouldn't deny that,'' Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Nations Denounce Iraqi Invasion
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An emergency Arab League Council Friday issued a strongly worded statement, condeming Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and demanding the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops. But a statement issued at the end of the two-day meeting said the Arab League rejected foreign intervention in the crisis. Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid said 14 of the League's 21 members voted for the condemnation, while one member abstained. Sudan, Palestine, Jordan and Yemen voted against it, he said. Libya's representative was not present and Iraq did not have the right to vote, he said. In Iraq, Jordan's King Hussein met with President Sadaam Hussein. The Jordanian leader announced there would be an emergency Arab mini-summit in Saudi Arabia on Sunday to discuss the crisis. Although the United States, the Soviet Union and other Western countries swiftly condemned Iraq and imposed sanctions on that nation, most Arab countries said little or nothing about the invasion until Friday. In its statement, the Arab League denounced the invasion and said it ``rejects and does not recognize anything resulting from it.'' The statement, handed out to reporters at the end of a two-day emergency meeting in Cairo, apparently meant that the League continues to recognize Kuwait's Emir Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah as the country's ruler. ``We condemn the bloodshed and the destruction of buildings and we call on Iraq to immediately and unconditionally withdraw its troops,'' the statement said. It also said the League ``rejects any foreign intervention or attempted intervention in Arab affairs.'' Egypt was the first major Arab country to condemn Thursday's invasion. Egyptian government officials said neither President Hosni Mubarak nor other Arab leaders believed Iraq's claim that it intervened to help Kuwaiti revolutionaries. But they said the Arab leaders initially held back criticism in hopes of containing the crisis and preserving Arab unity. ``First, we demand that Iraq withdraw its forces from Kuwaiti territories. Second, Iraq must stop trying to change the government in Kuwait by force and leave such internal issues to Kuwaiti people to decide by their own free will,'' said the Egyptian Foreign Ministry statement on Friday. Egypt also called for the two countries to negotiate their differences. The statement said the invasion could have ``dangerous repercussions'' in the region but did not elaborate. Another group of Arab nations that includes Saudi Arabia later issued a similar condemnation. The group, the Gulf Cooperation Council, also includes Qatar, Oman, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait. ``We strongly condemn and are very sorry for this attack that one Arab state took against another Arab state,'' the group's statement said after its representatives met in Cairo. Several hundred Kuwaitis, stranded in Cairo by the invasion, gathered in the lobby of the downtown Semiramis hotel where the Arab League Council met. The Kuwaitis urged the Arab representatives to help their country and carried pictures of the emir. He is believed to have fled to Saudi Arabia. Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat and Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi met in Libya to discuss the crisis, the Libyan News Agency reported. The agency said they decided Arafat would fly to Iraq in an effort to settle the dispute. Also in Cairo, the Middle East News Agency quoted Iran's chief delegate to the Organization of Islamic Conference, Hojatoleslam Mohammad Ali Taskhiri, as condemning the Iraqi attack. He reportedly said his country still recognizes the emir's government. Iran and Iraq fought an 8-year war that ended in a cease-fire in 1988, but they have not yet negotiated a long-term settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Man Comes Out Of Retirement To Earn Yale Degree At 85
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The time off that Daniel Wynkoop took after his junior year at Yale stretched to nearly 65 years. But finally, at age 85, he's no longer a college dropout. At the start of Wynkoop's senior year, he was forced to leave the school because he had gotten married over the summer _ the summer of 1925. He could have returned the next year as a married student, but ended up waiting more than 60 years to complete the seven credits he needed for a Yale degree. ``I finally had the time and the money. I asked my brother (a 1928 Yale graduate) what I ought to do with it, and he said, `Why don't you finish school.' So I did,'' said Wynkoop, a retired encyclopedia salesman who lives in St. Petersburg, Fla. His three years at Yale qualified him as an alumnus, and he attended reunions over the years with other Old Blues from the Class of 1926. But Wynkoop wanted a degree. So he signed up for Yale summer school, completing five courses over three summers, and was credited for a Spanish class he took at St. Petersburg (Fla.) Junior College. A widower who was married three times, Wynkoop plans to participate in graduation ceremonies next May with the Class of 1991. He has nine children and 25 grandchildren. Wynkoop, who checked out Friday from his dormitory at Calhoun College, one of Yale's residential colleges, said he kept his nose in the books during his second life at Yale. ``I had a nice couple of guys who said, `Do you want to go get a couple of beers. I said, `No, I've been on the wagon since I came here and I'll stay that way.'' He broke the rule once, when a Yale administrator invited him to lunch at Mory's, the storied Yale dining club. Most of the more than 1,000 students enrolled in Yale's Summer and Special Programs are in the teens and early 20s. Wynkoop also had to adjust to women students, who were first admitted in 1969. ``You know, those girls are not bad looking,'' he said, adding that they would have distracted him his first time around. Wynkoop, who majored in English, took courses this summer on detective stories and on radicalism since the 1960s, which was difficult because ``that's a subject with which I have very little sympathy.'' An earlier philosophy course was his favorite. ``I had a peculiar position in the class,'' he said. ``Because of my age, I had a different point of view on moral questions.'' Wynkoop said he feels sorry for people who ask him why he bothered going back to school. ``If they don't know, you can't tell them,'' he said. ``It's because I want to drink deeper of the cup of life.''

DOC.HEAD: Lightning Hits Pond, Kills Mother, Daughter
DOC.TEXT: A mother and daughter died and another child was hurled into the water when lightning apparently struck a pond and traveled up their fishing lines, authorities said. The surviving child, the woman's 11-year-old niece, was found wandering unharmed Wednesday along a street near Palm Beach International Airport. The small pond is near the airport. ``The child doesn't remember anything, except crawling out of the water,'' said Larry Easton, a county sheriff's detective. Barbara Buchanan, 31, of West Palm Beach, and her daughter, Michelle, were found dead Wednesday night, he said. There were no burn marks on the victims' bodies, leading deputies to believe lightning struck the water, traveled to shore and electrocuted them, said sheriff's Lt. Marvin Lewis. Deputies cannot explain why the niece survived. Her name was not released. A heavy thunderstorm struck the area Wednesday evening. Deputies said the victims may have sought refuge under pine trees by the pond. One fishing line still dangled in the water when firefighters arrived.

DOC.HEAD: Rhode Island Senator Stumbles in First Debate With Opponent
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Claiborne Pell, a 30-year Senate veteran, and his election opponent faced off in their first televised forum, with the incumbent Democrat suffering what he later described as a self-inflicted wound. Appearing Wednesday on WJAR-TV with Rep. Claudine Schneider, R-R.I., Pell hesitated when asked to identify the last legislation he personally pushed that directly benefited Rhode Islanders. ``I couldn't give you a specific answer,'' he said. ``My memory's not as good as it should be.'' The station later reported that Pell explained he had been trying to think of a bill that would affect only Rhode Island. Miss Schneider was asked to name the last bill that ``you've sponsored and were the prime mover on that directly benefits Rhode Island in some way.'' The 10-year congresswoman had a quick answer: a bill regulating and eventually banning garbage dumping at sea. ``My bill later became the committee bill,'' she said. But she acknowledged she was not the ``prime mover'' of the bill. And the version she first sponsored was changed, in ways she opposed, before it emerged from her ocean-related committee. ``In the House of Representatives, working with 434 other people, there are no bills that have my name on them, because that's just the way the system works,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Shiite Prisoners In Kuwait, Linked to Hostages, Are Free
DOC.TEXT: ABC News reported Friday that all of the 17 Shiite Moslems imprisoned for terrorism in Kuwait are now free following the Iraqi invasion. Islamic Jihad, a Moslem group holding Western hostages in Lebanon, has set the release of the 17 as a condition for freeing its hostages. Two of the 17 had already been released after serving five-year terms. In a report on ABC's World News Tonight, anchor Peter Jennings said ``ABC's Pierre Salinger reports that as of tonight they are all free.'' ``Does this affect the fate of the American hostages? We don't even know who freed the Kuwait prisoners,'' Jennings said. The report did not elaborate. Iraqi troops moved into Kuwait on Thursday. They are believed to control almost all of Kuwait, and it was not clear from the ABC report whether the imprisoned Moslems were now free of any restrictions the Iraqis might impose. Kuwait had identified the prisoners as members of the pro-Iranian Dawa party, an Iraqi group seeking to overthrow the government of President Saddam Hussein. They were jailed for the bombings of the U.S. and French embassies in Kuwait on Dec. 12, 1983, which killed five people and wounded 86. In Washington, John Dixon, a spokesman for the State Department task force on the Iraq-Kuwait conflict, said the department was aware of the ABC report but didn't know if the prisoners were free. Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, says it holds Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985, and Thomas Sutherland, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, abducted June 9 of that year. Anderson has been held the longest of all Western hostages. Of the 15 prisoners believed held by Kuwait before the invasion, three were under sentence of death. The others were serving sentences ranging from 10 years to life in prison. Kuwait had refused to free any of of the prisoners.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: In 14th graf: ``Similarly, banks,'' text of statement reads ``subject to the jurisdiction in the United States.'' Spokesmen not available for clarification
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department said Friday night the U.S. ban of Iraqi oil imports also covers Kuwaiti oil, now controlled by Iraq. A Treasury statement said oil from both Iraq and Kuwait loaded before President Bush's trade embargo against Iraq took effect may be delivered in the United States. Also, Kuwaiti firms may use their blocked bank accounts, Treasury said. Without elaborating on the inclusion of Kuwait, a Treasury statement said ``importation of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil will be permitted'' where: _The cargoes were loaded before 5:01 a.m. EDT Thursday (12:01 p.m. Kuwait time), the effective time of Bush's import ban. _Are landed before 11:59 p.m. EDT Oct. 1. _The bill of lading was issued before Thursday's cutoff hour. _Remaining payments are reported to Treasury and made into a bank account frozen by Bush's order. At least two cargoes of Iraqi oil could be affected by Treasury's announcement. In Corpus Christi, Texas, the Customs Service impounded a 479,000-barrel cargo that arrived Thursday for a Coastal Corp. refinery. Another tanker was in international waters off Port Arthur, Texas, unable to complete its journey to a Fina Corp. refinery. A similar exemption was made for cargoes in transit when a trade embargo was imposed against Iran in 1979. Treasury spokesmen did not immediately answer their office telephones. White House spokesman Doug Davidson said Bush had not amended his executive order to cover Kuwait but had left implementation of it and decisions on what is covered to Treasury. ``I would defer to Treasury on this,'' he said. U.S. banks will be permitted to pay checks and accept deposits in blocked accounts controlled by Kuwaiti firms ``provided that no benefit to the government of Iraq arises from transactions in the blocked accounts,'' the statement said. Those firms will be required to register with Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control, and the banks will be required to verify the registration. On similar conditions, banks and investment companies managing Kuwaiti-owned securities will be permitted to buy and sell and re-invest the proceeds ``in assets subject to the jurisdiction in (of) the United States,'' and foreign exchange deals for the government of Kuwait begun before the cutoff hour may be completed.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors of Destroyed Ship Arrive in Maine
DOC.TEXT: Soviet rescuers on Friday brought ashore 21 survivors of the wreck of a cargo ship, and the saved sailors said they felt ``very lucky'' to have lived through Hurricane Bertha. The Corazon broke into pieces Tuesday in the Atlantic Ocean about 400 miles east of New York. Six of its crew died, and three of the bodies were left at sea, said Elizabeth Brannan, a Coast Guard spokeswoman from Boston. The Soviet captain said his crew fought 30-foot waves and heavy winds to save the stricken sailors. ``What made the whole operation complicated was the wind and the height of the waves, as well as the rainstorms, very little visibility,'' said Vladimir Pushnoy, captain of the of the M-V Leonid Leonidov. Crew members from the Corazon wore yellow vests that were hard to see in the foamy water, Pushnoy said at a news conference Friday. After the rusty Soviet fishing boat docked in Portland Harbor Friday afternoon, the Corazon's survivors, many of them from Greece and the Philippines, stood on the deck and told their story to reporters. ``We are very lucky,'' said Pantelis Potiris, of Greece, the Corazon's cook. ``It was very bad, very rough.'' One survivor gave a thumbs up sign and said ``the Russians are good.'' An apprentice officer, Rolando Arellano, of Manila, Philippines, said he spent four to six hours floating in the water after his life raft capsized. One of his countrymen died trying to get off the Corazon, he said. ``When I jumped in the life raft, I found one Filipino floating,'' Arellano said. ``He hit the ship's hull.'' The dead included a first officer, a second officer, an assistant officer and a radio man aboard the ship. ``I hope only to stay alive,'' Arellano said. ``I always pray to God. We are thinking of our family and to save ourselves.'' Arellano said he would return to the sea because it is the only life he knows. After the Corazon sent out a distress signal Tuesday afternoon, the U.S. and Canadian coast guards helped Leonid Leonidov and other ships find the survivors. Two other ships in the area got close to Corazon crew members, but couldn't get them aboard. Pushnoy said his fishing support ship was able to pull off the rescue because his 46-member crew is used to working in open sea and tying up with other vessels. The last man rescued had been in the water 10 hours, he said. The Leonid Leonidov had been headed for the Gulf of Maine to pick up fish being processed by another Soviet vessel, the Riga, which is spending the summer off the Maine coast. The Corazon, a 593-foot freighter that was registered in Malta, had been carrying tons of cement from Greece to New York.

DOC.HEAD: British Prime Minister Says `Star Wars' Helped Change World
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT that area is a test site, sted headquarters for Star Wars; SUBS 6th graf, `The SDI ..., to conform.
DOC.TEXT: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, touring a Star Wars test site during an outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, said Friday the project had helped force sweeping changes in the Soviet Union. Despite the thaw in superpower relations that some claim has rendered the multibillion dollar Strategic Defense Initiative irrelevant, Mrs. Thatcher said Iraq's invasion of Kuwait proved the importance of a strong military. ``There will always be evil in human nature, and we never know where it will come from,'' she said. ``We must always keep our technology sharp.'' Thatcher said SDI had forced Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to realize his army could not keep up with the United States without draining the country's resources, she said. ``I believe it convinced the Soviet Union they can never achieve their aim by military might because they knew they could never succeed,'' she said. The SDI site, known as the National Test Bed, is developing military space-based technology in the United States. Projects under way would use lasers to shoot down enemy missiles in space and incoming nuclear warheads. Thatcher told about 1,000 SDI workers she was amazed how far the project had come since its inception in 1984 during the Reagan administration. Among British contributions to the SDI program are filters that can block Soviet attempts to jam military satellites with laser beams and a neutron generator that can determine the payloads of military missiles. Thatcher watched a display the ``Brilliant Pebbles'' project, one of the most successful developments in the Star Wars arsenal. The device fires rockets at incoming warheads. Star Wars, criticized from the start by some who say it is unworkable, is under increasing scrutiny because of U.S. budget constraints and warming superpower relations. Thatcher later toured Cheyenne Mountain, headquarters for NORAD, which tracks Soviet Missiles, airplanes and submarines world wide. She also visited the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, where scientists are studying global warming, an issue that has been of special concern to Thatcher, who was trained as a chemist.

DOC.HEAD: VOA Signals Jammed In Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Iraq jammed short-wave radio broadcasts from Voice of America on Friday, the agency's director said. Two of the six frequencies carrying Arabic-language broadcasts to the Middle East were jammed at 5 p.m. EDT (Midnight in Kuwait), said Richard Carlson, director of the U.S. government's overseas radio broadcasting. The jamming signal, which sounds like someone blowing bubbles, has electronic characteristics indicating it is Iraqi, Carlson said. The two jammed frequencies are broadcast from West Germany and the island of Rhodes off the southwestern coast of Turkey and are the most powerful frequencies beamed to the area, he said. Weaker Arabic signals and English-language broadcasts were not affected, he said. However, ``The BBC has had indications they're being interfered with as well,'' he said. Carlson said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was ``trying to keep his neighbors and his own people from knowing what is going on.'' He said he did not know how much of the signal was getting through to neighboring countries in the region. Iraq has not jammed VOA signals before, Carlson said. The only other country now jamming VOA is China, he said.

DOC.HEAD: US Embargo Unlikely to Cripple Iraq Without International Help
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf 11 ``Later, though,'' Treasury lumping Kuwaiti oil with Iraqi
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's cutoff of Iraqi oil imports is costing Iraq its No. 1 customer, but the sanction is unlikely to take a lasting toll on Baghdad unless Japan and other major oil importing countries join the embargo. Anything short of a concerted buyer boycott by the oil importing nations would be little more than a temporary inconvenience for Iraq. A solo American boycott would leave Iraq free to sell U.S.-bound oil to Japan or another customer, although it might be forced to take a slightly lower price in order to move the oil quickly in a glutted world market. But the inconvenience could be felt as much by American oil companies as by the Iraqi government. The embargo announced by Bush Thursday following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait bars the import of Iraqi oil, but it apparently does not stop American oil companies from continuing to buy Iraqi oil and ship it to their non-American affiliates, or simply swapping it on the world market. Among the major U.S. oil companies that buy Iraqi oil, Exxon Corp., for example, could divert its Iraqi purchases to its Western European affiliates for refining.
