The United States, among the dozens of countries which condemned Iraq's takeover of Kuwait, on Friday was the only nation to have barred imports of Iraqi oil, although European governments were reported to be considering boycotts. Japan's Kyodo News Service reported Tokyo also was contemplating a ban. Bush acknowledged the difficulty of making his sanctions work. ``I don't say they would work but we are putting them on there,'' he told reporters before leaving the White House for a weekend at his Camp David, Md. retreat. A Bush administration source said officials were considering expanding the American action to include Kuwaiti oil, since it now is under Iraqi control. The source, involved in round-the-clock monitoring of the Persian Gulf crisis, discussed the administration's thinking on condition he not be identified. Later, though, the Tresury Department issued a statement exempting oil in transit from both Kuwait and Iran from the president's embargo, thus including Kuwait. A White House spokesman said the president had not amended his order, and was leaving it up to Treasury as to precisely what was covered Of Kuwait's 1.8 million barrels a day of oil exports, about 120,000 barrels a day are bought by the United States. The rest goes to Western Europe and the Far East. Kuwaiti oil expors ground to a halt shortly after the invasion, although the Bush administration source said it appeared all Kuwaiti oil facilities had escaped war damage. The U.S. market is more important to Iraq than is Iraqi oil to America. The United States buys about 25 percent of Iraq's oil exports, making it Baghdad's No. 1 customer. U.S. purchases from Iraq have soared in recent years, jumping from about 100,000 barrels a day in 1987 to about 600,000 a day last month. Even so, the Iraqi oil represents only about 3.5 percent of total American oil consumption and about 7.6 percent of U.S. imports, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Although an international boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil would seriously damage Baghdad's economy and set back its efforts to rebuild following its costly 1980-88 war with Iran, the sanctions may also carry a price for the rest of the world. The approximately 4.5 million barrels a day of combined Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil exports, if removed from the world market, would leave at least a temporary shortfall in global supplies that almost certainly would drive up consumer prices. Henson Moore, the deputy secretary of energy, told reporters Thursday evening that the administration was not worried about a potential price rise resulting from a global boycott against Iraq. ``Should the oil from Iraq and Kuwait go off the market _ not be sold to anybody _ there is enough excess (oil production) capacity in the world to offset that loss,'' Moore said. It seems unlikely, however, that the countries with the most unused production capacity _ mostly gulf Arab nations, including Saudi Arabia _ would risk antagonizing Iraq by helping shield the United States from a price increase.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Iraqi Oil Seized, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0772,0459
DOC.HEAD: Federal Officials Seize Iraqi Oil, Goods At Texas Ports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Treasury announcing exceptions; picks up 8th graf pvs, `Fina has..
DOC.TEXT: Customs agents seized 479,000 barrels of Iraqi crude oil from one tanker and blocked another offshore, but both cargos apparently will be released since they were bought before an embargo was announced. The Treasury Department said Friday that oil loaded before President Bush announced a trade embargo Thursday against Iraq and Kuwait may be delivered. Treasury spokesmen were not available to comment on specifics, but the exception appeared to cover both the cargoes seized in Texas. The Customs Service, along with the U.S. Coast Guard, seized the oil at the Port of Corpus Christi on Thursday afternoon, hours after President Bush's embargo went into effect at 5 a.m. The oil was being unloaded from the Hellespont Dignity, sailing under a Swedish flag, at a Coastal Corp. refinery facility, said Patricia McCauley, district Customs director in Houston.The cargo had been unloaded at sea from a Norwegian mother ship, the Berge Banker. That ship remained in the Gulf of Mexico outside U.S. territorial waters, Ms. McCauley said. Another tanker, destined for a Fina Oil and Chemical Co. refinery in Port Arthur, was halted offshore. A Customs spokeswoman was unable to provide the name of that ship, its owners or its registry. Fina was trying to persuade the government to let the company take delivery, spokesman Rick Hagar said from the company's Dallas headquarters Friday. Past embargoes affected only new shipments made after the prohibitions took effect, he said. ``Crude oil that was on the water, already paid for, already bought, was permitted into the United States. That's what we're asking for in this case,'' he said. The Treasury announcement appeared to be an answer to Fina's request. The Treasury statement said importation of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil would be permitted if the cargoes were loaded before Thursday and landed by Oct. 1. Fina has refineries in Big Spring and Port Arthur and a terminal in Corpus Christi. President Bush issued the embargo after Iraq invaded Kuwait Thursday. The embargo covers Iraqi vessels and goods as well as ships flying Iraqi or Kuwaiti flags. The order also prohibits dealings between U.S. and Iraqi companies. In the past three months there have been 50 shipments of Iraqi oil arriving in Houston, Ms. McCauley said. Some Iraqi goods in the Port of Houston also have been detained, Ms. McCauley said. she did not elaborate. But very little ship traffic is moving in or out of Houston because of an oil spill cleanup in Galveston Bay.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Hears U.S. Proposal For Sanctions on Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs, to UPDATE with U.S. briefing, U.S. to push for sanctions despite Iraqi announcement. Pickup 17th, `Security Council...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States asked the U.N. Security Council on Friday to impose sweeping military, trade and economic sanctions on Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait. U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering said the members of the 15-nation council expressed strong interest in applying comprehensive mandatory sanctions. If approved, it would be the first time since 1967 that the Security Council imposed such wide-ranging sanctions _ from arms to trade _ upon a state. It was not known if the entire council was ready to approve such penalties. ``I detect strong interest in sanctions ... and we will be moving rapidly to discussion of a text ... A resolution could be passed in 24 hours,'' Pickering said after council consultations. ``We want to put teeth into the Security Council's demand Thursday that Iraq withdraw its troops from Kuwait,'' Pickering said. The Council on Thursday condemned the invasion, demanded Iraq's immediate and unconditional withdrawal, and called for urgent negotiations between Iraq and Kuwait to resolve their differences. A U.S. government official, who later briefed reporters on condition of anonymity, said the White House would press for sanctions despite Iraq's announcement late Friday its soldiers would begin leaving Kuwait on Sunday. He expressed skepticism about Iraq's announcement that it would start a troop pullout. Consultations continued with the Security Council and other nations in an effort to reach consensus on a resolution imposing sanctions. The measures would be designed to punish Iraq and to force it to withdraw completely and without conditions. The official said Washington may call for an emergency council meeting this weekend, but said differences existed. Pickering told reporters that sanction efforts were not incompatible with Arab League peace moves and that sanctions would reinforce other settlement efforts. He said the United States proposed far-reaching, detailed economic, financial and military sanctions _ ``anything you can think of'' _ including an embargo on sales of arms, military equipment, supplies and training. The U.S. official told the briefing that proposed sanctions probably would cover pipeline exports of Iraqi oil by Saudi Arabia and Turkey; removal of advisers and technicians from Iraq, and severing of commercial airline links. He said a U.S. draft does not mention freezing Iraqi or Kuwaiti assets abroad. Asked about Iraq's statement that Kuwait's royal family should not return, the official said Iraq should leave Kuwait ``whole, free, sovereign, intact and its government returned.'' He said sanctions would be lifted if Iraq withdraws and the status quo is restored. Pickering told reporters, ``Our (U.S.) view is that we should move rapidly to sanctions if Iraq doesn't show _ and it hasn't _ signs of compliance.'' . The U.S. envoy said one or two members, not identified, had reservations. Diplomats said China and Yemen, an Arab state, were not supportive. China, as a permanent member, could veto the measure. The Security Council rarely imposes sanctions, but improved U.S.-Soviet relations make them a possibility. The five permanent members with veto power are the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union. Ambassadors of the five have been consulting informally on strategy to end the crisis. The Soviet Union was expected to concur, since Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Friday issued a joint demand in Moscow for an arms embargo against Iraq. Security Council resolutions are considered legally binding upon its members, although they often are flouted. The U.N. Charter provides that the Security Council may call upon members to impose sanctions, including economic sanctions and interruption of travel and communications and severing diplomatic relations. In extreme cases, the council may employ blockades and military operations by the air, sea or land forces of U.N. members. It was believed only the fifth time in the council's 45 years that it has issued such a threat of sanctions. The most recent case was the council action demanding a cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war in 1987. Earlier times led to arms embargos against formerly white-run Rhodesia in 1967 and South Africa in 1977. There was also a warning about sanctions in the first Arab-Israeli war in 1948. The last U.N. embargo came in 1967 on Rhodesia. It was lifted in 1979, as the former British colony prepared for independence and majority rule as Zimbabwe.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Governor Says Scrutiny of Blacks Not Racism
DOC.TEXT: Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder said Friday that negative media focus on the private lives of black politicians does not mean there is a white conspiracy against leading blacks. Recent stories, including those on the drug trial of Washington, D.C., Mayor Marion Barry, only leave that impression, Wilder said. Wilder himself has been the focus of stories saying he has used a state helicopter to spend weekends with socialite Patricia Kluge. ``If I thought that there was a conspiracy, I couldn't exist,'' Wilder said. ``I couldn't have existed in the courtroom where being an African-American lawyer I was asking for justice from a jury that was all white and judges who were all white, but I found justice.'' During his first six months in office, the nation's first black elected governor has come under criticism for his busy travel schedule and recently for his friendship with Mrs. Kluge, estranged wife of America's richest man, John Kluge. The governor last winter appointed Mrs. Kluge, a former nude model and high school dropout, to the board of visitors of the University of Virginia. Wilder made his remarks at a news conference following a speech to about 2,000 black journalists. The National Association of Black Journalists is holding its annual convention at the Century Plaza Hotel through Sunday. Wilder called for journalists to go beyond problems of the black community and focus on problems that blacks and whites have in common. ``We do the public a disservice _ we limit our perspective _ if we think of ourselves as `black' officials or as `black' journalists,'' he said. Problems like the savings and loan bailout, that will cost an estimated $1.4 trillion, affect everyone, he said. ``Think of the inner city schools that could have been helped with that money. Think of the prenatal health care, the resources for the fight against drugs ... all lost forever,'' he said. Wilder called for blacks to unite and not to be pitted against one another. He urged the journalists to bring good news of the black community to the rest of the world. ``You and I know that there is a great deal of good in our communities which goes unnoticed and unappreciated, simply because the public is not made aware of it,'' he said. A study released at the beginning of the convention implies that black journalists' influence is limited by their numbers. The study released at the conference by the American Society of Newspaper Editors found that only 4 percent of reporters, editors, artists and photographers in 1990 are minorities, said Denise Johnson, vice president of the black journalists' association. The report also said that 4 percent of newspapers across the United States employ only whites. Blacks make up about 12.3 percent of the population. ``America is browner and tanner and is going to continue to be in the future and the industry must reflect that perspective and diverse view of the world through the people it hires,'' Johnson said. ``Most institutions in this country are still pretty much dominated by white middle-age males and I think the tendency on their part is to look out over the staff of people they direct and take under their wing a person who reminds them of themselves,'' Johnson said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede SAN SALVADOR
Police Say Reports of Salvadoran Massacre a Hoax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with massacre story called hoax. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Witnesses and military officials branded as a hoax on Friday reports that gunmen dragged 11 peasants from two families from their homes and killed them in northeastern Morazan province. Reporters arriving in the Morazan town of Cacoapera talked with several of the people supposedly killed, or with their relatives. ``There were no such assassinations,'' said Col. Oscar Leon Linares at military headquarters in the provincial capital of San Francisco Gotera. He said a woman traveled 10 miles from Cacoapera and told authorities that six people were killed, then told a radio station 11 had died. At least one newspaper and several radio stations carried the report Friday. The military also began an investigation based on the report of the woman. Residents later described the woman as mentally disturbed. Morazan province is hotly contested between government forces and guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. A 10-year-old civil war has killed about 72,000 people, most of them civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Warns Iraq: Stay Out of Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: President Bush warned Iraq on Friday not to tamper with U.S. ``vital interests'' by trying to add oil-rich Saudi Arabia to its conquest of Kuwait. He said the United States was willing ``to help in any way we possibly can'' to stop Iraqi aggression. The White House said all options, including military force, were under consideration. The State Department said Iraqi troops, hardened by eight years of war with Iran, were positioned 5 miles to 10 miles from the Saudi border, and spokesman Richard Boucher said, ``Their presence there clearly raises significant concern.'' The United States buys 1.2 million barrels of oil a day from Saudi Arabia, or about one-sixth of all American oil imports. Bush said there is a short-term surplus of crude oil but that ``long-run economic effects on the free world could be devastating'' if supplies are curtailed. ``When you look at vital interests of the United States, the relationship with Saudi Arabia and its independence and its freedom come under the heading of very, very important,'' Bush said. ``If they ask for specific help, it depends on what it is, but I'd be inclined to help in any way we possibly can,'' the president told reporters as he left the White House for a weekend at Camp David. At the United Nations, the U.S. delegate to the Security Council proposed a sweeping program of international sanctions, described by one official as ``anything you can think of.'' An Iraqi government spokesman was reported by Baghdad Radio as saying his nation's troops would begin withdrawing from Kuwait on Sunday. But the broadcast also said the Al-Sabah royal family that has ruled Kuwait for almost 250 years would never return to power. The White House appeared skeptical. ``We need to wait and see. There are many questions associated with it,'' said presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``We asked for immediate and unconditional withdrawal. If there are strings, we need to see what they are.'' Iraq said it sent its troops into Kuwait Thursday merely to provide security for a provisional government _ a contention dismissed in Washington and other Western capitals. A senior U.S. official aboard the plane of Secretary of State James A. Baker III, speaking to reporters on condition that his name not be used on the return from Moscow, said the invasion came despite warnings from the United States against it. ``There was a general warning ... at several different levels, including very high levels,'' the official said. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia ``would call for a direct military response by the United States, Western Europe, maybe even the Soviet Union. This would be an action that could not be ignored.'' House Armed Service Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., said bluntly, ``I think it means war'' if Iraq expands its invasion. ``I say that not as a threat but as a prediction. The world cannot sit back and watch a person like (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein take over half of the oil reserves in the world.'' Bush said he viewed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the threat to other Persian Gulf countries ``as a matter of grave concern to this country and internationally as well. What Iraq has done violates every norm of international law.'' Asked what the United States would do if Iraq invades Saudi Arabia, the president said, ``I'm not discussing options but I would simply say the status quo is unacceptable and further expansion would be even more unacceptable.'' The Pentagon said a third U.S. aircraft carrier was being readied to head to the Mideast to bolster U.S. forces already scattered outside the Persian Gulf region. Officials said the USS Saratoga would relieve the USS Eisenhower, which was deployed in the Mideast in March. The aircraft carrier Independence already is headed from the Indian Ocean toward the Persian Gulf to strengthen the eight-ship U.S. Navy presence already there. Military sources said the Independence was ``several days'' from reaching a staging area outside gulf waters. Pentagon sources said it would be difficult for the United States to parry Iraq's drive with a major assault of troops. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met with Bush at the White House, and the president was given ``a spectrum of options'' for military action including offering war-fighting hardware to Kuwait's neighbors as well as more aggressive moves such as a naval blockade or tactical air strikes on Iraq, Pentagon sources said. With tensions rising, the State Department advised the 3,000 Americans in Kuwait and the 500 in Iraq to leave as quickly as possible. In Kuwait, however, airports and ports were closed. Iraq also began jamming short-wave radio broadcasts from the Voice of America on Friday, the agency said. The administration said 14 Americans were known missing and believed to be in Iraqi hands. The United States demanded that they be accounted for and freed, Fitzwater said. The Americans are oil workers who were taken from three different oil fields near the Iraqi-Kuwait border, Boucher said. Fitzwater said the United States could not confirm reports that Americans were being rounded up or held in various places. He said Iraqi troops have been stationed around the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait ``but they have not gone inside. There is no indication they intend to do that.'' In the early hours of the invasion, which began before dawn Thursday, Iraqi officials promised U.S. Embassy officials in Baghdad that Americans would not be harmed, Boucher said. ``We reminded them of their commitment to safeguard the safety of Americans,'' he said. In an unprecedented step, the United States and Soviet Union jointly demanded that all countries cut off arms supplies to Iraq. The statement was issued in Moscow by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze after a hastily scheduled meeting. Shevardnadze, whose country has been Iraq's biggest arms supplier, predicted that Baghdad soon would withdraw from Kuwait. Fitzwater said ``the actions of Iraq at this point indicate a ruthlessness and disregard for international law that must make us concerned about all the other countries in the region and their security.'' NATO sources in Brussels said the United States alerted Western allies that it was prepared to respond should Iraqi troops push beyond Kuwaiti territory. ``We have told them that we don't rule out any military option and that everything is under consideration,'' Fitzwater said. ``We are considering all options.'' Bush spent 75 minutes with top advisers reviewing intelligence on the Middle East and the progress in implementing economic sanctions against Iraq, Fitzwater said. Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United States, Prince Bandar, met at the White House with Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser. Bush said he talked by telephone with Turkish President Turgut Ozal, whose country is a conduit for much of the oil flowing out of Iraq. Bush said that he and Ozal ``look at this matter with the same sense or urgency and concern.'' Bush declined to say whether Ozal had made a commitment to shut down the Iraqi pipeline but did say, ``That will be an option, I'm certain.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Call For Deeper Troop Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf 6: ``Late Friday,'' with agreement to debate SDI on Saturday. Though the Senate is debating less controversial amendments, following should stand for AMs. Please note the numbering sequence: a0775, slugged 3rd Ld, was advised by a0776 to have been a 2nd Ld, but then was followed by a0798 4th Ld. Thus there is no 3rd Ld.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate rebuffed an attempt Friday to cut nearly four times as many U.S. troops from the U.S. military as President Bush proposed to cut in his 1991 military budget. Despite arguments that the Cold War has ended and the United States faces severe money problems, the Senate rejected an amendment to cut 130,000 troops, including 80,000 in Europe. The vote was 59-40. In proposing a $307 billion defense bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, Bush called for about 40,000 troops to be cut overall. The Senate Armed Services Committee adopted a $289 billion military budget last month that would cut troop strength by 100,000, including 50,000 in Europe. The chairman of the Senate Armed Services panel, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., warned that a deeper cut in the nation's 2.1 million military personnel than the total adopted by his committee would force the Pentagon to ``send out the pink slips.'' In a speech on Thursday, Bush called for a 25 percent reduction in troop strength over five years _ about 500,000 through 1995 _ but cautioned against drastic reductions in the nation's mlitary. Late Friday, the Senate agreed to consider five amendments on the Strategic Defense Initiative on Saturday in hopes of completing the legislation and adjourning for the summer recess. On other issues on the defense agenda, the Senate: _The Senate rejected, 54-43, an amendment imposing a one-year moratorium on closing or realigning military bases on the list Defense Secretary Dick Cheney proposed in January unless Congress decides otherwise. Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., angrily cited statistics from a Democratic study showing that 99 percent of the 44,000 civilian jobs that would be lost from Cheney's January list of potential base closings were in Democratic congressional districts. ``You don't have to be a rocket scientist to know this didn't happen by coincidence,'' Bumpers said of what he perceived as a partisan list from Republican Cheney. But Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking GOP member on the Armed Services panel, argued that Cheney has tried to ``defend his action in cutting back military personnel and now we're about to handcuff'' him. _Rejected an amendment to increase the pay raise for military personnel included in the 1991 defense bill from 3.5 percent to 4.1 percent. The measure failed, 67-32. _Approved by voice vote a measure providing $5 million to Washington, Oregon and Idaho for the creation of a registry to monitor and notify individuals of the potential adverse effects of radiation released from the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Hanford, Wash., from 1944 to 1972. Approval of the measure came in the midst of a flurry of activity on the Senate floor in which 17 amendments were briefly described and adopted by voice vote in a mere 21 minutes. _Rejected, 52-45, an amendment to freeze funds for the Army's kinetic energy anti-satellite rocket program at this year's $74 million. In the new budget, Bush proposed a 181 percent increase to $208 million for the program. _Turned down an attempt to mothball three of the Navy's four battleships, one more than Bush has proposed in his fiscal 1991 budget and the total adopted by the House Armed Services Committee in its $283 billion defense bill. The vote was 55-44. Lawmakers have questioned the necessity of maintaining the 1940-vintage vessels, especially since the gun turret explosion last year aboard the USS Iowa that killed 47 sailors. Cheney has proposed retiring the USS Iowa and the USS New Jersey. Bumpers proposed adding either the USS Missouri or the USS Wisconsin to the list. Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., a former Navy pilot, said he doesn't have to ``make the case for the battleship. Saddam Hussein has made the case for the battleship,'' referring to the Iraqi leader who engineered the invasion of Kuwait. Bumpers responded, ``Where are the four battleships we have? Are they steaming to the Persian Gulf?'' Nunn complained that the Navy had promised a ``new and innovative'' use for the battleships when they were taken out of mothballs several years ago. ``We've wasted an enormous amount of money with four and now we're left with two and no innovative way to use them,'' Nunn said. ``The best solution is to cut one battleship.'' In rushing to complete work on the defense bill before the summer recess, the Senate also sidestepped a potentially volatile fight by setting aside an amendment to allow abortions in military hospitals for personnel and their dependents willing to pay for the procedure. Sen. Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., chief sponsor of the provision, withdrew his amendment after the Senate fell two votes short of limiting debate.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea, Soviets Meet on Normalizing Relations
DOC.TEXT: South Korean and Soviet officials held their first formal talks Thursday aimed at normalizing relations, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said. He told a regular news briefing the 20-member delegation from Seoul was to discuss investment, joint business ventures and better economic and technical cooperation. The Korean envoys will spend up to three days talking to ministries and visiting Soviet businesses, cultural centers and scientific establishments. South Korea and the Soviet Union agreed to limited consular relations in December. Moscow has been a close ally of Communist North Korea. Officials in Seoul have said the two countries may be able to establish diplomatic relations and exchange ambassadors by the end of this year.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Breast Feeding Enhances Immune System
DOC.TEXT: Breast-fed babies have more active immune systems after one year than babies who have been fed formula, Canadian researchers reported in the medical journal The Lancet. Researchers at the University of Alberta Department of Pediatrics compared the immune response systems of 57 infants who were breast-fed with those of 24 bottle-fed infants. The children were found through the Edmonton Board of Public Health Clinics by Drs. Henry Pabst and Donald Spady. They were given a vaccine for meningitis and severe pneumonia at two, four and six months, according to the article in the current issue of Lancet. The report said there were no significant differences in measured antibody levels between the two groups before the age of seven months. But after seven months, the antibody levels were significantly higher in the breast-fed infants than the formula-fed babies, the report said. ``These findings are strong evidence that breast-feeding enhances the active immune response in the first year of life, and therefore the feeding method must be taken into account in the evaluation of vaccine studies in infants,'' the report said. Spady said Thursday that it is well known that breast-fed babies are more healthy than formula-fed babies, but this is the first study to show that their immune systems are stronger and more efficient after several months. ``It demonstrates that the baby who is breast-fed is able to mount a more effective immune response,'' Spady said in a telephone interview. ``There is something in the milk that seems to stimulate their immune systems to work more effectively,'' he said, adding that further research will focus on what component of milk stimulates the improved response. The report said breast-fed infants were changed to formula feeding at an average age of 4 to 5 months, but Spady said some of the breast-fed infants were weaned as early as one month.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Suspected of Stealing Rare Audubon Prints Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Romona in 2nd graf cq
DOC.TEXT: A couple who allegedly stole more than 100 prints by Audobon, Goya and other artists while working as volunteers in the state art museum were arrested in Vermont, police said Thursday. Michael Richard Moskaluk, 43, and Romona E. Arnold, 33, were arrested Wednesday and held by the U.S. marshall in Burlington, Vt. Louisiana authorities were seeking their extradition to face at least 60 counts of felony theft. Moskaluk was arrested after allegedly trying to sell a dealer a print by the John James Audubon, the 19th century artist and naturalist. Although the print was not one of the stolen works, the art dealer reported Moskaluk's offer to the FBI, and the tip led to the arrest, said Sgt. G. Hamilton Mixon III. Moskaluk and Arnold worked as volunteers at the Presbytere branch of the museum, in New Orleans' French Quarter. They disappeared about two weeks ago as police were preparing to arrest them. A search of Moskaluk's house revealed shipping receipts linking him to the stolen art, police said. Moskaluk has five previous felony convictions, including ones for art theft, police said. Police have recovered all 60 stolen Audubon prints but cannot return them to the museum immediately because they're needed as evidence, said Mixon. Forty-eight prints and illustrations by other artists also are missing. They included two Goya prints; five lithographs by George Catlin, a 19th century illustrator of Western Indians; and 19 scenes of Mexico or the Mexican War by Carlos Nebel. Some of those works have yet to be traced. ``The sooner we send out the word that these things are back the happier I'll be,'' said director James Sefcik. ``Whether we get something back this week or not remains to be seen. I sure hope so.'' State police said much of the museum's art was sold through art dealers in France, Canada, Chicago, Philadelphia and New York. Officials said the prints brought as much as $2 million. The art dealers who purchased the works claimed not to know they were stolen, and will not be charged, police said. The thefts were discovered about two months ago after an exhibit of Audubon's drawings of Louisiana birds. The stolen Audubon prints were part of a complete set of 425 acquired by the museum 150 years ago, shortly after Audubon finished the so-called elephant folio of prints 2 feet by 3 feet.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Challenge Concludes in Federal Court
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania's abortion law is constitutionally sound and should be upheld, a state attorney said Thursday in closing arguments on a court challenge to the toughest such statute in any state. An attorney representing a group of abortion clinics and doctors opposed to the law countered that its restrictions would strip women of dignity, potentially endanger their health and have a chilling effect on doctors who perform abortions. ``There can be no doubt the challenged provisions burden women's rights to abortion,'' said Thomas Zemaitis, a lawyer for the clinics. The conflicting assessments came in closing arguments before Senior U.S. District Judge Daniel H. Huyett III, who has been asked to overturn key sections of the law on constitutional grounds. Pennsylvania's law is the most stringent on the books of any state. Only Guam, a U.S. territory in the Pacific, has adopted more stringent controls. The case has generated national interest because it might eventually provide a way to challenge Roe vs. Wade, the landmark 1973 decision that established abortion as a constitutional right. Lawyers expect a ruling in about a month. Huyett has blocked disputed sections of the law until he rules. Among the disputed provisions are requirements that women notify their husbands if they want an abortion and wait 24 hours before getting an abortion, and for minors to obtain the consent of at least one parent, or a court order, before receiving an abortion. Some of the contested sections of the law are redrafted from a 1982 statute, much of which was struck down by the U.S. Supreme Court in 1986. Senior Deputy Attorney General Kate L. Mershimer argued that there had been important abortion rulings since the Roe case, including a July 1989 Supreme Court decision in Webster vs. Reproductive Health Sercives Inc., a Missouri case that gave states greater leeway to restrict abortion. Ms. Mershimer made a point-by-point review of each disputed section, prefacing her remarks by saying, ``We believe our law ... remains constitutional.'' Zemaitis said testimony had shown how the law would place undue restrictions, controls that are far out of step with the Roe ruling. He said the provisions ``hardly promote an interest in women's health; they harm women's health.'' Zemaitis said the state was ``demeaning'' women by forcing them to wait 24 hours for abortions, and suggested that the section was written simply to discourage abortions. ``That's what this provision is all about: If we keep women tied up 24 hours they'll change their minds,'' he said. Both Mershimer and Zemaitis have expressed confidence their side would win. Most of the witnesses in the trial have been doctors or psychologists. The trial has been largely devoid of the emotionalism and protests that have typified the national debate over abortion. The courtroom, with seating for about 15, was only occasionally filled to capacity.

DOC.HEAD: Preliminary Reports Indicate Avianca Plane Was Not In Danger
DOC.TEXT: The Avianca jet given emergency clearance to land here this week was not dangerously low on fuel, preliminary reports indicate. Air traffic controllers, mindful of January's fatal crash of a fuel-starved Avianca jet approaching Kennedy Airport, declared a fuel emergency on an Avianca jet Tuesday night although the plane's crew said it was unnecessary. The crew aboard Avianca Flight 20 from Bogota, Colombia, told air traffic controllers the plane had 15 minutes of fuel left when it was about 30 miles south of Kennedy. The controllers put numerous other planes in a holding pattern to give the Avianca jet a straight-in approach, and the Boeing 767 landed safely at 9:24 p.m., about 12 minutes after its crew radioed the tower. Preliminary reports show the plane had at least 13,700 pounds of fuel in its tanks when it landed, which would have kept it in the air for about two hours, said Federal Aviation Administration spokeswoman Diane Spitaliere. When the pilot told the control tower he had only 15 minutes of fuel left, he was probably referring to the amount left before the plane would have to start using its reserve fuel, said Spitaliere. International flights are required to carry enough reserve fuel to reach an alternate airport plus 45 minutes for possible delays. The FAA was waiting for a report on exactly how much fuel the plane had, she said. An Avianca Boeing 707 crashed Jan. 25 in a wooded area of Cove Neck, on the approach to the airport, after the crew failed to properly alert air traffic controllers that the plane was out of fuel. The crash killed 73 people and injured 85.

DOC.HEAD: Increase in Outbreak of Shigella Bacteria
DOC.TEXT: Reports of illness from shigella bacteria, which causes acute diarrhea, nearly doubled in a two-year span, federal health officials reported Thursday. Health officials isolated 10.1 cases of shigella per 100,000 people in the United States in 1988, up from 5.4 per 100,000 in 1986, the Centers for Disease Control said; 22,796 cases were reported nationwide, the highest number since record-keeping began in 1965. Major shigellosis outbreaks in recent years included 513 confirmed cases in Peoria County, Ill., in 1987, and 191 in Kankakee County, Ill., in 1986-87. Shigella infection can cause severe diarrhea and other symptoms. Poor hygiene can be a factor in transmission.

DOC.HEAD: Big Ben Takes Time Off Again
DOC.TEXT: Like clockwork, Big Ben's famous hands stopped for the second day running Thursday at 5:20 p.m. This time, engineers were prepared. They quickly restarted the hands manually on the four clock faces atop the 20-story tower overlooking the Houses of Parliament. But engineers were still trying to figure out the reason for Big Ben's fitful timekeeping. London's weather, a favorite complaint for natives, has been unsually hot. Some residents suspect that to be the cause. On Wednesday, the clock stopped for about three hours before workers brought it back to life. Big Ben is a 13{-ton bell that chimes out the hours from behind the clock faces. Stoppages are rare for the 131-year-old clock tower, which has survived pollution, bad weather and war. A plan to renovate the clock's hammer arm and chimes is expected to be completed this month.

DOC.HEAD: Washington State Court Rules JAL Crash Cases Should Be Heard in Japan
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court on Thursday upheld a ruling that damage lawsuits against Boeing Co. from the 1985 crash of a Boeing 747 owned by Japan Air Lines should be heard by Japanese courts. The JAL 747-SR slammed into a mountainside on a flight from Tokyo to Osaka on Aug. 12, 1985, killing 520 of the 524 people aboard. In 1987, King County Superior Court Judge Gary Little dismissed the claims on condition that Boeing submit to jurisdiction in Japan, waive any statute-of-limitations defenses, admit liability for compensatory damages and accept the judgment on liability in Japan. Little granted plaintiffs in the case the right to return to Superior Court for trial on damages if ``the actions cannot be handled expeditiously in Japan.'' The lawsuits were filed against Boeing and JAL on behalf of the estates of 78 victims, including 71 Japanese citizens. Before dismissing the damage claims, the trial court found that Boeing had admitted botching part of its 1978 repairs on the aft pressure bulkhead of the aircraft, which separates the pressurized section of the plane from tail section. Boeing admitted its bungled repair caused the crash. Attorneys for the plaintiffs appealed on technical grounds, and argued that dismissal of the damage claims was fundamentally unfair. The high court confirmed the trial court's finding that the plaintiffs would get an adequate hearing in Japan. ``Plaintiffs have not challenged this finding and, indeed, concede that Japanese law provides full compensation,'' Justice Barbara Durham wrote for the court. Durham said the trial court had found that virtually all of the witnesses, documents and other evidence pertaining to the issue of damages are in Japan, favoring trial there. Japanese courts tend to provide smaller rewards in damage lawsuits.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Request to Stop Shark Hunt
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Thursday declined to stop a shark hunt that opponents claimed would draw the carnivorous fish toward shore, where they would threaten swimmers and surfers. A group filed a lawsuit Wednesday to obtain a temporary restraining order against the Columbia River-Pacific Ocean Shark Tournament scheduled for Friday and Saturday off the northern Oregon coast. Clatsop County Circuit Judge Pat Dooley said he couldn't stop the tournament on such short notice. Tournament opponents were troubled by plans to toss blood and fish parts into the ocean to attract the sharks. Biologist Mark Marks testified before Dooley that the practice could increase the chance of an attack. ``It would increase the risk potential, however small it may be,'' said Marks, a graduate student who studies shark behavior at Humboldt State University in northern California. ``Undoubtedly, this kind of behavior is not conducive to safe swimming.'' Ron Miller of Long Beach, Wash., a charter boat operator who helped organie the tournament, said, ``The whole thing has gotten the media into a feeding frenzy. It's just a handful of guys going out fishing.'' Miller said about a dozen boats were expected to take part in the hunt, and most of the fishing would be 60 to 100 miles offshore. The total purse for the competition is $80,000, including $35,000 for the largest shark caught. Plans for the tournament drew opposition from area surfers, windsurfers and jet skiers, the city council of Seaside about 20 miles south of the mouth of the Columbia River and surrounding Clatsop County's Board of Commissioners. The anti-tournament calls itself Safe Harbors and Recreational Choices, or SHARC.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalist Concert to Go Forward
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists who planned a three-day concert in a forest glade have agreed to move it about a mile away so the music won't disturb a family of northern spotted owls. U.S. Forest Service biologists had opposed the concert, saying a crowd of 700 to 1,000 people might upset the nesting owls. The federal government listed the spotted owl as a threatened species in June. Concert organizers had complained they were being harassed by the Forest Service since the Aug. 24-26 concert will feature acoustic folk music. The concert is sponsored by environmentalists who have beeng trying to stop logging of old growth forests where the bird lives. The Forest Service said Wednesday the environmentalists had agreed to move the event a mile from the spot where concerts had been held the last four years. The concert site is in the Willamette National Forest, about 10 miles northeast of Detroit in the Cascade Range of northwest Oregon.

DOC.HEAD: Mental Health Lawsuit Settled in Maine
DOC.TEXT: A judge Thursday approved settlement of a lawsuit on behalf of mental patients who claimed they were pumped with drugs and left in seclusion for long periods at the state's largest mental hospital. The class-action lawsuit was filed by four advocacy groups in Feburary 1989. It also claimed patients at the Augusta Mental Health Institute were denied adequate medical care, and that the state did not provide enough community treatment for the mentally ill. The settlement signed by state Judge Bruce W. Chandler was brought on behalf of an estimated 2,000 to 3,000 people who have been patients at the complex, which serves the entire state, since January 1988. It calls for a three-year program, which state officials estimated would cost $7 million, to reduce the population at the institute and expand community programs for former patients. ``Today is a historic day for the consumers'' of mental-health care in Maine, said Richard M. Goldman, an Augusta attorney representing the Maine Civil Liberties Union. Assistant Attorney General Linda Crawford pledged that Mental Health Commissioner Robert W. Glover, Human Services Commissioner Rollin Ives and hospital Superintendent Linda Breslin _ the defendants in the suit _ were prepared to implement the plans in the 131-page agreement. Lawyers in the case said they expected Chandler to appoint a special master to oversee the plan by mid-September. The agreement calls for the number of patients at the hospital to be gradually reduced to 70 by Aug. 1, 1995, including no more than 20 who require skilled nursing or intermediate care. The number does not include a separate forensic unit. On Thursday, the hospital had 280 non-forensic patients, including 97 in its nursing home unit, according to Tammy Woodard, secretary to Ric Hanley, the hospital's chief operating officer. By Jan. 1, 1991, the state must design a comprehensive mental health system that provides patients means to continue living in their communities unless they require hospitalization. The state must finance housing assistance, residential support programs and crisis-intervention services for patients, hiring additional staff to carry out the programs.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Says Invasion Will Not Affect Its Relations With Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Brazil, a key arms supplier to Iraq, said it is ``extremely concerned'' over that country's invasion of Kuwait but insisted its relations with Iraq will not be affected. ``Today, Brazil condemns the invasion but this won't affect relations in the long term,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Lucio Pimentel said at an afternoon briefing. ``There is no reason for a change,'' he added. ``Brazil has important interests with Iraq and these will be maintained.'' This South American country has become an important exporter of arms, cars and services to Iraq in exchange for petroleum. Last year, Brazil purchased $1.46 billion of crude oil from Iraq, or 26 percent of total daily oil imports, he said. However, Pimentel said Brazil has not exported arms to Iraq since 1988 because of unpaid debts on previous arms deals. Trade relations between the countries improved steadily after Brazil opened a credit line for weapons sales to Iraq in 1974. Iraq become Brazil's second-biggest weapons customer and top oil supplier, said Pimentel. During its 8-year war against Iran, Iraq bought large numbers of Brazilian-made ``Urutu'' armored personnel carriers and ``Cascaval'' reconnaisance and anti-aircraft combat vehicules, an official in a major Brazilian weapons manufacturer said. The official, who requested anonymity, said Brazil also sold Iraq sophisticated computer and radar-controlled rockets and a small quantity of ``Tucano'' planes, highly mobile training aircraft costing $2 million apiece. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday, seizing control of the oil-rich state after heavy fighting and setting up a provisional government after a 2-week-old dispute over oil production and borders.

Nearly one in four American infants is born to an unmarried mother, six times as many as four decades agog children born to single mothers, who often provide less financial security than some married parents, the CDC said. Twenty-four percent of U.S. infants were born to unmarried women in 1987, the latest year for which statistics are available, the CDC said. In 1950, the figure was 4 percent.

Mayor Marion Barry says he is suffering pain and shame after a six-week trial in which his defense admitted he used cocaine occasionally and the government accused him of having ``lived above the law.'' The jury of two whites and 10 blacks was instructed Thursday not to consider ``politics or race'' as the panel began deliberating the mayor's fate on 14 criminal charges. The nine-woman, three-man jury's first decision was selecting a foreman, Edward Eagles, one of the two whites. Barry engaged in ``occasional'' cocaine use, but the government failed to prove the drug possession, conspiracy and perjury charges against him, defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy told the jury earlier Thursday in closing arguments.

Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan and the Bush administration are demanding apologies from a Democratic congressman for calling the Cabinet member a ``disgrace to his race.'' The administration also called on the Democratic Party to repudiate the remarks made Thursday by Rep. Fortney ``Pete'' Stark, D-Calif., chairman of the health subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee. Stark said Sullivan, who is black, ``is being used by the administration and does not have the strength of his own convictions.'' The remarks by Stark, who is white, apparently were triggered by a speech Sullivan delivered in late July opposing proposals for federally sponsored national health insurance. Stark is sponsoring a proposal to levy an added income tax to pay for national health coverage.

Consumer and business groups want to know why American Telephone & Telegraph Co. apparently pocketed as much as $200 million of a government-ordered $500 million price reduction last month, but a regulator says the utility acted properly. The groups on Thursday petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to consider rule changes that would require AT&T to reveal how it figured that, in response to an FCC order, it had to cut prices only about $300 million rather than about $500 million. FCC Chairman Alfred Sikes told a House subcommittee that AT&T ``has fully flowed through its share of access price decreases to its price caps.'' He said AT&T had dropped prices so much voluntarily before July 1 that it needed only to reduce prices an additional $300 million.

Scientists, scholars and plain Garden-of-Eden-variety creationists are meeting to ponder dinosaur footprints, the aftermath of Noah's flood and other evidence they say discredits the theory of evolution. About 300 people from across the United States and Canada are attending the weeklong International Conference on Creationism, which features lectures on subjects such as the age of the earth. ``If we can show that the Earth is young ... in the range of 10,000 years, that essentially excludes a 4 billion-year-old Earth,'' conference coordinator Chris Brooks said Thursday. The argument holds that mankind could not have evolved the way evolutionists contend it did in such a short period, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Spending Increases in Southeast Asia
LaserGraphic planned
DOC.TEXT: The end of the Cold War may produce a peace dividend in Europe and the United States, but the nations of Southeast Asia are going the other way. Defense officials reject the term ``arms race,'' but all members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations except the Philippines are strengthening their military forces. Most blame uncertain conditions in the region. Translation: The likely reduction of U.S. forces compels the six ASEAN members to consider providing their own defense. It has dawned on ASEAN that, whatever happens to American bases in the Philippines, reductions in Washington's defense budget will mean a smaller U.S. military presence in Asia. A buildup of strategic weapons like missiles and advanced fighters is occurring because military commanders are looking to control borders and sea lanes. ``The relatively stable regional environment which we have long taken for granted is now being reshaped,'' Abu Hassan Omar, the Malaysian foreign minister, said in a policy statement. ``This could pose new challenges for all of us in the region, especially since a stable security environment has been an important underpinning of the region's rapid economic growth.'' No reductions in defense spending are contemplated by Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, the Philippines or Thailand, the six ASEAN members. Most are revising their military structures and weapons procurement programs to meet what they see as a shifting security environment that remains complex and potentially troublesome. ``If the United States significantly cuts back its military forces in the region, this will not be a signal for Singapore also to reduce our forces,'' said Lee Hsien Loong, deputy defense minister of Singapore. ``It will be reason for concern over a potentially destabilizing change in the regional balance of power.'' Lee, 37, is the eldest son of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. He also serves as trade minister and many expect him to become prime minister eventually. Singapore openly supports a continued U.S. military presence in the region, and a senior U.S. State Department official said in late July that Brunei had joined Singapore in offering access to the U.S. armed forces. An arrangement is being negotiated for increased use of Singapore's facilities by American planes and warships. Details of the arrangement with Brunei, which the U.S. official described as ``an enhanced security relationship,'' have not been disclosed. Officials in several other capitals agree privately with such support, but are noncommittal in public. Abu Hassan put it this way: ``Malaysia appreciates the U.S. role in the region and it is our sincere hope that the U.S. And the Philippines will find an amicable solution. ``What is more important, however, is that the close and extensive bilateral relations between the U.S. and the ASEAN countries, which have served our mutual interests, be maintained.'' Malaysia's military budget has grown with the economy, by 20 percent in the last two years. A memo of understanding signed with Britain in 1988 covers the purchase of Tornado fighters, anti-aircraft missiles and navy corvettes. Brunei, with money no object because of its oil riches, is buying patrol boats and the the sultanate's first combat planes, 16 British-built Hawks. Tight military budgets have been the rule in Indonesia while the country worked its way out of recession, but it followed Singapore in buying U.S.-built F-16 jet fighters. Planes of both countries use a new firing range in Sumatra. Defense spending in Singapore is about 6 percent of its gross domestic product, the sum of all goods and services sold in a nation. That amounts to the equivalent of $1.9 billion this year for a nation of 2.7 million people. Diplomats said Thailand's military budget increased 16 percent over last year, to $2.1 billion. The Thai air force also has F-16s and plans to buy flight simulators jointly with Indonesia and Singapore for pilot training. Bilateral land, sea and air exercises between forces of ASEAN members have become common, although it is not a military alliance. Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus of the Philippines thinks it is time for ASEAN to discuss regional security. ``If after sitting down, we should decide not to do anything and to consider this matter as a purely bilateral matter between us and each of the superpowers ... let that be, but at least we will know what we are thinking about,'' he told foreign correspondents last month in Manila. Some officials worry about what will happen in the region as U.S. and Soviet forces are reduced. ``Without a persuasive U.S. presence, there will be a power vacuum, which other powers would scramble to fill,'' Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore said in March. He gave India as an example and said the Japanese, too, were modernizing their forces. ``As an economic superpower, it has an understandable interest in the state of the region,'' Lee said of Japan. Diplomats say other ASEAN members consider China a greater regional threat than India. The Spratleys are a possible powder key. China, Malaysia, the Philippines and Vietnam have conflicting claims to the tiny islands in the South China Sea, which are being explored for oil. China and Vietnam came to blows over them in 1988.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday Aug 13

DOC.HEAD: Six-Part Series on Beer Brews Up
DOC.TEXT: There have been shows about the hunt for elephants, submarines, bad guys, lost tykes and even the elusive butterfly of love. And now, for something completely different: ``The Beer Hunter.'' It's a six-part serenade to suds, written and hosted by Michael Jackson, a British writer and beer expert. A man of firm views, he believes beer is far more than a belch propellant. ``It is as varied as wine, it is as noble as wine, it is as complex as wine,'' says Jackson, whose seven books on the subject include ``The New World Guide to Beer.'' His series, premiering Aug. 23 on cable's Discovery Channel, studies beer varieties in Holland, Germany, Belgium, Great Britain, Canada and the United States. His American visit reports on San Francisco's famed Anchor Steam beer. Jackson, who lives in London, said he's been writing about beer for 16 years. He began in journalism 14 years earlier. He noted in passing that ``in those days, newspaper journalists drank a lot of beer.'' There are rumors that some still do, he was told. ``Not so many now,'' he said, a bit wistfully. ``It worries me sometimes when I see these non-drinking journalists. I don't see how they can function.'' Jackson took up the cause of beer when he noticed how people partook of and talked about beer. Yet they only wrote about wine, no doubt considering beer one of the lesser grogs, suitable only for drinking. ``I felt right from square one that beer didn't get the respect it deserved,'' said the writer. He dedicated himself to raising beer criticism and reportage to the high, indeed mystical level devoted to the world of Grappa Stompa, which is Italian for Grapes That Have Been Stomped On. There are a variety of wines, such as chardonnay, cabernet, sauterne and port, he noted. But beer is equally diverse. There are Belgian brews with winey tartness; fruity-tasting ales; soft, spicy dark lagers, and so on. Jackson's crusade to make this known and enlighten minds and palates has not been without controversy in England, where there is an organization called The Campaign for Real Ale. There is debate within that group, he said, ``whether some of the writers _ i.e., me _ are making beer too elitist.'' Sometimes no help is needed. In New York and Los Angeles, for example, some citizens _ they are called yuppies _ try to be beer elitists. They invariably cause snickers because, no matter where they are, they always ask barkeeps: ``Ehhhh, what kinds of beer do you have?'' But New York and Los Angeles ``are very unsophisticated cities in terms of beer,'' Jackson contends. ``If you want to see people who know about beer, you have to go to Seattle or Portland or San Francisco.'' In those cities, he said, ``there's been a renaissance of serious interest in beer'' that started in the mid-'70s with the opening of several small breweries in Northern California and then spread to the Pacific Northwest. Jackson may well be envied by many journalists, particularly those who after work like to knock back a round or two of Old Frothingslosh. A few who take aboard more have been known to propose marriage, confide dark secrets, weep, fall off a bar stool or even sing, ``The Beer That Made Milwaukee Famous Has Made a Loser Out of Me.'' But for Jackson, moderation is all. His tippling is purely professional. He does admit that getting sloshed ``is a hazard. But I don't think I've ever fallen prey to it when I've been tasting.'' He did have a small problem when filming the German part of ``The Beer Hunter'' at a beer festival, he said. His director said things like, ``Can we do that again? Where you swallow that pint of beer, can we just do it again?'' By 9 p.m., Jackson still was being asked for another take. The script called for him to conclude things with a cosmic statement on beer. But he noticed he was approaching a condition known as Unclear. ``I said, `Hey, John, I'm just too drunk to do this.' And he said, `You don't seem drunk to me.' I said, `That's because you're drunk.''' Jackson gave it a try, though. He succeeded this time. ``I saw it on the rushes and thought I looked terrible,'' he said. ``But nobody's commented on it.'' __ Elsewhere in television... NBC AND UNION TO MEET: NBC and officials of the network's major union, the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, are scheduled to meet here Tuesday for what NABET negotiator Tom Kennedy calls exploratory talks. On July 27, a majority of the union's members rejected a four-year NBC contract offer for the second time this year. But no strike vote has yet been taken by NABET, whose members struck the network for 17 weeks in 1987. The union's previous contract expired on March 31. End Adv PM Mon Aug. 6

DOC.HEAD: Vulnerable to Oil Imports
DOC.TEXT: Good military and business strategy dictates avoidance of any action that places one in a position where others can call the moves. U.S. economic policy seems never to learn the lesson. Billions of dollars in loans to less developed countries someday may be witten off as uncollectible. Because of this threat, American borrowers already pay an interest premium beyond what rates otherwise might be. Political leaders have failed to deal effectively with decades of budget deficits. Much of the money, corporate and governmental, is borrowed abroad. Should foreigners withdraw it suddenly, the U.S. economy would suffer. These are just two instances of how vulnerable the United States economy is to actions over which is has relatively little control. The latest, of course, is the Mideast uproar, which threatens higher domestic oil prices. Higher domestic prices could: _Be the difference between an economy growing weakly, as now, and an economy tipped into recession. _Fuel inflation. Moreover, an inflation that domestic policy could do little to contain. Demand-pull inflation, in which an excess of demand pulls prices higher, can be dealt with internally. Imported inflation may not. The type of inflation produced by high imported oil prices is cost-push. Increased costs to importers are passed to refiners, to distributors, to the companies that buy it, to the customers of those companies... While such inflation would mean distressingly higher heating oil and gasoline prices, it could be devastating to industries, some of which already are operating on low margins because of global competition. Conceivably, the higher costs of fuel could mean less air travel at a time when airlines are seeking more passengers. It could mean considerably less driving, which in turn could become translated into fewer automobile sales. Should higher oil prices stick, it would be a serious blow to a resolution of the U.S. imbalance of payments. That problem, perhaps overly simplified, is that the United States buys more abroad than it sells there. One reason for this imbalance is the growth of oil imports, which now account for nearly 50 percent of U.S. supplies, a record high volume that is still growing. Now it will be growing at even higher prices. The one aspect of higher oil prices, a very tentative one at this point, is that conceivably it could spur domestic exploration and development, which has been eroding at a pace faster than usage is growing. June domestic crude oil production was just 7.1 million barrels a day. A little more than four years ago the country was producing 9.1 million barrels a day. The shortfall has been made up by increased imports. Because of its dependency on oil imports, U.S. options in the Iraq-Kuwait dispute are limited. Consider the extent of the involvement: domestic interest rates, the inflation rate, balance of payments, budget deficit... The situation didn't develop without warning. Few people who lived through the 1970s oil-import problems will ever forget them. In fact, they and their leaders vowed not to forget _ and then did. When the price of imported oil soared back then, it pitched the American economy into chaos, and some economists trace to it our current problems with inflation, high interest rates, and chronic imbalance of payments. The warning flag has been flying high and flapping loudly since the 1970s, but somehow it has been ignored. Ironically, some of those other problems, the ones that have so consumed the interest of policymakers and diverted their attention from oil, might have had their origins in the very thing they've ignored. That is, in America's dependence on imported oil.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Mon, Aug 6

For Release Monday, Aug. 6, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: It's Like Old Times for Oil-Service Stocks
DOC.TEXT: Thanks to rising oil prices and the flareup of trouble in the Middle East, some old stars of the stock market are back for a much-delayed encore. Even before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Thursday, the skimpy list of New York Stock Exchange issues making new 52-week highs gave prominent places to names like Schlumberger and Halliburton from the oil service industry. And as the hostilities set off an explosive reaction in markets around the world, oil-service issues racked up further gains. Until about a year ago, it had been a long dry spell for investors in oil service companies, which specialize in providing equipment and services such as construction and testing for oil and gas producers. The collapse in oil prices of the mid-1980s, while helping the rest of the economy and the overall stock market to prosper, drove the oil-service industry into the red in 1986 and 1987. A subsequent recovery was slow and tortuous. Oil-service stocks lagged through most of the 1980s while the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials kept soaring to new heights. Schlumberger, for example, had become a glamour name in the portfolios of investing institutions by the time it hit a record high of $87.25 a share, adjusted for splits, in late 1980. Then it lapsed into a long decline that drove it as low as $27.37 in 1986 and $26 in the October 1987 crash. From its ticker symbol SLB, some Wall Street traders took to calling it ``Slob.'' Since early 1989, however, the shares have more than doubled, from $32 to the neighborhood of $67. Similarly, Halliburton, after falling from $87 in 1980 to $17.50 in 1986, has rallied back above $55. Baker Hughes, the product of a 1987 merger between the oil-service companies Baker International and Hughes Tool Co., has since jumped from $11.12 to around $33. Some of that dramatic revival has stemmed from an improvement in conditions that has already shown up on the industry's bottom line. Few analysts dispute that further profit recovery is in store. ``With worldwide oil and gas exploration activity on the upswing as a result of rising crude prices, companies that provide equipment and services to the international oil industry are likely to prosper in coming years,'' says Standard & Poor's weekly publication The Outlook in a current report on the group. At the same time, however, some analysts question whether the real-live fundamentals are strong enough to justify the degree of enthusiasm traders have shown lately for the stocks. The oil-service group has become a favorite of speculators, they note, as a means of trying to profit from swings in the price of oil. Furthermore, they note, the experience of the '80s has shown that unpredictable shifts in Middle East politics can be volatile downward as well as upward for oil-service investors. The Value Line Investment Survey, in its latest quarterly review of the industry, cautions, ``we haven't made a case for the kind of boom apparently anticipated in the prices of some of this sector's stocks.'' In an analysis published recently as Iraq was beginning to menace Kuwait, Edward Yardeni, economist at Prudential-Bache Securities, concluded: ``This development does raise the risk of another oil crisis, especially since the United States is so dependent on foreign oil once again. ``But let's not get hysterical. Instead, let's keep a close watch on events in the Persian Gulf.''

DOC.HEAD: Some Republicans Feel Betrayed by GOP Budget Plan
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In the political poker game over a deficit-cutting deal, President Bush has shown most of his hand, and the Democrats have yet to turn over a card. That frustrates the White House, irks Republican negotiators, makes some GOP congressional candidates downright angry. And not just at Democrats. Bush moved from never to maybe to OK on a tax increase _ three abrupt steps in 12 weeks _ without notice to the Republican candidates who feel at risk. GOP campaigners who had gone to the voters with their own versions of the no-new-taxes position that served Bush in 1988 suddenly came up short one major issue. Even when they'd disagreed with him about the acceptability of a tax increase, they felt the issue had been blurred. That internal strain was worse for the fact that the White House made no effort to create a Republican consensus for the president's changing position. When he called the budget summit and said he would negotiate without preconditions, dropping the no tax barrier without actually saying so, the word went to congressional leaders, both parties. When he made it explicit, saying tax revenue increases would have to be part of a deficit-cutting deal, it was by written statement, no immediate explanation. And when the administration got specific 10 days ago, outlining a $54-billion deficit reduction plan replete with taxes _ one a ceiling on deductions for state and local income taxes _ it went to GOP summit negotiators, no notice to the rank and file. In a way, the major advantage of the party in the White House has become a liability. The Democrats, the congressional party, don't speak with one voice; they have to fashion bargaining positions with a consensus among House, Senate and committee leaders. They talked privately about a Democratic budget plan to put on the negotiating table, but couldn't come to terms and didn't push it. At the same time, the administration put together a $54-billion package of spending cuts and tax increases, and budget director Richard G. Darman presented it to the Republican bargaining team late in July. They agreed, or at least acquiesced. But their consent built no consensus behind the White House plan. And that problem quickly got worse. According to the White House, the Republican plan was prepared to be presented simultaneously with a Democratic package. There wasn't any. Besides, Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., went public with the administration plan, saying that a provision to limit the federal deductibility of state income taxes ought to satisfy the Democrats who wanted to increase taxes on the rich. That, and a proposal for steep tax increases on beer and wine, stirred an immediate backlash, especially among governors, who saw it as a threat to state revenue sources. The question of who'd go first on unpleasant tax and spending steps, and thus take the political onus, has been a sticking point all along. And the Democrats insisted they had not signed off on any deal to deliver simultaneous budget-cutting plans. Rep. Richard A. Gephardt, D-Mo., the majority leader, said ``there may have been some miscommunication about what was going to happen.'' So it seems. ``We have been dealing with the Democrats in good faith,'' Bush told restive congressional Republicans on Wednesday. ``We have a plan we are prepared to share with them when they present theirs.'' But it already had been shared, with the Democrats and everybody else, although not formally presented to the budget summit. And Bush's message to the Republicans varied depending on who was describing it. He said he would veto appropriations bills exceeding his original budget, although he doesn't have any to veto just now. And that he said he would enforce sharp, automatic cuts in federal spending _ potentially about $100 billion worth _ unless there is a settlement before Oct. 1, when the new budget year begins. But his own aides differed on how tough a campaign stance he'll take with the Democrats on spending and the deficits, with intensified budget negotiations due after Labor Day. It may not make a lot of difference; Republican candidates have drawn their own lines on the issue. That's one reason House Republicans voted in a July 18 caucus against any new taxes or higher rates on old ones, rejecting a position Bush had just accepted. They're the ones with re-election bids on the line this year, and some of them suspect their political interests are being risked in the administration quest for a five-year, $500-billion deficit reduction agreement _ a deal that would last past the next presidential campaign.
