DOC.HEAD: Africans Fear Eastern Europe Will Monopolize Western Aid
LaserGraphic planned
DOC.TEXT: Africa needed something to cheer about after the world recession of the 1970s and its own debt crisis in the 1980s. The end of the Cold War might have been just the thing, but the hoped-for peace dividend has not materialized and political pluralism is bad news to many African leaders. According to World Bank figures, a 10 percent cut in military spending would allow the industrialized world to double its official aid programs. That could mean better water supplies for Guinea, more bread in Mozambique and new schools and hospitals in the Congo. Instead of the money African leaders might have expected, however, they are increasingly worried about stiff competition from Eastern Europe's new democracies for Western interest, aid and investment. They fear Eastern Europe's constant tugging at Western heart and purse strings will divert badly needed capital and condemn the world's poorest continent to further decades of misery. What squaring up to the competition means in many cases is shock therapy for state-dominated economies that are lumbering and often corrupt. Economic reform aims to attract more Western capital to Africa, but also may force political reform on governments with little or no popular support. ``African leaders are worried ... firstly about official aid flows and secondly about private investment,'' said Roy Laishley, managing editor of Africa Recovery, a U.N. quarterly publication. Although Western officials are quick to reassure Africa it will not be forgotten, not all the signs are good. Analysts estimate aid must grow by 4 percent annually to produce a 1 percent increase in living standards for ordinary people of the Third World. Africa is the only continent where the struggle against poverty is a total failure, according to the World Bank's 1990 development report. By the year 2000, sub-Saharan Africa will account for more than 30 percent of the developing world's poor, compared with 16 percent in 1985, even if aid continues to grow at current rates, the report said. The bank, the largest source of aid to developing countries, said last month its lending had decreased in the past year for the first time since 1985. Moeen A. Qureshi, senior vice president for operations, said the decline from $21.3 billion for the year ending in June 1988 to $20.7 billion 12 months later was partly due to a reduction in loans to China. World Bank loans to Africa rose slightly to $3.93 billion from $3.92 billion, but Qureshi said the bank would be playing a much greater role in financing Eastern European countries such as Poland, Hungary, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia. World Bank lending is expected to rise again over the next year. Western nations cut development aid for poor nations to $46.5 billion last year from $48.1 billion in 1988, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. An OECD statement traced the decline to ``special factors in the timing of payments to multilateral institutions, mainly the World Bank.'' Joseph Wheeler, chairman of the organization's Development Assistance Committee, said Third World aid remained a high priority and the decrease did not involve shift of funds to Eastern Europe. Officials of the European Community point out that the $625 million of aid set aside this year for Poland, Hungary, Yugoslavia, Czechosolvakia, Bulgaria and East Germany is only 5 percent of the $15 billion, five-year Lome IV agreement channeling assistance to African, Caribbean and Pacific nations. The latest of the Lome packages, named for the capital of Togo, represents a 46 percent nominal increase and a 20 percent rise in real terms, said Xavier Prats, an EC spokesman for development. Third World populations expanding rapidly, however, and Lome IV still means only about $2 in new aid per person per year for 1990-1995, analysts say. That compares with an annual $20 per person for a three-year EC program in Poland and Hungary. European Community aid to those countries and Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Yugoslavia is expected to reach $1.25 billion a year by 1992, and the EC will be a major backer of a new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. ``In addition to aid, there's a need for additional investment'' in Africa, ``and that's certainly being undermined by the eagerness of the business community to look east and compete for future positions in Eastern Europe,'' said Jos Lemmers, director of the Council of Europe's Center for Global Interdependence and Solidarity. Barber B. Conable, president of the World Bank, said on a recent visit to West Germany the developing nations ``must work harder to attract investments; otherwise money will go to Eastern Europe.'' Private capital ``goes where the most attractive opportunities are,'' he said. That now appears to be Africa's main problem. Because of easier opportunities in Eastern Europe, fewer Western investors are willing to brave the unpredictable, often anti-capitalist African business climate unless political leaders offer sweeping economic reforms, analysts say. President Kenneth Kaunda decided recently to double the price of flour and other basic commodities to shore up Zambia's flagging economy. Zambians protested violently and security forces arrested an army officer for plotting a coup. ``I would say some of the reforms African nations are using to attract foreign investment are dangerous,'' a U.N. Africa specialist said, on condition of anonymity. ``It's a high political risk to take, to implement austerity measures at a time when very poor people already have next to no money in their pockets.'' Pro-democracy protests have taken place in several African nations this year. Many Western aid experts are critical of demands by some donors that continued aid be linked to political reform. ``What is essential is to have greater respect of human rights,'' an EC official said, also on condition of anonymity. ``that doesn't mean just transplanting Western-style democracies to Africa. They are not always practical and often not possible.'' Lemmers' center at the Council of Europe is sponsoring a series of East-West-South conferences scheduled to begin in Budapest, Hungary, this year. He said Africa could benefit from the end of the Cold War, citing new market potential in Eastern Europe for Third World agricultural products. Instead of laying the blame for Africa's economic ills solely at the door of the former European colonial powers, African leaders now seem more willing to shoulder some of the responsibility. President Quett Masire of Botswana described the new attitude as a turning point for the continent. ``We are willing to go to the doctor and ask for the right medication,'' he said recently after a 70-nation conference on Africa in the Netherlands. Masire and Robert McNamara, former president of the World Bank, were co-chairmen.

DOC.HEAD: Southeast Asia Welcomes Changes in Europe, but ...
With BC-What Now-Africa
DOC.TEXT: The European Community's effort to revive the economies of Eastern Europe causes anxiety among Southeast Asian nations that seek aid and investment. While welcoming the emergence of democracy in the former Soviet bloc, some members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations worry that resources will be diverted to that region at their expense. Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, Brunei and the Philippines make up the assocition, a loose grouping formed in 1967 to foster regional economic and cultural development. All six are apprehensive that removal of most trade barriers among the 12 European Community nations in 1992 will hurt their export-driven economies, and seek assurances that Eastern Europe's restoration will not be at their expense. ``ASEAN's fear is that the community's assistance to these countries would result in the diversion of its assistance from other developing countries, especially ASEAN,'' said Foreign Minister Abu Hassan Omar of Malaysia. ``The community's investment in ASEAN has been lagging behind those of Japan and the United States,'' he said at a news conference. ``With the opening of Eastern and Central Europe,lion. Investment by EC countries in ASEAN member nations is far behind that of Japan and the United States, and has grown at a slower rate. ASEAN officials say Europeans favor investments within the EC or in North America, and fear the pattern will reinforced by the unified market. Some in ASEAN feel the region risks becoming Japan's ``economic backyard'' if European trade and investment goes elsewhere. Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore expressed that view on a recent trip to Europe. He said returns on investments in Eastern Europe might not equal those on money put into nations of the Pacific rim, many of which are booming. ``To make East European work forces highly productive and competitive, that cannot be done overnight,'' Lee declared. Officials of ASEAN said rechanneled aid and investment would be direct losses, and Eastern Europe also might become a low-cost trading competitor, Indonesia appears most vulnerable to such a diversion. It remains heavily dependent on help from abroad and expects more than one-quarter of revenue for the 1990-91 fiscal year to come from foreign aid. More than $4.5 billion will reach it this year from the Intergovernmental Group on Indonesia, an organization of 13 donor countries, the World Bank and similar agencies.

DOC.HEAD: One Year Later: War With Cocaine Gangs Inconclusive
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Colombians have died and the United States has spent millions of dollars in a year-long effort to destroy the Medellin cartel, but the war goes on and the cocaine still flows north. A presidential candidate was shot down at a rally the night of Aug. 18, 1989, and the government, shocked and outraged, declared war on drug gangs that had become so powerful they threatened to take over the country. Luis Carlos Galan, who spoke out against the cocaine barons, was standing on a wooden platform acknowledging the cheers and applause of thousands of people when hired killers opened fire with machine guns. His death began a chain of events that terrorized Colombia and revealed the horror a voracious U.S. appetite for cocaine could create. A year later, the war rages on. Increasingly, it appears unwinnable, but the government has scored some victories. National police have seized a record 40 tons of cocaine so far this year in raids on jungle laboratories, more than the 33 tons captured in all of 1989. Cocaine delivered in Miami costs $35,000 a kilogram, or 2.2 pounds. Before last August, the price had been as low as $10,000. Officials say the higher prices indicate success in reducing the supply, but the flow has not been stopped. Galan's murder awakened Colombians from a slumber that had permitted drug traffickers free rein. President Virgilio Barco issued his declaration of war and the world's attention focused on this South American country. At the rally, the initial reaction to the shots was like the response to an earthquake, when people know something is terribly wrong but do not realize immediately that the ground is heaving beneath them. Because of the noisy scene, the rapid gunfire made popping sounds, like small firecrackers. Not even Galan's bodyguards understood immediately. Panic and screams began when Galan fell, mortally wounded. Two more presidential candidates were murdered soon afterward and the drug gangs bombed a packed airliner, killing all 107 people aboard. In several cities, car bombs exploded at restaurants, supermarkets, schools and in the streets. Some bombs in Bogota, the capital, were so powerful they left huge clouds hanging over the city of 6 million people. Colombians had viewed terrorism in places like Lebanon or Israel as distant wars among fanatics. Now they had their own terrorists, not religious or political fanatics with age-old grievances, but drug traffickers who killed other people coldly, to protect their business. The Medellin cartel, largest of the cocaine gangs, was taking in billions of dollars a year by 1989 and warning public officials to get out of the way. Those who couldn't be intimidated were murdered. ``We now know that the cartel is like a monstrous octopus in the ocean, with only the top of its head visible,'' a source involved in planning the anti-drug war told The Associated Press. ``The tentacles extend to the United States and around the world,'' he said, referring to bank deposits, bribes and murder. Like virtually every other person involved in fighting the Medellin cartel, the source would speak only on condition of anonymity. With Galan's death and the government crackdown that followed, the world opened its eyes to the danger of the drug gangs. President Bush sent $65 million worth of military aid to Colombia from a special fund available to him. In February, he met with the presidents of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru, which provide most of the world's cocaine, in the Colombian port city of Cartagena. Bush agreed to increase economic aid to the impoverished Andean nations to help them and their farmers find alternate sources of income. At another summit in Britain, Western European nations recognized the high price Colombia was paying in the drug war and agreed to help. Justice Minister Roberto Salazar noted that other countries were realizing the drug trade was international, not a Colombian problem. ``The world began to recognize that Colombia is providing 90 percent of leadership in fighting the drug scourge,'' he said in an interview. Because of police raids, drug traffickers have moved many cocaine processing operations to neighboring Brazil and Ecuador, Salazar said, and the labs being destroyed are so rudimentary they can be replaced in a few days. Another problem is the billions of dollars available for bribes. ``If a cop in New York or Miami making $30,000 a year can be bribed by drug traffickers there, then imagine how easy it is to bribe one here who makes only about $2,000,'' an agent of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration told the AP. Most of the war on traffickers falls to the 80,000-man national police force led by Gen. Miguel Gomez, 52, who has a university degree in education. ``Fortunately, we've got an honest cop at the top,'' a U.S. diplomat said. Gomez has dismissed half a dozen colonels, several dozen other officers and hundreds of ordinary policemen in an effort to clean up the force. A source close to the search for bribe takers said a police colonel can make $15,000 a month in payoffs. Gomez said he had only 22 helicopters for raiding labs and fighting the cocaine gangs, and needed 20 more. Salazar, the justice minister, said the struggle involves much more than police or military action. Some countries allow the shipment of cocaine-processing chemicals to Colombia, he said, and the drug lords can buy all the weapons they want on the international arms market. Huge arms shipments destined for Colombia's drug traffickers have been seized in the past year, but many others obviously get through. Raids on cartel hideouts over the years have turned up hundreds of thousands of weapons. Foreign governments appear either unable or unwilling to stop the laundering of drug money, Salazar said in the interview. Industrialized countries must strengthen regulation of banks, he said, and praised U.S. requirements that banks report all accounts worth more than $5,000. ``When they can pick up cellular phones and transfer millions of dollars, they can own half the world,'' Salazar said of the cocaine barons. He said the success of Colombia's war on the cartels depends in large part on how much of their assets are seized elsewhere. President Barco's government negotiated an agreement with the United States that allows Colombia to share in the hundreds of millions of dollars of traffickers' assets seized in the United States. Cesar Gaviria, the new president, pledged before his inauguration Aug. 7 to press the anti-drug war, but has said Colombia will not fight it alone. Gaviria has not indicated whether he will continue Barco's policy of extraditing trafficking suspects. Twenty have been sent to the United States for trial in the past year, but none are believed to be major figures. Salazar said Colombia must consider reforming its justice system so the suspects can be tried at home. In the past, judges have been bribed or coerced into letting drug traffickers go. Drug-trafficking cases should be handled by special judges who live and work in protected areas, the justice minister said.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Medellin Cartel Still Eludes Capture
With BC-Colombia's Drug War
DOC.TEXT: Pablo Escobar, a former car thief who became a billionaire cocaine trafficker, remains at large in the Colombian Andes, where the fear and loyalty of peasants protect him. There may never have been a manhunt like the one for Escobar, who runs the drug gang that smuggles most of the cocaine sold in the United States. Speculation that security forces didn't really want to catch Escobar and other members of the Medellin cartel ended Dec. 15, when the army tracked down and killed Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, the cartel's No. 2 man. Police killed all five of Rodriguez's bodyguards and his 17-year-old son, Freddy, who was carrying weapons. Rodriguez ran into a banana plantation, firing at a helicopter gunship pursuing him, and the helicopter riddled the cocaine trafficker with bullets. Some observers say police do not intend to take Escobar alive because his men could might kidnap government officials and hold them hostage until their boss was freed. The search appears relentless. Police set up roadblocks and soldiers raid suspected hideouts. Using sophisticated U.S. radio monitoring and tracking devices, they try to trace transmissions believed to come from Escobar's bodyguards. Colombia's 80,000 national police have mounted several major operations based on tips about where Escobar could be found. Security forces seem to have come close three times in the last year. Several weeks ago, the army thought it had Escobar surrounded. When soldiers broke into a shack, they found it empty, but a coffee pot was steaming and there was evidence Escobar had been hiding out there. A wanted poster with Escobar's photograph has appeared regularly on television. Although the government has offered $500,000 for his capture, it is doubtful many Colombians are eager to cash in. Escobar and his cohorts have killed at least hundreds of people, perhaps thousands. Also, many poor Colombians hold Escobar in high regard. He approaches sainthool in a neighborhood of Medellin, the cartel's headquarters, where he replaced slum shacks with houses of brick and cinder block. Gen. Miguel Gomez, chief of the national police, said Escobar was moving from hideout to hideout in the northwestern state of Antioquia. Escobar's genorosity to peasants makes information on the drug lord's whereabouts hard to come by. ``He owns every pair of eyes in Antioquia,'' a foreign diplomat said. Asked about Escobar's ability to elude the dragnet, Gen. Gomez said: ``We have our own methods, and we will succeed.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug. 12

DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait shook financial markets around the world, sending oil prices, the dollar and interest rates soaring and stock prices reeling. Crude oil rose $1.57 a barrel in New York futures trading Thursday and nearly $2 in London, unleashing fears of a resurgence of inflation and a possible recession in the United States that affected other markets Oil prices were boosted by the possibility the invasion eventually could affect output from the two nations or other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

Major U.S oil companies said they had small or no operations in Kuwait and did not expect infrequent crude shipments from the country to be disrupted because of the invasion by neighboring Iraq. Texaco Inc. operates the only refinery in either country _ a 50-50 joint venture with state-owned Kuwait Oil Co.in an area known as the neutral zone between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. Texaco spokeswoman Anita Larsen said Thursday about 80 percent of the refinery's 800 employees are Saudi nationals and are 17 American. She said operations were continuing despite the invasion.

Allianz AG, Europe's largest insurance company, announced an agreement to purchase Fireman's Fund Insurance Co. for $3.3 billion in cash. Fireman's Fund, a nationwide property and casualty company, is the principal subsidiary of Greenwich-based Fund American Companies, and had gross premiums in 1989 of $3.2 billion. Allianz, based in Munich, West Germany, had a worldwide premium value of $20 billion in 1989, and has 223 subsidiaries in 45 countries. The deal was announced Thursday.

Aerospace giant Pratt & Whitney said it will eliminate 4,000 jobs by the end of 1993, mostly through attrition, because of an expected reduction in its military engine business. The action, announced Thursdau, will reduce the size of the jet engine maker's U.S. work force by about 11 percent, with Pratt & Whitney's Florida operations suffering the greatest impact.

Orders to factories for manufactured goods slumped in June for the third time this year, the government said. The report added to analysts' fears of a possible recession. The Commerce Department said Thursday the decline was concentrated in durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years. They fell 2.8 percent to $125.1 billion after a 2.2 percent advance a month earlier. Non-durable orders were flat at $112.3 billion.

Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said the Justice Department will pursue all allegations of savings and loan fraud, but he declined to comment on a report the FBI is seeking evidence of political influence-peddling in 1988 S&L bailout deals. The Los Angeles Times reported Thursday the FBI was investigating allegations of political favoritism in selecting buyers for dozens of failed S&Ls in deals which involved billions of dollars in federal subsidies.

An administrative law judge recommended that five U.S. airlines be awarded direct routes to Japan from six U.S. cities. The judge on Thursday picked United, Delta, American, Continental and America West airlines to fly the new routes in what is already a $6 billion annual aviation market for the two countries. Cities getting new flights would be Chicago; Los Angeles and San Jose, Calif.; Portland, Ore.; Seattle, and Honolulu.

Kansas Gas and Electric Co. urged stockholders to reject a $27-per-share, $875 million takeover offer from Kansas City Power and Light Co. KG&E said Thursday the offer, made last month, of $857 million in cash for its common stock and $18 million cash for three series of preferred stock was inadequate.

Union pilots who joined a strike against Eastern Airlines have the right to replace trainees hired during the carrier's rebuilding, a federal judge ruled. But Eastern said Thursday it planned to appeal the decision and officials said there will be no immediate effect on current employees or operations. All but 200 of the 3,600 ALPA pilots walked off the job in sympathy with striking Machinists in March 1989. Pilots ended their strike last November, but fewer than 50 have been recalled to the Miami-based airline, ALPA officials said.

Stock prices fell broadly Thursday in the heaviest trading of the year as news of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait jolted markets worldwide. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 34.66 points to 2,864.60. The dollar rocketed higher as Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent currency investors scrambling to a safe haven. Gold rose moderately. Bond prices tumbled on fears that rising crude oil prices would trigger higher inflation. In commodity markets, oil futures soared, livestock and meat futures were down sharply and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Recession: A Matter of Definition
Also moved in advance
DOC.TEXT: For practical, everyday purposes, the debate about whether the economy is in recession or just this side of it is all but meaningless. Recession is a technical, statistical, arbitrary definition. It isn't a line that when crossed rearranges the perspective, any more than the autumnal equinox brings a sudden change to fall weather. For many people, it is a rather academic event, occurring when the economy suffers two consecutive quarters of shrinking gross national product, and that means you are at least six months into it before you know it. In fact, there have been recessions that weren't demonstrated until they were over and recessions so mild they might have represented better times than during some officially designated growth periods. Some recessions sneak up gradually, as some economists believe is happening now, and others explode, as in 1973, when President Ford was campaigning to ``Whip Inflation Now,'' not realizing that a deep recession had begun. There have been recessions that skipped some geographical and occupational areas, and a recession in the mid-1980s that encompassed most of the nation but never qualified as one because good times in a few states skewed the averages. At one extreme, there have been recessions so deep unemployment rose to 25 percent, and so long they ruined most of a decade, as in the late, unlamented 1930s. And at the other extreme, recessions that came and departed silently. Far more important than the technical definitions are: 1. the strength or weakness of the economy; and 2. whether it is gaining strength or losing it. Right now the economy is weak, and it is losing strength. Real gross national product rose at an annual rate of just 1.2 percent during the second quarter of the year, the fifth straight quarter of less than 2 percent growth rates. A healthy economy would grow twice as fast. For probably the only time since the recession of the early 1980s, the major private sectors of the economy _ consumer spending, business fixed investment, housing construction and net exports _ declined simultaneously. In the same quarter, real disposable personal income rose at an anemic annual rate of less than 1 percent. Consumer confidence is unsteady. Big ticket sales are off. Some housing values are down. Homebuilding is depressed. Some, perhaps most, of this is a consequence of what is called the Federal Reserve's tight money policy. Restrict the flow of money to the economy and the price of it _ interest rates _ goes up or remains high. Tight money means tougher borrowing conditions, the intent of which is to suppress activity. In real estate, for example, easy money policies of the mid-1980s had led to bad loans, an excess of construction and bankruptcies. Tight money, however, is a blunt instrument, hurting bad risks and good together. It is the weapon now being used by the Fed to bring down what are seen as inflationary pressures. But it could create new ones. Small business, for example, is complaining that it is bearing the brunt of the slowdown effort, and a survey by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce tends to confirm that claim. The survey found that 20 percent of all businesses seeking credit in the past six months had trouble borrowing, but that for smaller commpanies _ those with sales of less than $1 million _ the percentage rose to 27.4. Small companies are generally the innovators and job creators. They are the price cutters. They are risk-takers, capable of failing, to be sure, but also of growing swiftly. They are the future competition for giant companies. For them, the source of future economic growth, the recession has already begun, no matter that the official declaration of recession has not been made.

DOC.HEAD: Restless Checchi Structuring a Bigger, Friendlier Northwest
With BC-NWA-Glance.
Also in AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Alfred Checchi is trying to make Northwest Airlines bigger and friendlier, but he has been battling a sluggish industry and some isolated turbulence in his first year as chairman. On the Aug. 3 anniversary of the day Checchi's group finalized a $3.65 billion buyout of the nation's fourth-largest carrier, Northwest is eyeing growth despite an industry-wide slump. With eyes on Eastern Airline's Atlanta hub and possibly other Eastern jewels, Checchi has discussed the idea of buying the carrier's assets out of bankruptcy court proceedings. ``They barely had the Northwest deal done before they started looking at the landscape (for acquisitions),'' said Duane Woerth, head of the union representing Northwest's 5,600 pilots. ``He's changed the focus from top to bottom.'' In the past 18 months, Northwest has gone from being a conservatively managed takeover target with a fat balance sheet to a highly leveraged aggressor headed by industry novices. Racked with labor strife and performance problems under former chairman Steven Rothmeier, Northwest under Checchi is at peace with its unions and winning back customers who had come to know it as ``Northworst.'' But along the way there have been distractions. Three Northwest pilots were arrested March 8 and accused of flying a passenger jet while under the influence of alcohol. Northwest also has said it is one of many airlines being investigated by the Justice Department for possible industry price fixing. Checchi and other top executives at the airline have been declining interviews for weeks. But he repeatedly has said he intends to double the carrier's size in five years and make it America's most preferred airline. ``They've improved the morale and the spirit of the people, but I don't think they've made any money,'' said Mort Beyer, an aviation consultant in Arlington, Va. ``My impression is that their costs will be increasing faster than their revenues. I continue to watch it with concern.'' Since the takeover, Checchi has filled eight of the top 10 posts at Northwest and has lost a lead fleet manager to United Airlines. Former chief financial officer William Trubeck also has resigned, but will act indefinitely as a consultant. Five new executives had no airline management experience: Checchi, director Gary L. Wilson, chief executive officer Fred Rentschler, president Frederic Malek, and chief financial officer John Dasburg. Rentschler had been chief executive at Beatrice Cos. and Dasburg, Malek, Wilson and Checchi had worked together at Marriott Corp., where Wilson was Checchi's boss. ``They are primarily deal makers,'' Cliff Ehrlich, senior vice president of human resources at Marriott, said of Checchi and Wilson. ``I think they wake up in the morning thinking about deals and go to bed thinking about deals.'' Checchi has said the airline is healthy despite a $7.2 million operating loss in the final quarter of last year and a $90 million operating loss in the first quarter of this year. Nevertheless, the $3.35 billion takeover debt has been slashed to about $2 billion, putting the airline three years ahead of its seven-year repayment schedule, spokesman Doug Miller said. But most of the payments have been made from cash reserves, by selling and leasing back some planes and restructuring real estate, Beyer said. ``That can't go on forever,'' he said. ``They need better cash flows and the outlook for the year is down. The industry has had $2.5 billion in operating losses in the past nine months, but nobody pays attention to that.'' Mike Hamilton, an analyst for The Leuthhold Group of Minneapolis, said Northwest could afford an acquisition, but only at the right price. ``I don't think he'll get them (Eastern's assets) at bargain prices,'' Hamilton said, ``but there is nothing lost in trying.'' Eastern assets would fit Northwest by adding passenger loads, expanding maintenance space and feeding Northwest's Pacific Rim routes. But labor trouble could break out if Checchi hires from the non-union ranks at Eastern, said Guy Cook, president of International Association of Machinists District Lodge 143. ``We will war with them if they come up with stupid ideas,'' Cook said. ``But at this point I have no reason to war with them.'' Checchi hasn't been tested by contract talks, but Woerth and Cook say relations are vastly improved. For 40 years, Northwest workers considered themselves pawns of draconian managers, Cook said. Now they sense some cooperation. In the old days, for example, a collision of ground vehicles triggered automatic three-day suspensions, Cook said. A new disciplinary program instead emphasizes good performances, he said. ``What I notice is the people throughout the company are more proud of the airline,'' Woerth said. Meanwhile, travelers have observed a more punctual and reliable airline. Northwest recently completed six months of on-time performance, even with or ahead of comparable carriers, according to U.S. Transportation Department reports. In addition, fewer bags have been lost. The improvements dovetail with a five-year plan to invest $422 million to improve food service, seat space, cabin decor and speed of maintenance. ``When it was Northwest Orient it was a class airline,'' said Jim Maggio, whose New York firm is a travel agent for General Motors Acceptance Corp. ``They're getting back to that.'' Hamilton said the pilots' arrests and other incidents could have left bigger stains on the company. But Checchi's management team moved swiftly, including firing the pilots. Trial of the pilots began this week in federal court. ``The one thing they have is a lot of common sense,'' Hamilton said. ``They'll make a mistake, but they don't make the same mistake twice.''

DOC.HEAD: Experts Say Iraqi Invasion Likely To Boost Consumer Energy Prices
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait will likely mean higher energy costs for much of the nation, but the federal government says the long-term effect won't be significant. Oil experts say it's difficult to predict exactly how much prices will rise but that higher costs on the wholesale side will trickle down to consumers. Concern that oil production and shipments might be disrupted in the Middle East _ the source of about a quarter of U.S. oil imports _ already has caused wholesale energy prices to soar. In futures trading, crude oil jumped more than $1.50 a 42-gallon barrel, while unleaded gasoline and heating oil gained more than 3 cents a gallon. Trilby Lundberg, manager of a biweekly survey of gasoline prices that bears her name, said spot checks show that some wholsale gasoline distributors have raised their prices around a dime a gallon from Wednesday due to the recent increases in prices from their suppliers. Iraq invaded and seized control of its much smaller neighbor at the northern tip of the Persian Gulf early Thursday. The attack followed weeks of tension between the two countries over Iraqi accusations that Kuwait stole oil from its territory and was costing it billions of dollars in revenue by overproducing and helping depress the price of oil. In response to the invasion, President Bush embargoed Iraq's 588,000 barrels a day of oil imports to this country, a cutoff that analysts said could be made up from other countries. Henson Moore, the deputy secretary of energy, told reporters in Washington that American consumers had little reason to worry, mainly because an excess world supply of oil would cushion the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti imports for an indefinite period. ``We do not see ... any imminent threat to the United States'' as a result of the loss of Iraqi oil, Moore told a news conference at department headquarters. ``Nor do we see any long-term significant increase in prices.'' John Easton, the assistant energy secretary for international affairs and energy emergencies, told the news conference that the International Energy Agency, the 21-nation organization of oil consuming countries, had tentatively scheduled a meeting of its board of governors next week in Paris to consider the Iraqi situation. Wholesale prices already had been rising in recent days in reaction to an agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, of which Kuwait and Iraq are members, to restrain crude production in order to raise the price of its oil to a target of $21 a barrel. On Thursday, the September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, jumped $1.57 to settle at $23.11 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The near-month contract for the crude had traded in the low $16 range earlier this summer. Among refined petroleum products, unleaded gasoline for September delivery settled up 3.8 cents to 68.07 cents a gallon. Heating oil settled up 3.5 cents to 64.69 cents a gallon. The general rule of thumb, according to industry experts, is every dollar rise in the barrel of crude oil means a rise of two cents to a nickel at the pumps. Peter Beutel, a trader and vice president for Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, predicted home heating oil prices would rise at least a nickel a gallon by the fall due to the impact of the invasion. He said prices at the gas pumps could rise between 5 and 10 cents a gallon by Labor Day, one of the heaviest driving times of the year for Americans. The average national price of a gallon of gas, including taxes, was around $1.18 cents by late July, according to the biweekly Lundberg Survey of nearly 13,000 service stations. Edward Ryan, an oil trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said consumers should be spared an immediate increase in energy prices because of the current world glut of crude, partly due to high production of the OPEC. In the United States alone, supplies of unleaded gasoline are up about 10 percent from a year ago to 167.2 million barrels from 156.3 million, according to figures from the commodities brokerage Refco Inc. Crude stocks are up to 338.7 million barrels from 330.6 million. ``You may not see the impact on the consumer level for at least four to eight weeks,'' Ryan said. ``The current supplies on hand are adequate and I just don't see retail prices reacting in the same way as on the wholesale level.'' John H. O'Connell, an energy analyst at Refco, said the oil companies could absorb some of the increase. ``I think the oil companies will be cautious about passing it (price hike) on to the consumers for fear it might hurt consumption,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney To Eliminate 4,000 Jobs By 1993
DOC.TEXT: Workers at Pratt & Whitney's East Hartford plant say they're not surprised at the company's plan to trim its work force to make up for a drop in defense business. ``People would have had to have had their heads in the sand not to expect this,'' said John Makowiec, of East Longmeadow, Mass., a work leader who has been employed by Pratt for 30 years. Tom Leduc, of Enfield, a millwright who has been with the company 25 years, said there is always talk about reducing the work force so there is no point in worrying. ``People now just wait until their time comes,'' he said. The aerospace giant announced Thursday it will eliminate 4,000 jobs by the end of 1993, mostly through attrition, because of an expected drop-off in its military engine business. The action will reduce the size of the jet engine-maker's U.S. work force by about 11 percent, with Pratt & Whitney's Florida operations suffering the greatest impact. Although it has a $20 billion backlog of orders for commercial engines, the company said that would not offset the projected decline in defense contracts. Pratt & Whitney said half of the job reductions will take place at its Connecticut, Maine and Georgia operations, which employ 28,300 people, with Connecticut bearing the brunt of the cutbacks. The company makes all of its commercial and military engines in Connecticut, where it has a work force of 25,400 at plants in East Hartford, Southington, North Haven and Middletown. It is the state's largest private employer. The other 2,000 jobs will be eliminated from Pratt & Whitney's West Palm Beach operations, where 8,400 are employed, mostly in military engineering and testing. ``We think that this shrinkage reflects where we see the Defense Department going,'' said Curtis Linke, a spokesman for Pratt & Whitney, a division of United Technologies Corp. With easing world tensions, the budget ax is expected to come down on Pratt-powered Air Force planes, such as the F-16 jet fighter, the advanced tactical fighter and the C-17 transport. ``The military business is still very viable for us, it is just getting smaller,'' Linke said. Orders for commercial engines continue to be strong, but deliveries are spread out over the next decade, the company said. In 1989, Pratt & Whitney earned $2.5 billion from its defense sales, or about 36 percent of its business. Commercial engine sales accounted for $3.4 billion in revenues, or 49 percent. Revenues from engines built for general aviation totalled $1 billion. Pratt & Whitney normally loses about 6 percent of its work force through attrition each year. But some layoffs will also be necessary because ``attrition never takes places in exactly the right places,'' Linke said. The company said up to 300 workers could be laid off in Florida this fall, and O'Connor said an undetermined number of layoffs are also likely in Connecticut. The cutbacks will be the second big work force reduction in two years. The company eliminated 2,650 salaried jobs in 1988 and 1989, citing intense competition. The machinists union, which represents workers at all four Connecticut plants, said company officials had agreed to meet with union leaders in two weeks to discuss ways of avoiding layoffs. Romegialli said the union will push a number of proposals, including an expansion of the company's early retirement program and the transfer of affected workers to other divisions of United Technologies.

DOC.HEAD: West German Company to Purchase Fireman's Fund For $3.3 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Insurance industry analysts say a move by Europe's largest insurance company to buy Fireman's Fund Insurance Co. would give the firm a strong position in the U.S. market. Allianz AG and Fireman's parent company, Fund America Companies announced agreement on the $3.3 billion cash deal Thursday. ``Allianz, true to their statement, is interested in a bigger presence in the largest insurance market in the world,'' said James Ramenda, an insurance analyst with Northington Partners in Avon, Conn. ``Clearly, the U.S. market is more than half of the world market, and you can't in this day and age be isolated from that,'' said Bob Branche, managing director of Branche Research Group near Philadelphia. Fireman's Fund, a nationwide property and casualty insurance company, is the principal subsidiary of Fund American, and had gross premiums in 1989 totaling $3.2 billion. Allianz, based in Munich, West Germany, had a worldwide premium value of $20 billion in 1989, and has 223 subsidiaries in 45 countries. Allianz already operates in 20 states, company officials said. Analysts agreed that the purchase would help Allianz prepare for Europe's economic changes scheduled for 1992, when the common market countries plan to ease trade barriers. With 1992 and its promise of increased competition looming, ``diversification makes a lot of sense,'' Ramenda said. The $3.3 billion price tag, which is almost three times Fireman's Fund's book value, was the price Allianz had to pay for a larger share of the U.S. market, Ramenda said. Foreign buyers need to find ``friendly deals'' in the U.S. market because hostile deals can be blocked easily at the state regulatory level, he said. The price ``simply testifies to Fireman's Fund's negotiating ability,'' Ramenda said. Under the agreement, Allianz will acquire 100 percent of Fireman's Fund Insurance stock. Fund American will buy back Fireman's Fund's common stock portfolio and other long-term investments for $2.2 billion in cash. When the transaction is closed, Fund American will repurchase all 300,000 shares of convertible preferred stock of Fund American now owned by IFINT SA, a Luxembourg corporation, for $434 million in cash plus unpaid dividends. Fund American also plans to offer shareholders $800 million in assets, either through dividends or a tender offer, the company said. The sale will convert Fund American from an insurance company to an investment company, said Thomas Sargent, an insurance analyst with Conning & Co. of Hartford. Fireman's Fund, headquartered in Novato, Calif., was founded in 1863. In 1968, it was acquired by The American Express Co., and in 1985 became an independent company during what was then the largest initial public offering in the history of the New York Stock Exchange. The company's revenues increased from $3.3 billion in 1985 to $4.3 billion in 1987, but slipped to $3.29 billion last year. Net income also peaked at $404 million in 1987; last year's profits fell to $116 million from $279 million in 1988. Joyce Culbert, an insurance analyst with S.G. Warburg and Co. in New York, said she couldn't understand Fireman's Fund's appeal to Allianz, since the U.S. company has been fighting rising claims costs and flat premium prices. ``The question is, what do you do to make it better, and do the Germans know something that (Fireman's Fund Chairman) Jack Byrne doesn't know?'' Culbert said. But Ramenda said Allianz would simply ride out Fireman's problems until the U.S. insurance market begins to improve, probably in 1992. ``The U.S. market's highly competitive,'' he said, ``so it's unlikely that any one player could buck the cycle.'' Wolfgang Muller, a member of the board of management of Allianz, said in a statement that his company ``can add value to (Fireman's Fund Insurance) through our international capabilities, but any advances would come carefully and slowly.'' The transaction, which is subject to approval by insurance and other regulatory authorities and Fund American stockholders, is expected to be completed early next year.

DOC.BYLINE: Chrysler Boosting Prices; De-emphasizing Incentives ^By FREDERICK STANDISH
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. plans to try to back away from focusing on incentives, allowing the company to keep its 1991 price increase average to less than 1 percent, a company executive says. Thursday's announcement of a tentative price increase follows an announcement last week that Ford Motor Co. would boost prices on its 1991 cars by an average of 3.2 percent and truck prices would rise 3.6 percent. General Motors Corp. has not announced tentative 1991 prices. Generally, the prices announced in midsummer are for dealers placing large orders, especially for rental-car company fleets. There is a chance that prices will change before the vehicles are offered for retail sale. Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell said Thursday that part of the company's pricing strategy includes reducing the significance of cash rebates and low-interest financing in buying and selling a car. ``We would hope to de-escalate the use of incentives,'' Bidwell said, adding, however, ``No one, certainly not Chrysler, is going to turn this parade around.'' Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca blamed incentive costs, which have been averaging more than $1,000 for every car and truck it sells, for causing a drop in second-quarter earnings to $180 million, down 47.2 percent from the same time last year. GM, which reported a 40 percent profit decline, and Ford, whose profits fell by 45 percent, said they also were hurt by the cost of incentives, as well as by economic problems in Brazil. GM won't say precisely how much it spent on incentives during the quarter. Ford put its average cost at $1,050 per vehicle. Chrysler will lower by $1,100 the sticker price on the Dodge Monaco LE. The Dodge Dynasty will cost $560 more than this year. All the comparisons involve comparably equipped vehicles. Popular optional equipment on one model year's vehicles often is included as standard equipment on later models. That boosts the price and makes year-to-year comparisons difficult. Also muddying year-to-year comparisons is padding the automaker builds into prices for incentives. ``We've allowed allowances for rebates and incentives in the '91 prices,'' Bidwell said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Appoints Special Master for Stotler Funds
With PM-Mahlmann
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has appointed an attorney to oversee the operation of Stotler Funds Inc., a company controlled by Karsten Mahlmann before his resignation as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade. Attorney Kenneth M. Rosenzweig was named special master on Thursday by U.S. District Judge Milton Shadur. Rosenzweig has broad powers to monitor the affairs of Stotler Funds. A special master was appointed at the request of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. CFTC attorneys had charged in an emergency lawsuit filed Wednesday that two of Stotler Funds' investment pools had defrauded customers by making $5.6 million in unauthorized loans and investments to its parent company, Stotler Group Inc. At one point in a hearing Thursday, CFTC attorney Judith Goodie expressed concern about whether the funds were protected from further alleged misappropriation. ``Were there to be a continuation of the same kind of practice,'' said Shadur, ``this case would be a strong candidate for referral to the U.S. attorney's office.''

DOC.HEAD: Procter & Gamble Announces Expansion of Bar Soap Production
DOC.TEXT: The Procter & Gamble Co. says it plans to more than double the size of its bar soap operation at the plant where it has made Ivory soap since 1886. The project will cost about $200 million and will include a 65,000 square foot expansion to the Ivorydale plant in the suburb of St. Bernard, the company said Thursday. Construction is to begin in October and should finish by next summer. ``This project will ensure that we have a state-of-the-art soap operation that is ready to meet business and competitive challenges well into our second century,'' said Ken McWhorter, the site manager. The Ivorydale plant now employs about 750 people. The expansion will create about 50 new jobs, P&G said. Procter & Gamble makes a large variety of food, personal care and consumer products. It reported sales of $21.4 billion last fiscal year. Along with Ivory soap, the Ivorydale complex makes powdered laundry detergent, household cleaning products, food and industrial chemicals.

The stock market sold off sharply for the second straight session today as a new report on employment intensified recession worries. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 53.71 points to 2,810.89 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by nearly 4 to 1 among New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 222 up, 862 down and 362 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 40.68 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The Labor Department reported this morning that nonfarm payroll employment fell by 219,000 in July, surprising analysts who had been looking for a modest increase. The civilian unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent. Those figures reinforced concern in the financial world that economic activity was weakening more than had been thought just a few weeks ago. Many observers fear that the problem could be compounded by a jump in oil prices arising from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait this week. At its early low the Dow Jones industrial average was down about 60 points. Then ``bargain-hunting'' traders began to appear to provide a bit of support to the market. Among actively traded blue chips, International Business Machines dropped | to 109[; Philip Morris { to 46[; Johnson & Johnson ~ to 67~, and Wal-Mart Stores \ to 29|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 3.37 to 188.99. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.23 at 349.82. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 34.66 points to 2,864.60. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 5 to 2 on the NYSE, with 458 up, 1,207 down and 351 unchanged. Big Board volume came to 253.09 million shares, up from 176.81 million in the previous session and the heaviest total since a 416.29 million-share daay last Oct. 16.

DOC.HEAD: Infomercials Industry Forms Trade Association
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1st, 5th, 7th grafs to CORRECT typo `infomercials' sted `informercials.' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The makers of late-night television's ``infomercials'' are forming their industry's first trade association. ``It's a watershed,'' infomercial marketer Greg Renker said Thursday in announcing the formation of the National Infomercial Marketing Association to ``work with Congress and the staff of the Federal Trade Commission in developing advertising standards'' for the industry. ``It gives us legitimacy in the eyes of Capitol Hill and consumers, and it establishes us as a long-term industry,'' said Renker, whose Palm Desert, Calif.-based Guthy-Renker Corp. markets self-help and motivational courses. Infomercials, or program-length commercials, have had a checkered history since they were introduced in the mid-'80s, often masking as talk shows or ``Investigative'' news specials that actually hawked a product. Thousands of complaints over the years prompted U.S. Rep. Norman Sisisky, D-Va., to hold hearings on the industry before the House Small Business subcommittee that he chairs. Leaders of the infomercial industry met with Sisisky last week as they worked to form the association. ``If this is a sincere effort to address the problem of infomercial advertising abuses, it is a welcome development and a victory for consumers,'' Sisisky said Thursday. The infomercial marketers also met separately with Barry Cutler, director of the FTC's Bureau of Consumer Protection, which has filed six ``law enforcement actions'' against infomercial makers in the past few months. ``We want to encourage the FTC to nail infomercial producers who make false and misleading claims or are deceptive,'' Renker said. ``We want to discourage them from lumping us all into the same category and creating laws and regulations that hurt our sales effectiveness in the long term.'' The biggest players in the industry attended the Washington meetings and are joining the association, which plans to hold its first meeting on Sept. 13 in Washington, D.C. In addition to Guthy-Renker, they included New York City-based Synchronal Corp., and the Phildelphia-area based companies American Telecast, Quantum Marketing International Inc. and Media Arts International Inc. ``One of the frustrating elements of our new association is that the television stations are the gatekeepers,'' Renker said. ``They must take responsibility for the programming time that they sell, and it is incumbent on them to recognize association members and to scrutinize those who do not have a proven track record in the industry.''

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Rate Jumps to 5.5 Percent in July
With BC-Unemployment-States, f0037
DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate jumped to 5.5 percent in July _ the highest jobless rate in two years, the government said today in a report providing mounting evidence of a weak economy. The Labor Department said that July's 0.3 percentage point rise, up from the June jobless rate of 5.2 percent, put the American unemployment rate at its highest level since it hit 5.6 percent in August 1988. The sharp increase in unemployment was due largely to the economy's loss of 219,000 jobs, the government said. Though about 160,000 of those Americans who lost jobs were temporary census workers laid off by the government, private industry payrolls also lost 45,000 jobs. The report shows that the ``economy appears to be caving in to a full-fledged recession,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. Other analysts said the unemployment data showed an economy skirting the edge of a recession. ``The economy is just hung up on a rock on the middle of the road. It's still an economy thats inching ahead, but at a glacial pace ... We're close to the edge. It wouldn't take much of a breeze to push us over,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. Janet Norwood, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, noted that weak job growth had spread to the nation's service sector. That sector had been ``the major engine of job growth during the current economic expansion. But that engine seems to have sputtered in July,'' Mrs. Norwood said. On Wall Street today, the stock market sold off sharply. In early trading, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 53.71 points to 2,810.89. Job losses in the private sector were largely due to the continuing deterioration in the nation's construction and manufacturing sectors, the government said. Many analysts were bracing for even worse unemployment news in the months ahead as the impact of a prolonged period of economic sluggishness begins to force the jobless rate higher. Today's report provides the first indication of whether the economy fared any better so far in the third quarter than earlier in the year. Analysts were disturbed by government data last week that showed the economy grew at an annual rate of just 1.2 percent from April through June. The unemployment rate is derived from a household survey by the Labor Department, while job growth numbers are figured from a separate survey of business establishments. The job growth survey is often considered a more reliable indicator of economic activity. Construction payrolls fell by 50,000 jobs, after seasonal adjustment, posting the fifth consecutive decline to reflect continued weakness in the housing market, the government said. The number of jobs in the construction industry is more than 100,000 below the level of last fall, the government said. The nation's manufacturing slump continued in July, but factory job losses were not as great as they have been in the past. Last month, factory payrolls fell by 7,000 jobs, marking the 15th time in 16 months that manufacturing jobs declined. Since reaching a post-recession peak in March 1989, nearly 350,000 factory jobs have been lost. Meanwhile, the service sector, which has been carrying the economy in past months, began to show weakness as well, the government said. Service sector jobs fell by 160,000, but that number included temporary census workers. Still, several industries within the service sector lost small numbers of jobs, including wholesale trade, finance, insurance and real estate and business services. Retail trade added 20,000 jobs. Health services, which had added an average of 50,000 jobs each month in the first half of this year, expanded by only half that amount in July by adding 25,000 new jobs. Labor costs, which have been rising and are being blamed for worsening the nation's inflation problems, continued to speed up. Average hourly earnings posted a 0.6 percent rise in July to $10.09, up from the $10.03 the average worker earned per hour in June. The Labor Department's household survey showed that overall, total civilian employment was about 118 million in July, down from the 118.4 million employed in June. The jobless numbered 6.8 million, up from 6.4 million employed in June. The average manufacturing work week was down slightly in July, falling from 41 hours to 40.9 hours. Manufacturing overtime was 3.7 hours in July, a slight decline from June's average of 3.8 overtime hours. Last month's 5.5 percent unemployment rate pushed it beyond the level it has held for more than a year. Since September 1988, the jobless rate, before last month, had fluctuated within a tenth of a percentage point of 5.3 percent, except for March 1989, when it hit a 15-year low of 5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Current Account Surplus Up 12.2 Percent in June
DOC.TEXT: The surplus in the broadest measure of Japan's trade rose 12.2 percent in June from a year earlier, snapping two consecutive months of decline, the Finance Ministry said Friday. The surplus in the current account, the widest measure of a nation's trade in goods and services, widened to $4.78 billion from $4.26 billion in June 1989, according to the ministry. The June increase followed a 57.5 percent decline in the current account in May on a year-on-year basis. In May, the surplus stood at $1.46 billion. Finance Ministry officials attributed the rise in the current account surplus to higher exports and a decline in oil prices. But they added that it was too early to determine whether the downward trend had fully reversed. The merchandise trade surplus for June rose 8.0 percent from a year earlier to $7.05 billion on an unadjusted basis. Exports rose for the first time in nine months, increasing 3.3 percent to $23.10 billion. Imports rose to $16.05 billion, up 1.4 percent from a year earlier. Exports and imports in the current account are measured when contracts are settled and are different from the customs-clearance trade figures which are announced separately by the ministry each month. The current account does not include breakdowns of trade figures by country or region.

DOC.HEAD: Montgomery Ward, Sears End Talks
DOC.TEXT: In an unusual move, Montgomery Ward & Co. and Sears, Roebuck and Co. have announced that they discussed and rejected ``certain joint business opportunities.'' In a statement Thursday, the two giant retailers declined to indicate what the discussions entailed, and would not say whether they entertained the possibility of a merger. The Chicago Tribune today cited unnamed sources at one of the companies as saying the discussions began several months ago at the suggestion of a Ward executive. The talks were preliminary and in the ``what if?'' realm, the sources said. Spokesmen for both companies refused to comment on whether the retailers had considered merging. ``Certain joint opportunities doesn't mean a merger,'' said Charles H. Thorne, a spokesman for Montgomery Ward. ``We're standing on the statement as it has been provided,'' said Jerry Buldak, Sears' director of external communication. The companies released the announcements in Chicago, where they are headquartered, and in New York. The announcement was in response to media inquiries, the statements said. Sears is headed by Edward Brennan. His younger brother, Bernard, is chief executive officer at Ward. Bernard Brennan has been credited with cutting Ward's debt by closing its catalog division and selling the company's credit operations. The chain was losing $385 million a year when Bernard Brennan joined it in 1985. Last year, it reported net income of $150 million on sales of more than $5 billion. Sears is undergoing a massive corporate restructuring. It reported net income of $1.51 billion in 1989, up from $1.45 billion in 1988. Its earnings have been lower in the first two quarters of 1990, however.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Markets Open Lower, Turn Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, amid worries about the Persian Gulf situation. The crop markets opened lower, then turned mixed in a recovery led by the soybean complex. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said some of the strength stemmed from continuing anxiety over the Persian Gulf conflict, including fears that Iraq, having conquered Kuwait, may invade Saudi Arabia. ``War is always bullish for commodities,'' he said. Analysts also said the soybean market was oversold and due for a correction after a decline that began about six weeks ago. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.84{ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 2} cents higher with September at $2.52} a bushel; oats were unchanged to 2{ cents lower with September at $1.18} a bushel; soybeans were 5 cents to 6} cents higher with August at $5.87 a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange; pork futures were mostly higher. Live cattle futures were .15 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 77.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .50 cent lower with August at 88.70 cents a pound; live hogs were .50 cent lower to .15 cent higher with August at 58.05 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .75 cent to 1.6 cents higher with August at 47.75 cents a pound. DOC.HEAD: Phone Companies Ringing In The '90s With New Services
Graphic in AP Access under CUSTOMCALL
DOC.TEXT: The boss needs you to contact a client in another part of the country right away, but you don't have the phone number at your finger tips. Relax. Directory assistance can dial it for you. And if you're expecting an important call at home? You can tell whether a call is for you instead of your spouse by obtaining a personalized telephone ring. These are just some of the newer services the nation's six regional telephone companies are offering or plan to offer their customers. Many more are on the way due to changing lifestyles and the so-called Baby Bells' hunt for more revenue amid heightened competition in the deregulated phone markets. ``It is a major new source of revenue,'' said Marianne Bye, an industry analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``It's also a high margin area for the company, meaning that it costs them very little to provide.'' Bell Atlantic Corp. in Philadelphia has been a leader in providing these services, including the controversial ``Caller ID'' feature, industry analysts say. But similar services can be found anywhere since the Baby Bells use basically the same technology and get the computer software from the same vendors, they say. Clayton Brown, an analyst with A.G. Edwards & Sons, said telephone companies are only limited by the sophistication of their network. ``Little by little, as they improve their network, they can offer more and more services, which will enhance their revenue a bit more,'' Brown said. For St. Louis-based Southwestern Bell Telephone Co. _ which serves 9.5 million homes and businesses in Missouri, Kansas, Arkansas, Oklahoma and Texas _ add-on services make up about 13 percent of billed revenue. More than half of its customers choose to have at least one of the custom features, according to the company. ``It's a significant revenue stream,'' said David Martin, a Southwestern Bell spokesman. ``They cover their costs many times over,'' BellSouth Corp., based in Atlanta, anticipates about $65 million in revenue this year from its add-on services. Spokesman Terry Johnson said the company expects that amount to more than triple in two years and increase sixfold by 1994 as technology improves and regulatory matters are resolved. Other companies weren't able to provide a revenue breakdown. The most popular feature, the Baby Bells say, is ``Call Waiting,'' which tells customers using a phone that there's another incoming call and allows them to answer it. This feature is available throughout most of the country. ``Call Forwarding,'' ``Three-way Calling,'' and ``Speed Calling'' also are gaining in popularilty and availability, experts say. At Southwestern Bell, for instance, they're available in about 90 percent of the company's territory. Costs usually range from $2 to $10 a month, according to the companies. The most controversial feature is ``Caller ID,'' which displays incoming numbers on a small video device as a way to thwart unwanted callers. Promoted by Bell Atlantic, the feature costs around $6.50 a month, plus another $60 to $80 for a small viewing device that flashes an incoming number before the phone is answered. Businesses love this service, but it has come under fire from privacy advocates and some states. A Pennsylvania court, for instance, has outlawed it as a violation of wiretap laws. So far, six areas of the country have this service, and as many as 22 states are debating whether to allow it. Some of the more unusual services in the early stages of availability include: _A personalized telephone ring. Distinctive rings allow three phone numbers to be combined on one phone line and let everyone know who the phone is for when it ``ring RIIINNNGG rings'' for Dad or ``ring ring RIIINNNGGGs'' for his oldest daughter. The feature already is available on some office phone systems. _The ``lazy person's phone book.'' When a customer calls directory assistance, a recorded voice provides the phone number and, for a fee of around 30 cents, offers to dial the number. _The distinctive phone book listing. If your name is John Smith and you want to stand out in a sea of John Smiths in the telephone book, you can have your listing appear in ``sophisticated script'' or ``bold contemporary.'' The cost is around $6 initially, plus $3 a month. Jolene Meyer, Southwestern Bell's district manager of new product development, said the most popular of the so-called second phase of features is ``Call Return.'' It allows customers to automatically call back the last incoming call, whether or not they answered it. If the other line is busy, they can hang up and Call Return will automatically keep dialing the number and notify them with a special ring when the line is free. ``Call Return is the most popular of the group I think because it's comparable to Call Waiting,'' Meyer said. ``The customer doesn't have to do anything. It's kind of passive _ when we're out in the back yard and we hear the phone ring, we're reminded that we have that service and we have the option of answering it now or later.'' A similar feature is ``Call Cue,'' which redials the last number you attempted to call, and, if the other line is busy, will continue redialing for you. Other features include ``Call Blocker,'' ``Call Trace,'' and ``Priority Call,'' which provides customers with a distinctive ring for each of three pre-selected incoming phone numbers. Phone companies say that because of the technology involved in linking central offices, a number of these services won't be available to all their customers for five to 10 years. But they say the demand is definitely there. ``Our lifestyles are demanding more control,'' said Southwestern Bell's Meyer. ``People are kind of tired of having their chains pulled every time the phone rings. ``They have very busy, hectic lives. They put up with traffic jams, stress at the office and when they get home they want to have some control over who they talk to and when.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with closing prices in Europe, selected midday prices in New York
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell today against most major currencies in hectic European trading marked by rumors about turmoil in the Middle East and a report that suggested weakness in the U.S. economy. Gold prices were mixed. Dealers said the dollar took a nosedive early in the trading day after U.S. unemployment figures for July were released. The government said the U.S. unemployment rate jumped to 5.5 percent in July from 5.2 percent in June, a larger increase than had been expected. Traders moved quickly to sell the U.S. currency. The dollar's drop was cut short by continued fears of a further escalation of hostilities in the Middle East, dealers said. ``The market is pessimistic about the U.S. economy, but that isn't enough right now,'' said a dealer with a U.S. commercial bank in London. ``The (Persian) Gulf news overrode it.'' Market players said the dollar moved back and forth on rumors that Iraqi troops, which invaded Kuwait early Thursday, had now set their sights on Saudi Arabia. ``The market was very thin and chaotic and mostly affected by rumors concerning the Middle East,'' said a trader at a large Frankfurt bank. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to close at 149.35 Japanese yen from 148.90 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 149.85 yen. At midday in New York, the dollar was quoted at 150.35 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.8570 from $1.8495 late Thursday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.8537 at midday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.5920 West German marks, down from 1.5970; 1.3505 Swiss francs, down from 1.3570; 5.3345 French francs, down from 5.3510; 1.7945 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7985; 1,164.90 Italian lire, down from 1,168.50, and 1.1510 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1519. Bullion dealers said the market was hectic with gold seesawing in a broad range that illustrated the market's nervousness. ``The market wasn't based on logic today,'' said a Zurich dealer. ``The market is reacting to every news item about the Middle East crisis.'' Gold rose in London to a late bid of $379.25 a troy ounce from $378.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $378.00 an ounce from $379.00 late Thursday.
