DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Tumbles More Than 100 Points At Mid-Afternoon
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices plummeted in afternoon trading today amid continued tension over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, with the Dow Jones industrial average skidding down more than 100 points. ``The Middle East remains a tinderbox,'' said Alan Ackerman, a market strategist with Gruntal & Co. ``It's unstable and unpredictable.'' The key Dow Jones average of 30 big industrial stocks was down about 118 points in sustained selling shortly before 2 p.m. on Wall Street. In the broader market, traders said over-the-counter stocks were swamped with sell orders. The stock market was battered by fears that higher energy prices worldwide resulting from the Iraqi invasion would trigger inflation and further destabilize the U.S. economy. Already in a downslide because of recent reports of underlying economic weakness, the market was hit with more bad economic news this morning as the government reported higher unemployment in July. The Labor Department said nonfarm payroll employment fell by 219,000 in July, surprising analysts who had been looking for a modest increase. The civilian unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent. But market participants had their eye on Iraq, concerned that while Kuwait's oil reserves may not be critical to world supplies, further moves by Iraq could threaten oil from Saudi Arabia and other nations. ``The real concern is how far will Iraq go in the Middle East,'' Ackerman said. ``There's an absence of superpower intervention. Obviously there's a lot of nervousness worldwide.'' The Dow industrials fell 34.66 points Thursday on fears that a possible disruption of oil supplies could spark inflation and recession in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Market Plunge Trips Circuit Breakers For Index Futures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with second circuit breaker triggered; picks up 6th graf pvs, The report...
DOC.TEXT: A plunge in stock-index futures prices today on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange tripped two ``circuit breakers'' intended to prevent a runaway stock-market collapse. The drop in index futures coincided with a plunge in the stock market in response to disappointing economic news and fears of escalating conflict in the Middle East. All Standard & Poor's 500 stock-index futures contracts fell the permitted opening limit of 5 points within the first 10 minutes of trading, forcing exchange officials to declare a halt to trading from 9:40 a.m. EDT to 9:42 a.m. EDT, according to Andrew Yemma, an exchange spokesman. A second circuit breaker was triggered shortly after noon when the near-month contract, for delivery in September, tumbled to 341.9, 12 points below Thursday's settlement. Under Merc rules, selling below that level was prohibited for 30 minutes. S&P 500 index futures are valued at $500 per point. The plunge in index futures coincided with a drop of more than 90 points in the Dow Jones industrial average after the Labor Department reported the nation's unemployment rate jumped to 5.5 percent in July, the highest jobless rate in two years. The report was perceived as evidence of a weakening economy at a time when the markets already were extremely jittery over the possibly inflationary impact of skyrocketing crude oil prices linked to Iraq's conquest of Kuwait. Stock-index futures are contracts for future deliveries of baskets of stocks, such as the 500 stocks tracked by the S&P 500 index. Investors buy and sell the contracts to hedge against losses in the stock market or to speculate on stock-market moves. The Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade implemented the circuit breakers after the stock-market crash of October 1987, which some critics contended was exacerbated by trading strategies that employ computers to trade huge blocks of stocks and index futures.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Troops Take 14 US Oil Workers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Edits thruout to UPDATE with 14 missing, State Department asking Americans to leave, other details; also tightens. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: At least 14 Americans are missing from Kuwait oil fields and U.S. officials believe they are in Iraqi hands, a State Department spokesman said today. There are no reports of injuries to Americans in the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, but the State Department was advising the estimated 3,000 Americans in Kuwait and 500 in Iran to leave as soon as they can, said spokesman Richard Boucher. He said, however, immediate departures would not be possible from Kuwait because of the fighting and because all airport and ports are closed. The U.S. Embassy in Baghdad contacted officials of the Iraqi foreign ministry today to ask about the whereabouts of 14 missing Americans and to remind the Iraqis ``of their commitment to safeguard the safety of Americans,'' said spokesman Richard Boucher. In the early hours of the Iraqi invasion, which began before dawn Thursday, Iraqi officials promised U.S. authorities in Baghdad that Americans would not be harmed, Boucher said. He said privacy laws do not allow public disclosure of the companies the missing Americans worked for or their names, but another official said the Iraqis had been given those details and information about the circumstances of the disappearances to help in gaining their return. Iraq has provided no information about those missing, Boucher said. The 14 were taken from three different oil fields near the Iraqi-Kuwaiti border, Boucher said. ``We can't confirm they're in Iraqi control but we believe they are,'' he said. Although the government gave no details about the missing, family members of employees of Santa Fe Drilling Co. of California said the company had contacted them about missing relatives. Larry Neal, a spokesman for Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, said State Department officials indicated to him that most of the oil field workers were employed by Santa Fe Drilling. A Shreveport, La., woman said she received a call from Santa Fe Drilling that her husband, Donald G. Whatley, was missing. Whatley has been working as a drilling supervisor for Santa Fe in Kuwait, said Doris Whatley. She said Whatley had just returned to the oil operation after vacationing in Shreveport. ``They took him from his rig this morning and they took him across the border (to Iraq),'' she said Thursday. ``He just barely had arrived there in time for them to take him off his rig.'' Mrs. Whatley said she had not heard from State Department officials about her husband, but officials of Santa Fe Drilling called her to say he was missing. ``I don't want him to be forgotten like the rest of the hostages in the Middle East have been,'' she said. In Gilmer, Texas, the family of Charles Amos, 56, said he was among those rounded up by Iraqi soldiers. Amos also works for Santa Fe, the family said. ``We are holding out for whatever information we can get,'' said son David Amos. State Department officials told the Amos family that he'd been moved by soldiers who invaded Kuwait on Thursday morning, the younger Amos told KLTV and the Longview News-Journal. ``We were set to have a family reunion this weekend, and dad was going to fly out of Kuwait'' early Thursday morning, said his daughter, Karen Amos. ``But we got the call from the State Department about 2 p.m.'' Amos has been traveling and working overseas for more than 20 years, his son said. A short time before a State Department official disclosed the suspected roundup of some Americans, President Bush was asked about reports that American workers in Kuwait had been taken into custody. ``I don't have anything on that right now,'' he said. ``Secondly, it would affect us in a very dramatic way because I view a fundamental responsibility of my presidency is protecting American citizens. If they're put into harm's way I have certain responsibilities.''

DOC.HEAD: Financial Markets Shaken by Persian Gulf Hostilities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 new grafs to UPDATE with Dow Jones plunge, later New York oil trading, picks up 4th graf, In London... SUBS 11th graf, On Wall... to UPDATE Dow industrials. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait continued to shake financial markets today, but stock and bond prices got another jolt from a disappointing report on unemployment that worsened fears about inflation and a recession in the United States. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks tumbled more than 100 points at one time during the session on the double dose of bad news before recouping slightly. Oil prices, which shot up Thursday after the Iraqi attack, continued to climb today. Prices were boosted by the possibility the invasion eventually could affect output from the two nations or other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, was up $1.94 to $25.05 a barrel by mid-afternoon on the New York Mercantile Exchange after jumping $1.57 on Thursday. In London, the spot price of North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude, was quoted at $23.25 a barrel today, up 86 cents from Thursday, when the price rose $2 a barrel. The surge in oil prices came as a blow to other financial markets already concerned about the weakening U.S. economy. With oil and other energy sources crucial for every segment of the economy, rising crude prices can reinvigorate inflation. That would make the Federal Reserve _ which considers fighting inflation one of its top priorities _ less likely to move interest rates lower as a means of stimulating the economy. ``The Fed is caught between a rock and a hard place,'' said Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc. ``They're trying to support a weakening economy and at the same time keep interest rates at a level to support foreign capital and keep inflation under control.'' The outlook worsened today as the Labor Department announced the unemployment rate rose a sharp 0.3 percent to 5.5 percent in July. The jump indicated a continuing slowing of the economy as private companies lost 45,000 jobs from their payrolls. The report also carried bad inflation news: Average hourly earnings posted a 0.6 percent rise to $10.09, up from the $10.03 the average worker earned per hour in June. The double blow of rising oil prices and a negative economic outlook sent stock prices sharply lower. On Wall Street, the Dow industrial average skidded more than 100 points before rebounding slightly at mid-afternoon. The indicator was down about 81 points at 2:30 p.m. EDT, at 2,783.42. The Dow Jones average, which tracks the movement of 30 blue chip stocks, skidded 34.66 points on Thursday as traders grew uneasy about the effect oil prices would have on corporate profits. Stock prices also tumbled overseas in response to the Iraqi invasion. In Tokyo, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 729.42 points, ending the day at 29,515.76. The index lost nearly 593 points on Thursday. Japan is especially vulnerable to the possibility of a disruption of energy sources because it imports 99 percent of its oil. Traders there are concerned that the oil price rise will take a heavy toll on Japanese business. Bond prices were also hit hard by the unemployment report and the prospect of higher inflation from rising oil prices. At midday today, the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was down about $3.43 per $1,000 in face value after plunging more than $12 on Thursday. The bond's yield, considered a benchmark for interest rates throughout the economy, rose to 8.48 percent from 8.46 percent late Thursday. Bond traders are concerned that inflation will erode the value of their fixed-income holdings. They're also worried that interest rates won't be dropping soon, as bond prices rise when rates decline, so higher rates depress prices. The dollar first soared Thursday in response to the Iraqi invasion and then gave up ground amid concern about the U.S. economy. Today the dollar was little changed against most foreign currencies, but made its biggest moves against the Japanese yen. In early New York trading, the dollar was worth 149.965 yen, up from 149.30 late Thursday.

Those figures reinforced concern in the financial world that economic activity was weakening more than had been thought just a few weeks ago. Many observers fear the economy's problems could be compounded by a jump in oil prices arising from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait this week. Selling intensified as reports reached Wall Street that Iraqi forces were near the border of Saudi Arabia. It subsequently let up a bit when a Soviet official said Iraq was expected to withdraw from Kuwait in the near future. DOC.HEAD: Soybeans End Higher; Grains Lower In Volatile Session
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures ended higher and grain futures closed lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a see-saw session influenced mainly by developments in the Persian Gulf. Traders closely followed news reports for indications of whether Iraq was more likely to withdraw its invading troops from Kuwait or push on into Saudi Arabia. ``War is always bullish for commodities,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. News that Iraqi troops were within six miles of the Saudi border gave the markets a strong boost at midday. But as the close approached, the grain markets were calmed by a report that Iraq had indicated to the Soviet Union it planned to withdraw troops from Kuwait. Soybeans remained higher on ideas that the market was due for a rebound after falling for nearly six weeks. By the close, ``there was nothing too spectacular as far as price movement, but there was a lot of stomach churning while trading,'' said John Frazier, director of agriculture trading for Gerald Inc. in Chicago. At the close, wheat futures were 2 cents to 4} cents lower with September at $2.80} a bushel; corn was } cent to 2} cents lower with September at $2.50 a bushel; oats were 4{ cents to 6{ cents lower with September at $1.14\ a bushel; soybeans were 2} cents lower to 6\ cents higher with August at $5.86{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: National Intergroup Reports Loss
DOC.TEXT: National Intergroup Inc. on Friday reported a net loss of $281.7 million in its first fiscal quarter of 1991 due to reserves set aside to cover restructuring costs. The holding company, which has interests in metals and pharmaceuticals, said it lost $13.01 per share in the three months ended June 30, compared with a gain of nearly $13 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier. The company said it set aside $239.5 million in the most recent quarter to cover anticipated losses on the sale of its Ben Franklin stores and Permian Corp. subsidiaries. The company is selling most of its metals and other assets and plans to move its headquarters to Dallas, where its remaining asset, FoxMeyer Drug Co., is based. The company recorded a $26.7 million charge in the fiscal 1991 quarter associated with the closing of its Pittsburgh office and a $14.8 million non-recurring charge reflecting the market value of the preferred stock and expenses related to the sale of 20 percent ownership of National Steel Corp. to NKK Corp. of Japan. Those losses were offset partially by a $12 million gain on the sale of the company's information services subsidiary, Genix Enterprises Inc., to MCN Corp., a holding company for Michigan Consolidated Gas Co. ``Though the loss is significant, it clears the decks and allows us to move forward with our plan to focus our attention and resources on the drug distribution business,'' said Howard M. Love, chairman and chief executive officer. FoxMeyer reported operating income increased 39 percent to $10 million in the first fiscal quarter from $7.2 million in the year-ago period. Sales increased 15 percent to $666.8 million from $577.2 million. The company's equity investment in National Steel Corp. resulted in a net loss of $11.7 million in the first fiscal quarter, compared with income of $16.2 million in the year-ago period. The decrease was due mostly to the change in the company's ownership interest in National Steel, NII said. Centaur Partners of New York, the company's largest stockholder with 16.5 percent of outstanding shares, has been vying for seats on NII's board of directors. Centaur principals and Love said June 25 that the investor group won enough votes at the company's annual election to fill three seats on the 10-member board, keeping NII's candidates out. Centaur wants NII to sell FoxMeyer, the nation's third-largest drug distributor, and give the proceeds to shareholders.

DOC.HEAD: Accountants Must Say if They're Unlicensed, California Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: Accountants without a license can practice in California but have to call themselves ``unlicensed accountants,'' according to a state appeals court ruling released Thursday. In a 3-0 decision, the 1st District Court of Appeal upheld the State Board of Accountancy's authority to allow only California's 55,000 certified public accountants to use the terms ``accountant'' or ``accounting,'' without other modification, in connection with their business. But the court noted that state law does not require a license to prepare financial reports or do most other accounting work. Certified public accountants, who must meet state standards for education and experience and pass a national examination, can certify their audits and financial statements to lenders, government agencies, stockholders and the public. People without licenses can call themselves accountants, the court said, as long as they also state that they are unlicensed or provide some other disclaimer saying their services do not require a license. Because the Constitution provides some protection to free speech in advertising, ``we must permit the use of those terms (such as `accountant') if they are qualified by a warning or disclaimer that avoids their misleading impact,'' said the opinion by Presiding Justice Clinton White. The ruling is a partial victory but is far from satisfactory, said Ralph Alldredge, a lawyer for the California Association of Independent Accountants, a group of about 700 unlicensed accountants. He said no decision has been made yet on an appeal. ``To call yourself an unlicensed accountant is a derogatory term, almost,'' he said. ``It's a very negative way to have to present yourself to the public.'' Alldredge said no one knows how many unlicensed accountants work in California. Because of state restrictions, he said, some list themselves in telephone directories under bookkeeping or tax services or business consulting, none of which accurately describes their work. The association he represents joined Bonnie Moore, an unlicensed San Francisco accountant with a college degree in accounting, in a 1986 suit challenging the state Board of Accountancy's regulations. The board had ordered Moore and her firm to stop using the terms ``accounting'' and ``accountant'' in their business. San Francisco Superior Court Judge Thomas Dandurand ruled in the board's favor. White noted that the U.S. Supreme Court has recognized advertisers' right to free expression in truthful claims. Those rulings indicate that practitioners such as Moore must be allowed to tell the public they are accountants, as long as they specify that they do not have or need a license for their work, White said.

DOC.HEAD: Posts $33.3 Million Loss for Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp., which has shrunk under the weight of troubled real estate loans, announced Friday it lost more than $30 million in the second quarter. The financial report is the latest gloomy financial news for the banking company, continuing a tumble that began late last year. The company lost more than $1 billion in 1989, and $46.6 million in the first quarter that ended March 31. In the second quarter, which ended June 30, the banking company lost $33.3 million, or 49 cents per share, compared with earnings of $36.5 million, or 52 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Bank Chairman Lawrence Fish said in a statement that the company has made ``slow but steady progress'' in trying to recover. But he said the loss was not unexpected ``because of the continued sluggishness in the region's economy, the softness in the real estate market, and lower net income.'' The losses, in part, reflected how the bank has had to divert money into reserves to cover bad loans. The bank's total non-performing assets, which include troubled loans, totaled $2.78 billion, compared with $2.67 billion in the first quarter. Gerard Cassidy, a bank analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc., said the bank's assets were not deteriorating at the same rate as in the past. ``But when you're at these levels, you need to see reduction in non-performing assets, not smaller increases,'' he said. ``Overall, the numbers are a continuation of a negative trend.'' Bank of New England has been operating under federal orders since early this year. The bank came under heightened government scrutiny when a downturn in the economy and the real estate market exposed mountains of bad loans. Part of the bank's strategy has been to sell off assets and slash its work force to cut costs and raise money. The bank has reduced its workforce by 4,000 through a combination of layoffs, attrition and the sale of assets. Since the beginning of the year, the bank has sold more than $5 billion in assets, said spokesman James Dorsey. The company has decided not to sell it subsidiary bank in Maine, but is continuing discussions with possible buyers for its Rhode Island subsidiary. The bank had been borrowing money from the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston to meet immediate cash needs but stopped in mid-June. Bank of New England officials said, however, ``this could change from time to time.'' The bank said it has been able to stabilize its deposits through a campaign to attract certificates of deposit and by offering other retail products. Through the first half of the year, the bank lost $79.9 million, or $1.17 a share. That was slightly larger than the deficit of $78.8 million, or $1.12 a share, in 1989's first half. Assets totaled $23.07 billion at the end of the first half, down from $31.98 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Another Week of Bargaining Winding Up
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Thursday completed the presentation of its first set of contract proposals to the United Auto Workers union, leaving a UAW negotiator pleasantly surprised. ``What we got today indicated more than in '87 they heard our demands and they're moving on them,'' said William Don Hammonds, rank-and-file chairperson of the UAW negotiating team at Ford. Hammonds, plant chairperson of UAW Local 737 in Nashville, Tenn., was a member of the 1987 union team that negotiated the current contract with Ford. While the initial two weeks of negotiations have been cordial, said Hammonds and UAW Vice President Ernest Lofton, lots of work remains to reach a contract before the Sept. 14 deadline. ``Job security is still one of the things we have a great difference on,'' Lofton said. The union has tapped job security as its top priority for negotiations at General Motors Corp., Ford and Chrysler Corp. All three contracts expire at the same time. Negotiations at Chrysler got off to a rocky start, UAW Vice President Stan Marshall said last week. He said Chrysler made a ``mockery'' of the opening of talks by floating contract concepts to the media before bringing them to the union. Since then, negotiators have been meeting at the main bargaining table and taking turns making presentations. Few specific contract proposals have changed hands. There has been little official word from the talks at GM. Company and union negotiators have been meeting in subcommittees focused on various sections of the contract, such as health and safety, time off and scheduling. No specific economic proposals have been offered by either side in all three sets of negotiations. Lofton said he didn't expect the union to make specific economic offers until around Labor Day, when the UAW chooses one of the Big Three as its negotiating ``target.'' There's been a tradition in auto industry bargaining that the UAW chooses one company, suspends negotiations at the other two and, eventually, reaches an agreement with the first. That contract then is more or less imposed on the other automakers with little change. There has been speculation this year that the pattern may be broken by Chrysler. Chrysler's chief negotiator, Anthony St. John, has said simply continuing the current contract would increase labor costs by about 16 percent, an increase Chrysler can't afford. At news conferences following the opening of negotiations at each of the Big Three, UAW President Owen Bieber said the union had no intention of breaking the tradition. He said the union had worked too hard to bring the three contracts back in line with common expiration dates. It's the first time in 11 years that the contracts expire at once.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher; Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar climbed against most major currencies Friday in volatile trading as dealers divided their attention between news on the Persian Gulf crisis and evidence the U.S. economy may be on the verge of recession. Gold prices posted minor gains and losses in worldwide trading. Investors unloaded dollars early in the U.S. trading day, reacting to the latest economic statistics from Washington. A Labor Department report showing the nation's unemployment rate shot up to 5.5 percent in July from 5.2 percent in June sparked the selloff. Analysts said the report, which furnished one of the first insights into the economy's performance last month, flashed recession warning signals. The July jobless rate was the highest since it hit 5.6 percent in August 1988. But the turmoil in the Middle East in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait kept dealers on guard against selling dollars aggressively. The jump in oil prices since Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait early Thursday has been a key reason for the dollar's advance. Oil transactions are conducted in dollars. ``There still was a great deal of buying interest,'' said Kevin Lawrie, treasury manager at the Bank of Boston's office in New York. ``No one's comfortable going home short of dollars over the weekend when anything can happen out there.'' Rumors that Iraqi troops had begun an assault on Saudi Arabia signalled an escalation in the Persian Gulf conflict and temporarily gave investors an extra incentive to buy dollars as a safe haven currency. When word came later in the session that Iraq planned to withdraw its troops from Kuwait over the weekend, the dollar buying subsided somewhat. By the time trading was done in New York, the dollar stood at 149.925 Japanese yen, up from 149.30 yen Thursday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to close at 149.35 Japanese yen from 148.90 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 149.85 yen. Sterling's value against the dollar dipped in the United States. One British pound fetched $1.85375 late in New York, compared to $1.8545 late Thursday. In London, the pound rose to $1.8570 from $1.8495 late Thursday. Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late quotes, included: 1.5935 German marks, up from 1.5910; 1.3505 Swiss francs, down from 1.3530; 5.3415 French francs, up from 5.3320; 1,166.00 Italian lire, up from 1,164.50; and 1.15125 Canadian dollars, unchanged. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Thursday's late levels were: 1.5920 West German marks, down from 1.5970; 1.3505 Swiss francs, down from 1.3570; 5.3345 French francs, down from 5.3510; 1.7945 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7985; 1,164.90 Italian lire, down from 1,168.50, and 1.1510 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1519. Bullion dealers overseas said the precious metals markets were hectic with gold seesawing in a broad range. Domestic dealings were more subdued. Gold for current delivery settled at $377.40 a troy ounce, up 60 cents on on New York's Commodity Exchange. Republic National Bank later quoted a troy ounce of gold at $377.25, 35 cents higher than Thursday's late bid. In London, gold rose to a late bid of $379.25 a troy ounce from $378.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $378 an ounce from $379 late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $375.75 an ounce, down from $379.39 on Thursday. Silver bullion was unchanged in London from late Thursday's bid, closing at $4.87 an ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Macy Sells 1 Percent Stake; Says Agreement With Lenders Amended
DOC.TEXT: R.H. Macy & Co. Inc. on Thursday said its senior bank lenders have agreed to modify an agreement, making it slightly more lenient, which will give the retailer greater financial flexibility as it enters the important fall season. The New York-based retailer also said it has agreed to sell a 1 percent equity interest to the real estate development group Corporate Property Investors for $15 million in cash. Four other property developers already hold investments in Macy's. The decision to sell the stake to Corporate Property Investors recognizes ``our long-standing, ongoing relationship and prospective future real estate activities,'' Macy's said. Proceeds from the sale will be used to buy back its debt from time to time in the open market, Macy's said in a letter to its investors. The retailer periodically releases such letters to update investors on its financial condition. A copy was distributed to news media. The letter said Macy's conservative inventory management and expense plan for the spring appear to have paid off. Macy's had more cash available in late spring than it expected to have, possibly indicating that the department store operator is weathering the current poor retail environment better than private analysts anticipated. ``Our cash availability was almost $65 million higher for the 25th week this spring, when our needs peaked, than the $113 million projected in February to our banks and the factors,'' Macy's said. ``We are confident that this conservative approach will ensure a continuation of our liquid position in spite of a continuing soft retail environment,'' it said. The modification in the loan agreement reduced the amount of cash Macy's must have in relation to its debt. Macy's said the bank agreement didn't need to be modified until the end of October. But the company's lead bank lenders suggested that the amendment be made now ``so there would be no question about Macy's financial flexibility and liquidity as we enter the important fall season.'' The letter, signed by three executives including chairman Edward S. Finkelstein, said Macy's is reviewing a number of ways to reduce its interest costs. It didn't give specifics and said investors would be advised of Macy's debt cost-reduction plans as they develop.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plummet, Bonds Tumble on Economic, Gulf War Speculation
DOC.TEXT: Rising unemployment and fears of spreading Middle East conflict blasted the financial markets Friday. Stocks plummeted and interest rates jumped on speculation the battered U.S. economy could get worse. Feeding the turmoil was the government's report that unemployment rose 0.3 points to 5.5 percent in July, another sign the economy might be slipping into recession. Adding to the mix was the second straight day of sharply rising oil prices, a possible harbinger of higher inflation that could squeeze business and consumers alike. Weakened by the two-pronged fear, stock prices began tumbling early. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue chip industrial stocks fell more than 118 points by mid-afternoon. The sell-off was so swift that temporary ``circuit breaker'' halts in trading of Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures were triggered twice on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Nevertheless, the market rallied in later trading. The Dow finished down 54.95 at 2,809.65, extending its 34.66-point drop of Thursday. Helping grease the stock drop was a surge by interest rates in the long-term bonds, as traders reacted to the growing signs of higher inflation. The yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond finished at 8.56 percent, up from 8.45 percent late Thursday and 8.35 percent on Wednesday. Both markets reacted to the rise in oil prices, which have shot higher since immediately after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Thursday morning. Oil prices rose on speculation that supplies could be affected if the invasion escalated into an attack on neighboring Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest crude exporter. Such rumors periodically sent long-term bond prices lower, but Iraq announced late in the day it planned to begin withdrawing its troops from Kuwait on Sunday. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, traded up more than $2.50 a barrel at one point before settling at $24.49, up $1.38 from Thursday's close on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract rose $1.57 on Thursday. The surge in oil prices has been a blow to markets already concerned about the health of the U.S. economy. A sustained rise in crude prices is seen as boosting inflation, which reduces the chance the Federal Reserve will push interest rates lower to stimulate the economy. In foreign exchange, the dollar climbed against most major currencies in volatile trading as dealers divided their attention between the economic and Middle East news. The dollar rose to 149.925 Japanese yen in New York from 149.30 yen Thursday. Against the West German mark, the dollar rose to 1.5935 from 1.5910. Stock prices also tumbled overseas Friday in response to the Iraqi invasion. In Tokyo, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 729.42 points, ending the day at 29,515.76. The index lost nearly 593 points on Thursday. Japan is especially vulnerable to the possibility of a disruption of energy sources because it imports 99 percent of its oil. Traders there are concerned that the oil price rise will take a heavy toll on Japanese business. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 19.9 points, or 0.9 percent, to 2,284.6.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Term Bond Prices Plummet
DOC.TEXT: Long-term bond prices plunged again Friday as high unemployment and Middle East tensions battered the rumor-riddled credit markets. But short-term interest rates were hammered down after the Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate shot up to 5.5 percent in July from 5.2 percent in June. The report was another sign that the nation's faltering economy may be heading into a recession, which could herald lower interest rates. In the short end of the market, it temporarily overshadowed another day of inflation worries triggered by rising oil prices after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond tumbled 1[ points, or $11.25 per $1,000 in face value, on top of losses Thursday of more than $12. The bond's yield, which rises when the bond's price falls, climbed to 8.56 percent from 8.45 percent late Thursday. Economists said the unemployment report combined with a wave of other negative economic data in recent days normally would give the Federal Reserve enough reason to lower interest rates, which would boost bond prices. That sentiment was reflected among shorter maturity bills and bonds. But the longer end of the market was gripped by the belief that the spike in oil prices would fuel inflation worldwide. Inflation, which the Fed seeks to control through monetary policy, erodes the value of fixed-income securities such as bonds. ``The data was weak enough under normal circumstances to make people think the Fed would certainly ease,'' said James Capra, senior vice president with Shearson Lehman Government Securities Inc. ``But now the issue is will the oil prices move cause the Fed to pause or wait.'' Economists are concerned that a Fed lower interest during a time of price concerns, fanning inflation. Last month's jobless rate was the highest since it hit 5.6 percent in August 1988. The sharp increase largely reflected the economy's loss of 219,000 jobs. Though about 160,000 of those Americans who lost jobs were temporary census workers laid off by the government, private industry payrolls also lost 45,000 jobs, the government said. ``The market is trading in wide swings,'' Capra said. ``It's made it difficult for anyone but those with the strongest of views.'' The long end of the market was wracked by speculation about events in the Middle East, including unconfirmed rumors that Iraq was poised to possibly invade Saudi Arabia following its seizure of Kuwait. A serious escalation of hostilities in the region could push oil prices even higher, worsening the inflation and economic outlook. However, late in the day, Iraq said it planned to begin removing its troops from Kuwait on Sunday. Prices of short-term governments rose [ point, intermediate maturities ranged from unchanged to down 13-32 point and long-term issuestumbled 21-32 point to 31-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 2.66 to 1,164.71. Yields on three-month Treasury bills tumbled to 7.55 percent as the discount dropped 10 basis points to 7.32 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.57 percent as the discount dropped 9 basis points to 7.21 percent. Yields on one-year bills plunged to 7.55 percent as the discount lost 12 basis points to 7.06 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 7} percent, down from 8 percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 92}, down ]. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.34 percent from 7.31 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Developments, Recession Fears Roil Commodity Markets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Repeating to delete second display
DOC.TEXT: Recession fears, inflation worries and conflicting reports from the Persian Gulf ricocheted through U.S. commodity markets Friday, resulting in price moves with little relation to supply and demand factors. ``It seemed like a lot of attention was focused on what the latest rumors were,'' observed Tim Evans, a copper trader with Deak International Inc., a New York-based dealer of metals and currencies. Oil futures ended sharply higher despite active selling late in the session; precious metals were higher; copper futures fell; livestock and meat were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Commodity traders kept close watch on stock and crude-oil markets, where changing news reports about the Iraq-Kuwait situation caused wild price swings that rippled out to other markets. ``War is always bearish for stocks and bullish for commodities,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. The Persian Gulf situation seemed very bullish for commodities early in the day when rumors circulated that Iraqi troops had invaded Saudi Arabia from Kuwait, which probably would result in further disruptions of crude oil shipments to the United States. Those rumors were discounted but news reports then surfaced that Iraqi troops were just six miles from the Saudi border, causing another plunge in stock prices and sharp gains in many commodities. Newswires then reported Iraq had told the Soviet Union it planned to withdraw from Kuwait, prompting a strong rally on the stock market and selling in the commodity markets, particularly in crude oil. After most market had closed, reports came out that the Iraqi government would begin withdrawing troops from Kuwait on Sunday. To further complicate matters, the Labor Department reported Friday that nonfarm payroll employment fell by 219,000 in July and unemployment jumped three-tenths of a percentage point to 5.5 percent. The figures reinforced concern in the financial world that economic activity was weakening more than had been thought just a few weeks ago. The recession fears weighed heavily on the copper market, which is especially sensitive to signs of economic weakness, and on the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 120 points early in the afternoon, but recovered to finish with a loss of about 55 points. A similar plunge in stock-index futures prices tripped two ``circuit-breakers'' in the Standard & Poor's 500 index futures trading pit at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The circuit breakers are a series of trading halts and price limits intended to stop a runaway stock-market collapse. The contract for September delivery of the 500 stocks tracked by the index settled 6.62 points lower at 344.86. The contract is valued at $500 a point. Copper futures settled 2.4 cents to 3.4 cents lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in August at $1.261 a pound. Skyrocketing oil futures contributed to inflation fears, which prompted buying in the precious metal and soybean markets. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 68 cents to $1.38 higher with September at $24.49 a barrel; wholesale heating oil was .20 cent to 2.06 cent higher with September at 66.58 cents a gallon; wholesale unleaded gasoline was .70 cent to 4.11 cents higher with September at 72.18 cents a gallon. Gold futures ended 20 cents to 60 cents higher on the Commodity Exchange with August at $377.90 a troy ounce; silver was 0.5 cent to 0.7 cent higher with August at $4.842 a troy ounce. On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat futures settled 2 cents to 4{ cents lower with September at $2.80{ a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 3\ cents lower with September at $2.49{ a bushel; oats were 4} cents to 7 cents lower with September at $1.14 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 6\ cents higher with August at $5.86{ a bushel. DOC.HEAD: Court Approves Takeover Agreement, Company Announces Loss
DOC.TEXT: Allegheny International Inc. said Friday federal bankruptcy court had approved of an agreement giving a New York investment group control of the maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances. The company also announced $32.1 million in losses in its fiscal 1990 third quarter as consumer-products divisions posted decreased operating earnings. The U.S. Bankruptcy Court approval will allow the investors, Japonica Partners, to take control of Allegheny on Aug. 15. The deal, announced Thursday by committees representing company creditors and shareholders, is contingent on Japonica's ability to raise enough money. Allegheny's senior managers and board members would be ousted on that date by Japonica's handpicked managers and a board comprising nominees from Allegheny, bank creditors and unsecured creditors. The executive committee of Allegheny International's board of directors, which had opposed Japonica's assuming a position of power, unanimously approved the settlement Thursday. The full board ratified the deal Friday. Allegheny International filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws in February 1988. The company, to be renamed Sunbeam-Oster Companies Inc., initially will remain a publicly traded company. But Japonica is expected to own 90 percent of the stock, creditors' lawyers said at a bankruptcy court hearing. Japonica has said it intends to keep company headquarters in Pittsburgh, where Allegheny International employs about 60 people. The agreement would distribute stock and warrants to creditors and shareholders as specified in management's reorganization plan, but would require Japonica to buy the securities from anyone who wants to sell. The price would be $7 per share or $1.53 per warrant, except for bank creditors, who have agreed to accept $6.60 per share. Creditors would have the option of keeping their stock. Japonica would combine about $270 million in cash Allegheny International has on hand with $97 million in equity it has received from its primary investors to repay the company's bank lenders and trade creditors of the company's operating units. Japonica also would have to provide $100 million in working capital for the company's operations and a $10 million letter of credit to fund administrative expenses incurred after Aug. 15. The group also would have to honor severance agreements for Allegheny International's senior managers, which would cost $5.3 million. Japonica already has invested about $125 million to buy claims against Allegheny International, entitling it to receive about half of the reorganized company's stock. Japonica has said it intends to appoint William Webber, who ran the Sunbeam unit in the early 1980s, president of the reorganized company. In its earnings statement for the three months ended July 1, Allegheny International reported a loss of $3.51 per share, compared with a net loss of $15.3 million, or $2.10 a share, in the year-ago period. Sales increased 1 percent to $237.3 million from $234.9 million. For the fiscal 1990 nine-month period, the company reported a net loss of $42.6 million, or $5.89 a share, compared with a loss of $18.2 million, or $3.75 a share, in the year-ago period. Sales in the nine-month period fell 3 percent to $704.8 million from $730.2 million.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds Agency's Right To Sue for Racketeering
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ruled Friday that an agency created by Congress to protect securities investors can sue fraudulent brokers for racketeering and seek triple damages. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said the Securities Investor Protection Corp., can use the powerful Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act in civil suits against brokers. SIPC reimburses customers of failed brokers and can appoint a receiver to sell or liquidate an insolvent broker who has violated the law. If the broker's assets are not enough to pay claims, SIPC uses its own funds, collected from member institutions. The agency moved in 1981 to liquidate two brokerages, First State Securities Corp. and Joseph Sebag Inc., and said it had to spend nearly $13 million of its own funds to pay customer claims. SIPC then sued in federal court in Los Angeles against six companies and numerous individuals, claiming they had used the two brokers as vehicles to manipulate the companies' stock in the over-the-counter market. The lawsuit sought triple damages under RICO, claiming that the stock fraud had been a ``pattern of racketeering activity.'' A federal district judge dismissed the racketeering claim, saying SIPC had neither bought nor sold the securities in question, as required for a stock fraud suit. But the appeals court said RICO suits are not limited to buyers or sellers of stock. Noting that the RICO law expressly covers ``any person injured in his business or property by reason of a violation,'' the court said the law made no reference to a requirement that a plaintiff be a buyer or seller of securities. ``It is not appropriate for this court to impose such a limitation,'' Judge David Thompson said in the 3-0 ruling reinstating the RICO claim. Lawyers for both sides in the case said the ruling appeared broad enough to apply to some defrauded private investors as well. ``People who weren't buyers or sellers of stock which was the subject of manipulation could come in under RICO'' if they had suffered losses, said Stephen Taylor, a lawyer for SIPC. ``I think it is a broadening of the law and would have wide implications beyond SIPC,'' said Jack Mamet, a lawyer for defendant Robert G. Holmes Jr., the founder and president of Aero Systems Inc., one of the six companies whose stock was allegedly manipulated. Mamet said a Supreme Court appeal would be considered. Depending on the ruling's interpretation, Mamet said, an investor in a future case who held stock affected by fraud but who had not been induced to buy or sell the stock because of the fraud could be able to sue under RICO. SIPC is a nonprofit corporation whose membership consists of most registered brokers and dealers. It was established in 1970 after the collapse of several brokerage houses.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Higher, Share Prices Plunge
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened higher against the Japanese yen Friday morning, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The dollar opened at 149.77 yen, up 0.87 yen from Thursday's 148.90-yen close. On the stock market, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average quickly dropped 609.89 points, or 2.02 percent, falling to 29,635.29 within the first 30 minutes of morning trading. Following its strength against the yen in New York, the dollar opened higher and continued to rise as market players kept an eye on developments in the Iraq-Kuwait conflict, dealers said. Iraq invaded Kuwait and took control of its capital Thursday. The United States announced it will impose economic sanctions against Iraq, while the Soviet Union also decided to stop exporting military weapons to the Middle Eastern nation. ``Market players are still buying the dollar as a safe investment because of uncertainties in the Middle East situation,'' said Kimihiro Hashimoto, a trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. In New York, dealers unloaded yen due to concern that Japan would be hurt more than any other major industrialized country by disruptions in Mideast oil supplies. Japan depends on imports for nearly all its oil needs. Hashimoto said the dollar's surge quickly reversed a recent decline in the currency, but it might not lead to a long-term upward trend. ``Dollar trading will be affected for a while by pessimistic prospects for the U.S. economy and the Middle Eastern situation,'' Hashimoto said. Gloomy prospects for the U.S. economy makes the dollar less attractive, while concern over the Middle East crisis encourages buying the currency because the dollar is considered a safe haven in times of uncertainty. On the stock market, traders said share prices were lower across the board as the Iraq-Kuwait conflict continued to discourage market players, prompting large-scale selling. But Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co., said the general market sentiment reflected participants waiting for Friday's release of the U.S. jobless rate for July. ``Because of the persistent pessimistic prospects of U.S. economic growth, the dollar is not soaring that much today despite the Middle East situation. This will help stock investors calm down and support the market,'' he said. Other positive news for the market was a less-than-expected rise in oil prices in Tokyo, he said. The October Brent oil contract was quoted at 22.90 dollars, up nearly three dollars from Thursday. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 7.660 percent from Thursday's close at 7.615 percent. Their price fell to 84.91 points from 85.16 points.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Agrees to Sell Ford Aerospace for $715 Million to Loral
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to include more information on Loral and chairman's comments. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, The sale ...
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Friday it agreed to sell its Ford Aerospace Corp. subsidiary to the defense electronics company Loral Corp. for $715 million in cash. In addition, Loral will assume Ford Aerospace's liabilities and assets. Loral Chairman Bernard Schwartz said the debt was small _ perhaps less than $10 million. Ford officials declined to say what the liabilities were. Loral will more than double its size. The company now has about 13,000 employees and reported revenues of $1.3 billion and profits of more than $75 million for the fiscal year ended March 31. Schwartz said the corporation wasn't worried about cuts in Defense Department spending since his company is heavily involved in sophisticated surveillance systems. ``We're not the metal-benders,'' he said. ``We're in the high-tech portion of the business.'' The sale, which is subject to government approval, moves Ford closer to its goal of ridding itself of its non-automotive businesses. On Tuesday, Ford said it would form a joint venture with the Italian industrial giant Fiat Group, involving Ford's agricultural implement maker Ford New Holland. Fiat will hold 80 percent of the joint venture and Ford will own the rest. In February, Chrysler Corp. sold its Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. for $825 million. GM-Hughes Electronics Corp. is General Motors Corp.'s aerospace subsidiary. GM has no intention of selling all or part of GM-Hughes. In fact, GM-Hughes was part of a consortium of companies which submitted a bid for Ford Aerospace that ultimately was rejected. A joint Ford-Loral news release said the Ford Aerospace sale is not subject to financing conditions. Last week, when Ford and Loral entered final negotiations, Loral said it would form a new corporation with the merchant banking operations of Shearson Lehman Hutton of New York for the acquisition. There has been no mention during any of the wrangling that led to the purchase that Loral would break up Ford Aerospace, a Newport Beach, Calif.-based company with about 17,000 employees worldwide. In a brief statement Friday, Loral said it had no plans to spin off any of Ford Aerospace's business or for major changes in the company's operations. Ford Aerospace received about $1.8 billion in contract awards last year and had a backlog of about $2 billion in contracts at the end of last year.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT close of S&P 500 to 344.86.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices sold off sharply in a convulsive session Friday as the market reacted to Middle East oil worries and mounting recession fears. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down more than 120 points at its midsession low, closed with a 54.95-point loss at 2,809.65. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 5 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 264 up, 1,457 down and 305 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board reached a 1990 high of 292.36 million shares, against 253.09 million in the previous session. Selling also pounded the over-the-counter market, where technology stocks showed steep losses. The Labor Department reported Friday morning that nonfarm payroll employment fell by 219,000 in July, surprising analysts who had been looking for a modest increase. The civilian unemployment rate jumped three-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent. Those figures reinforced concern in the financial world that economic activity was weakening more than had been thought just a few weeks ago. Many observers fear the economy's problems could be compounded by a jump in oil prices arising from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait this week. Selling intensified as reports reached Wall Street that Iraqi forces were near the border of Saudi Arabia. It subsequently let up a bit when a Soviet official said Iraq was expected to withdraw from Kuwait in the near future. After the close in New York, Iraq confirmed that it planned to begin pulling back forces from Kuwait on Sunday. The session marked the second time in the last two weeks that the Dow fell more than 100 points intraday before recovering some of its loss. On July 23 the average plummeted in the first hour, then finished with a net deficit of 56.44 points. Among the blue chips, International Business Machines dropped 1| to 108[; Procter & Gamble 2\ to 80; General Motors { to 43]; General Electric ~ to 69}, and American Express \ to 27}. In the energy sector, by contrast, prominent oil issues climbed in early trading and then turned back. Exxon dropped [ to 53[; Texaco 1\ to 64|, and Mobil ] to 66~ even as oil prices kept climbing. In the over-the-counter market, Apple Computer fell 2\ to 41\; MCI Communications 1 to 35}, and Intel 1 to 39\. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 345.20 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $66.55 billion, or 1.99 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 3.54 to 188.82. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 8.23 to 407.06, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 6.62 at 344.86. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market tumbled 11.43 to 417.46. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 346.63, down 5.52.

DOC.HEAD: More Manufacturers Selling Their Own Stuff, So Who Needs Department Stores?
Graphic in AP Access under FACOUTLETS
DOC.TEXT: Vacationers bound for summer getaways will notice something has happened to out-of-the-way tourist spots. Many have become miniature shopping meccas catering to devoted bargain seekers. Clusters of shops carrying discounted designer duds have sprouted up all over the country. More manufacturers whose wares are normally peddled by mainstream retailers are striking out on their own. Outlet complexes are thriving in areas frequented by tourists, who have the time to browse for good buys. Busloads of pricewise shoppers regularly pour in. Elsewhere, outlets grouped near major thoroughfares are catching the attention of passers-by. The trend has ominous implications for traditional retailing. It won't run all regular stores out of business. But it does mean more competition in a saturated industry already fraught with fierce battling for market share. Sales at outlets are growing faster than general retail revenues, although they still account for a small portion of retailing. Outlets generated nearly $6 billion in sales last year, according to Value Retail News, a Clearwater, Fla.-based publication that tracks the industry. By contrast, a single retailer, industry biggie Sears, Roebuck and Co., alone had 1989 sales of over $30 billion. ``People like the excitement of shopping in a factory outlet. They like the prices,'' says Lynn Ellsworth, president of Company Stores Development Corp., a Brentwood, Tenn.-based builder of outlet malls and a pioneer in the field. Manufacturers have several incentives to sell directly to consumers. It allows them to control the process of getting rid of leftovers rather than risk problems that can crop up when they unload merchandise on liquidators. Close-out chains and off-price merchants _ which absorb excess apparel and sell it at discount _ often compete for customers with nearby department stores and other regular retailers. Manufacturers usually make sure their own outlets are far away from major shopping hubs so they don't jeopardize sales of their labels selling at full-price stores or upset relations with retailers, their primary customers. ``We purposely stay away from traditional retailers,'' notes Benard Holtzman, president of apparel designer Harve Benard Ltd. Clothing companies, accessory makers and others that go into retailing must tred carefully. The last thing they want is for outlet customers to return home gloating to their local retailer about the great deal they got. Women's apparel powerhouse Liz Claiborne Inc. has located its 22 outlet stores 45 minutes to an hour away from regular retailers selling its label. Ritzy Ralph Lauren's lines are sold at discount outlets deliberately situated 90 miles to 120 miles away from places where the Polo collection is sold in full-price, company-owned boutiques and department stores. Nevertheless, the issue is so touchy that manufacturers don't exactly go out of their way to publicize their involvement in the outlet business. Some even disguise their name, meaning customers can't tell who owns an outlet. Pricy Izod-Lacoste sportswear is sold at outlets called Fashion Flair, for instance. Irked by the trend, the National Shoe Retailers Association recently adopted a resolution expressing disapproval of the proliferation of company-owned factory outlets. Independent shoe retailers are up in arms because, they say, manufacturers are bypassing them in channeling merchandise to outlets. Association President Bill Boettge said the group believes independent shoe sellers are being treated unfairly. He said the group isn't trying to start a national boycott but some association members are refusing to carry merchandise of manufacturers that operate their own outlets. From a manufacturer's point of view, it makes good business sense to look for new channels of distribution. Upheaval in the retail industry, intensifed by the bankruptcy filings of big name chains, including the parent companies of Bloomingdale's, The Bon Marche, Lazarus and others, has made manufacturers nervous about depending on department stores to market merchandise. No longer mere havens for fashion has-beens, manufacturers increasingly use their factory outlets to showcase merchandise. Phillips-Van Heusen Corp. reportedly does half its business in its own outlets, marketing Van Heusen Shirts and shoes from its G.H. Bass & Co. division. Commercial developers say projects involving outlets tend to get financial backing more easily in these tight money days than construction of traditional retail centers. Although lenders have tightened up their practices after the savings and loan debacle, they're still willing to support sound deals. Conventional retailers may be on the ropes but factory outlets look like they're on stable ground, according to Richard Echikson, chairman of Millburn, N.J.-based Retail Consultants Inc., which helps clients assess potential retail investments. ``There is an increasing interest in the financial community and development community in true factory outlet malls,'' says Echikson. With financial backing, an increasing number of outlets has gone upscale, offering entertainment and other amenities. The Woodbury Common in Central Valley, N.Y., for instance, recreates a village setting. Malls are growing bigger, too. Benderson Development Co., out of Buffalo, N.Y., plans to open what it claims will be the world's largest manufacturers' outlet mall late next year in downtown Niagara Falls. Not all outlets are in the middle of nowhere or even near prime tourist attractions. Many outlets have been moving closer to metropolitan areas as more manufacturers get into the act. According to Value Retail News, the number of outlet chains has mushroomed, and last year more were opened than ever before in a single year. By the middle of this year, there were about 350 chains in operation, up from 264 at the start of 1989. The popularity is expected to continue as consumers save more of their incomes than they did during the free-spending '80s. Aging baby boomers are keen on bargains now that they are tucking away spare dollars for their tots' educations. Charles Bloom, chairman of the Chelsea Group, a New Jersey-based developer, owner and operator of factory outlet shopping centers, says the concept complements traditional retailing and will never supplant it. ``Without retail, there is no wholesale,'' he notes. ``You couldn't buy a bargain if it wasn't selling for a higher price somewhere else.''
